Text

[The Rev. Septimus Harding]100-septimus harding was , a few years since , [a beneficed clergyman residing in [the cathedral town of —]251-the cathedral town of —]250-a beneficed clergyman residing in the cathedral town of — ; let [us]252-us call [it]251-the cathedral town of — [Barchester]6-barchester . Were [we]252-us to name [Wells]101-wells or [Salisbury]2-salisbury , [Exeter]3-exeter , [Hereford]4-hereford , or [Gloucester]5-gloucester , it might be presumed that something personal was intended ; and as this tale will refer mainly to [the cathedral dignitaries of [the town]254-the town in question]253-the cathedral dignitaries of the town in question , [we]252-us are anxious that no personality may be suspected . Let [us]252-us presume that [Barchester]6-barchester is [a quiet town in the West of England]255-a quiet town in the west of england , more remarkable for the beauty of [[its]6-barchester cathedral]256-its cathedral and the antiquity of [its]6-barchester monuments , than for any commercial prosperity ; that [the west end of [Barchester]6-barchester]257-the west end of barchester is [the cathedral]258-the cathedral close , and that [the aristocracy of [Barchester]6-barchester]259-the aristocracy of barchester are [the bishop]260-the bishop , [dean]261-dean , and [canons]262-canons , with [[their]259-the aristocracy of barchester respective wives]263-their respective wives and [daughters]264-daughters . Early in life [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding found [himself]102-mr. harding located at [Barchester]6-barchester . A fine voice and a taste for sacred music had decided the position in which [he]102-mr. harding was to exercise [his]102-mr. harding calling , and for many years [he]102-mr. harding performed the easy but not highly paid duties of [a minor canon]265-a minor canon . At the age of forty a small living in [the close vicinity of [the town]254-the town]266-the close vicinity of the town increased both [his]102-mr. harding work and [his]102-mr. harding income , and at the age of fifty [he]102-mr. harding became [precentor of [the cathedral]258-the cathedral]268-precentor of the cathedral . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had married early in life , and was [the father of two daughters]270-the father of two daughters . [The eldest]271-the eldest , [Susan]103-susan , was born soon after [his]102-mr. harding marriage ; the other , [Eleanor]104-eleanor , not till ten years later . At the time at which [we]272-we introduce [him]102-mr. harding to [[our]272-we readers]273-our readers [he]102-mr. harding was living as precentor at [Barchester]6-barchester with [[his]102-mr. harding youngest daughter]274-his youngest daughter , then twenty - four years of age ; having been many years [a widower]275-a widower , and having married [[his]102-mr. harding eldest daughter]276-his eldest daughter to [a son of [the bishop]260-the bishop]277-a son of the bishop , a very short time before [his]102-mr. harding installation to the office of [precentor]279-precentor . Scandal at [Barchester]6-barchester affirmed that had it not been for the beauty of [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding would have remained [a minor canon]265-a minor canon ; but here probably [Scandal]105-scandal lied , as [she]280-his daughter so often does ; for even as [a minor canon]265-a minor canon [no one]283-no one had been more popular among [[his]102-mr. harding reverend brethren]284-his reverend brethren in the close , than [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ; and [Scandal]105-scandal , before [she]105-scandal had reprobated [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding for being made precentor by [[his]102-mr. harding friend]285-his friend [the bishop]260-the bishop , had loudly blamed [the bishop]260-the bishop for having so long omitted to do something for [[his]102-mr. harding friend]285-his friend [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . Be this as it may , [Susan Harding]103-susan , some twelve years since , had married [the Rev. Dr. Theophilus Grantly]106-dr. grantly , [son of [the bishop]260-the bishop , [archdeacon of [Barchester]6-barchester]291-archdeacon of barchester , and [rector of [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi]292-rector of plumstead episcopi]289-son of the bishop , archdeacon of barchester , and rector of plumstead episcopi , and [[her]103-susan father]293-her father became , a few months later , [precentor of [Barchester Cathedral]8-barchester cathedral]294-precentor of barchester cathedral , that office being , as is not usual , in [the bishop]260-the bishop 's gift . Now there are peculiar circumstances connected with the precentorship which must be explained . In the year 1434 there died at [Barchester]6-barchester [one John Hiram]296-one john hiram , who had made money in [the town]254-the town as [a woolstapler]298-a woolstapler , and in [his]296-one john hiram will [he]296-one john hiram left the house in which [he]296-one john hiram died and certain meadows and closes near [the town]254-the town , still called [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's Butts]9-hiram 's butts , and [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's Patch]10-hiram 's patch , for the support of twelve superannuated wool - carders , [all of whom should have been born and bred and spent [their]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester days in [Barchester]6-barchester]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester ; [he]296-one john hiram also appointed that [an alms - house]301-an alms - house should be built for [[their]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester abode]302-their abode , with a fitting residence for [a warden]303-a warden , which [warden]304-warden was also to receive a certain sum annually out of the rents of the said butts and patches . [He]296-one john hiram , moreover , willed , having had a soul alive to harmony , that [the precentor of [the cathedral]258-the cathedral]305-the precentor of the cathedral should have the option of being also [warden of [the alms - houses]308-the alms - houses]307-warden of the alms - houses , if [the bishop]260-the bishop in each case approved . From that day to this the charity had gone on and prospered — at least , the charity had gone on , and [the estates]310-the estates had prospered . Wool - carding in [Barchester]6-barchester there was no longer any ; so [the bishop]260-the bishop , [dean]261-dean , and [warden , who took it in turn to put in]313-warden , who took it in turn to put in [the old men]314-the old men , generally appointed some hangers - on of [their]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester own ; [worn - out gardeners]315-worn - out gardeners , [decrepid grave - diggers]316-decrepid grave - diggers , or [octogenarian sextons , who thankfully received a comfortable lodging and one shilling and fourpence a day]317-octogenarian sextons , who thankfully received a comfortable lodging and one shilling and fourpence a day , such being the stipend to which , under the will of [John Hiram]107-john hiram , [they]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester were declared to be entitled . Formerly , indeed,—that is , till within some fifty years of the present time,—they received but sixpence a day , and [their]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester breakfast and dinner was found [them]300-all of whom should have been born and bred and spent their days in barchester at a common table by [the warden]318-the warden , such an arrangement being in stricter conformity with the absolute wording of [old Hiram]107-john hiram 's will : but this was thought to be inconvenient , and to suit the tastes of neither [warden]304-warden nor [bedesmen]320-bedesmen , and the daily one shilling and fourpence was substituted with the common consent of all parties , including [the bishop]260-the bishop and [the corporation of [Barchester]6-barchester]322-the corporation of barchester . Such was the condition of [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's twelve old men]323-hiram 's twelve old men when [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was appointed [warden]304-warden ; but if [they]323-hiram 's twelve old men may be considered as well - to - do in [the world]325-the world according to [their]323-hiram 's twelve old men condition , [the happy warden]326-the happy warden was much more so . The patches and butts which , in [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's time , produced hay or fed cows , were now covered with rows of [houses]327-houses ; the value of [the property]328-the property had gradually increased from year to year , and century to century , and was now presumed by [those who knew anything about it , to bring in a very nice income]329-those who knew anything about it , to bring in a very nice income ; and by [some who knew nothing about it , to have increased to an almost fabulous extent]330-some who knew nothing about it , to have increased to an almost fabulous extent . [The property]328-the property was farmed by [a gentleman in [Barchester]6-barchester , who also acted as [[the bishop]260-the bishop 's steward]334-the bishop 's steward]332-a gentleman in barchester , who also acted as the bishop 's steward — [a man whose father and grandfather had been stewards to [the bishops of [Barchester]6-barchester]336-the bishops of barchester , and farmers of [[John Hiram]107-john hiram 's estate]337-john hiram 's estate]335-a man whose father and grandfather had been stewards to the bishops of barchester , and farmers of john hiram 's estate . [The Chadwicks]108-the chadwicks had earned a good name in [Barchester]6-barchester ; [they]108-the chadwicks had lived respected by [bishops]338-bishops , [deans]339-deans , [canons]262-canons , and [precentors]341-precentors ; [they]108-the chadwicks had been buried in [the precincts of [the cathedral]258-the cathedral]342-the precincts of the cathedral ; [they]108-the chadwicks had never been known as [griping , hard men]344-griping , hard men , but had always lived comfortably , maintained [a good house]345-a good house , and held a high position in [Barchester]6-barchester society . [The present Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick was [a worthy scion of a worthy stock]346-a worthy scion of a worthy stock , and [the tenants living on the butts and patches]347-the tenants living on the butts and patches , as well as those on [the wide episcopal domains of the see]348-the wide episcopal domains of the see , were well pleased to have to do with so worthy and liberal [a steward]349-a steward . For many , many years,—records hardly tell how many , probably from the time when [Hiram]107-john hiram 's wishes had been first fully carried out,—the proceeds of the estate had been paid by [the steward]350-the steward or [farmer]351-farmer to [the warden]318-the warden , and by [him]318-the warden divided among [the bedesmen]353-the bedesmen ; after which division [he]318-the warden paid [himself]318-the warden such sums as became [his]318-the warden due . Times had been when [the poor warden]354-the poor warden got nothing but [[his]354-the poor warden bare house]355-his bare house , for the patches had been subject to floods , and [the land of [Barchester butts]6-barchester]356-the land of barchester butts was said to be unproductive ; and in these hard times , [the warden]318-the warden was hardly able to make out the daily dole for [[his]318-the warden twelve dependents]358-his twelve dependents . But by degrees things mended ; the patches were drained , and [cottages]359-cottages began to rise upon the butts , and [the wardens]360-the wardens , with fairness enough , repaid [themselves]360-the wardens for the evil days gone by . In bad times [the poor men]361-the poor men had had [their]361-the poor men due , and therefore in good times [they]361-the poor men could expect no more . In this manner the income of [the warden]318-the warden had increased ; [the picturesque house attached to [the hospital]364-the hospital]363-the picturesque house attached to the hospital had been enlarged and adorned , and the office had become one of the most coveted of the snug clerical sinecures attached to [[our]365-our church]366-our church . It was now wholly in [the bishop]260-the bishop 's gift , and though [the dean and chapter]368-the dean and chapter , in former days , made a stand on the subject , [they]368-the dean and chapter had thought it more conducive to [their]368-the dean and chapter honour to have [a rich precentor appointed by [the bishop]260-the bishop]369-a rich precentor appointed by the bishop , than [a poor one appointed by [themselves]368-the dean and chapter]371-a poor one appointed by themselves . The stipend of [the precentor of]372-the precentor of [Barchester]6-barchester was eighty pounds a year . The income arising from the wardenship of [the hospital]364-the hospital was eight hundred , besides the value of [the house]374-the house . Murmurs , very slight murmurs , had been heard in [Barchester,—few]12-barchester,—few indeed , and far between,—that the proceeds of [[John Hiram]107-john hiram 's property]375-john hiram 's property had not been fairly divided : but they can hardly be said to have been of such a nature as to have caused uneasiness to any one : still the thing had been whispered , and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had heard it . Such was [his]102-mr. harding character in [Barchester]6-barchester , so universal was [his]102-mr. harding popularity , that the very fact of [his]102-mr. harding appointment would have quieted louder whispers than those which had been heard ; but [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was [an open - handed , just - minded man]376-an open - handed , just - minded man , and feeling that there might be truth in what had been said , [he]102-mr. harding had , on [his]102-mr. harding instalment , declared [his]102-mr. harding intention of adding twopence a day to [each man]377-each man 's pittance , making a sum of sixty - two pounds eleven shillings and fourpence , which [he]102-mr. harding was to pay out of [his]102-mr. harding own pocket . In doing so , however , [he]102-mr. harding distinctly and repeatedly observed to [the men]378-the men , that though [he]102-mr. harding promised for [himself]102-mr. harding , [he]102-mr. harding could not promise for [[his]102-mr. harding successors]379-his successors , and that the extra twopence could only be looked on as a gift from [himself]102-mr. harding , and not from the trust . [The bedesmen]353-the bedesmen , however , were most of [them]353-the bedesmen older than [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , and were quite satisfied with the security on which [their]353-the bedesmen extra income was based . This munificence on the part of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had not been unopposed . [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick had mildly but seriously dissuaded [him]102-mr. harding from it ; and [[his]109-mr. chadwick strong - minded son - in - law]381-his strong - minded son - in - law , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , [the man of whom alone [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding]383-the man of whom alone mr. harding stood in awe , had urgently , nay , vehemently , opposed so impolitic a concession : but [the warden]318-the warden had made known [his]318-the warden intention to [the hospital]364-the hospital before [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon had been able to interfere , and the deed was done . [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's Hospital]387-hiram 's hospital , as [the retreat]388-the retreat is called , is [a picturesque building enough]389-a picturesque building enough , and shows the correct taste with which [the ecclesiastical architects of those days]390-the ecclesiastical architects of those days were imbued . [It]387-hiram 's hospital stands on [the banks of [the little river]392-the little river , which flows nearly round [the cathedral close]393-the cathedral close , being on the side furthest from [the town]254-the town]391-the banks of the little river , which flows nearly round the cathedral close , being on the side furthest from the town . [The London road]395-the london road crosses [the river]396-the river by [a pretty one - arched bridge]397-a pretty one - arched bridge , and , looking from [this bridge]398-this bridge , [the stranger]399-the stranger will see the windows of [[the old men]314-the old men 's rooms]401-the old men 's rooms , each pair of windows separated by a small buttress . [A broad gravel walk]402-a broad gravel walk runs between [the building]403-the building and [the river]396-the river , which is always trim and cared for ; and at the end of the walk , under the parapet of the approach to [the bridge]405-the bridge , is a large and well - worn seat , on which , in mild weather , three or four of [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's bedesmen]406-hiram 's bedesmen are sure to be seen seated . Beyond this row of buttresses , and further from [the bridge]405-the bridge , and also further from the water which here suddenly bends , are the pretty oriel windows of [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's house]408-mr. harding 's house , and [[his]102-mr. harding well - mown lawn]409-his well - mown lawn . The entrance to [the hospital]364-the hospital is from [the [London]13-london road]395-the london road , and is made through a ponderous gateway under a heavy stone arch , unnecessary , one would suppose , at any time , for the protection of [twelve old men]412-twelve old men , but greatly conducive to the good appearance of [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's charity]413-hiram 's charity . On passing through this portal , never closed to any one from six A. M. till ten P. M. , and never open afterwards , except on application to a huge , intricately hung , mediæeaval bell , the handle of which [no uninitiated intruder]414-no uninitiated intruder can possibly find , the six doors of [[the old men]314-the old men 's abodes]416-the old men 's abodes are seen , and beyond [them]417-them is a slight iron screen , through which the more happy portion of [the Barchester élite]418-the barchester élite pass into [the Elysium of [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's dwelling]420-mr. harding 's dwelling]419-the elysium of mr. harding 's dwelling . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding is [a small man , now verging on sixty years , but bearing few of the signs of age]421-a small man , now verging on sixty years , but bearing few of the signs of age ; [his]102-mr. harding hair is rather grizzled , though not grey , [his]102-mr. harding eye is very mild , but clear and bright , though the double glasses which are held swinging from [his]102-mr. harding hand , unless when fixed upon [his]102-mr. harding nose , show that time has told upon [his]102-mr. harding sight : [his]102-mr. harding hands are delicately white , and both hands and feet are small ; [he]102-mr. harding always wears a black frock coat , black knee - breeches , and black gaiters , and somewhat scandalises some of [his]102-mr. harding more hyperclerical brethren by a black neck - handkerchief . [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's warmest admirers]422-mr. harding 's warmest admirers can not say that [he]102-mr. harding was ever [an industrious man]423-an industrious man ; the circumstances of [his]102-mr. harding life have not called on [him]102-mr. harding to be so ; and yet [he]102-mr. harding can hardly be called [an idler]424-an idler . Since [his]102-mr. harding appointment to [his]102-mr. harding precentorship , [he]102-mr. harding has published , with all possible additions of vellum , typography , and gilding , a collection of [our]425-we ancient church music , with some correct dissertations on [Purcell]110-purcell , [Crotch]111-crotch , and [Nares]112-nares . [He]102-mr. harding has greatly improved [the choir of [Barchester]6-barchester]426-the choir of barchester , which , under [his]102-mr. harding dominion , now rivals that of [any cathedral in [England]14-england]427-any cathedral in england . [He]102-mr. harding has taken something more than [his]102-mr. harding fair share in the cathedral services , and has played the violoncello daily to such audiences as [he]102-mr. harding could collect , or , faute de mieux , to [no audience at all]428-no audience at all . [We]425-we must mention one other peculiarity of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . As [we]425-we have before stated , [he]102-mr. harding has an income of eight hundred a year , and has [no family]429-no family but [[his]102-mr. harding one daughter]430-his one daughter ; and yet [he]102-mr. harding is never quite at ease in money matters . The vellum and gilding of " [Harding]102-mr. harding 's Church Music , "[433-the publisher] cost more than [any one]431-any one knows , except [the author]432-the author , [the publisher]433-the publisher , and [the Rev. [Theophilus Grantly]106-dr. grantly , who allows none of [[his]102-mr. harding father - in - law]435-his father - in - law 's extravagances to escape [him]102-mr. harding]434-the rev. theophilus grantly , who allows none of his father - in - law 's extravagances to escape him . Then [he]102-mr. harding is generous to [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter , for whose service [he]102-mr. harding keeps [a small carriage]437-a small carriage and pair of ponies . [He]102-mr. harding is , indeed , generous to all , but especially to [the twelve old men who are in a peculiar manner under [his]102-mr. harding care]438-the twelve old men who are in a peculiar manner under his care . No doubt with such an income [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding should be above [the world]325-the world , as the saying is ; but at any rate , [he]102-mr. harding is not above [Archdeacon Theophilus Grantly]113-archdeacon grantly , for [he]102-mr. harding is always more or less in debt to [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law , who has , to a certain extent , assumed the arrangement of [the precentor]441-the precentor 's pecuniary affairs . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding has been now [precentor of [Barchester]6-barchester]442-precentor of barchester for ten years ; and , alas , the murmurs respecting the proceeds of [Hiram]107-john hiram 's estate are again becoming audible . It is not that [any one]431-any one begrudges to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding the income which [he]102-mr. harding enjoys , and the comfortable place which so well becomes [him]102-mr. harding ; but such matters have begun to be talked of in [various parts of [England]14-england]444-various parts of england . [Eager pushing politicians]445-eager pushing politicians have asserted in [the House of Commons]446-the house of commons , with very telling indignation , that [the grasping priests of [the Church of]15-the church of [England]14-england]447-the grasping priests of the church of england are gorged with the wealth which the charity of former times has left for the solace of [the aged]448-the aged , or the education of [the young]449-the young . The wellknown case of [the Hospital of St. Cross]450-the hospital of st. cross , has even come before [the law courts of [the country]452-the country]451-the law courts of the country , and the struggles of [Mr. Whiston]114-mr. whiston , at [Rochester]16-rochester , have met with sympathy and support . [Men]453-men are beginning to say that these things must be looked into . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , whose conscience in the matter is clear , and who has never felt that [he]102-mr. harding had received a pound from [Hiram]107-john hiram 's will to which [he]102-mr. harding was not entitled , has naturally taken the part of [the church]454-the church in talking over these matters with [[his]102-mr. harding friend]285-his friend , [the bishop]260-the bishop , and [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , indeed , [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , has been somewhat loud in the matter : [he]382-the archdeacon is [a personal friend of [the dignitaries of the Rochester Chapter]461-the dignitaries of the rochester chapter]460-a personal friend of the dignitaries of the rochester chapter , and has written letters in the public press on the subject of that turbulent [Dr. Whiston]115-dr. whiston , which , [[his]102-mr. harding admirers]462-his admirers think , must well nigh set the question at rest . It is also known at [Oxford]17-oxford , that [he]102-mr. harding is the author of the pamphlet signed " Sacerdos "[102-mr. harding] on the subject of [the Earl of]463-the earl of [Guildford]18-guildford and [St. Cross]19-st. cross , in which it is so clearly argued that the manners of the present times do not admit of a literal adhesion to the very words of [the founder]464-the founder 's will , but that the interests of the church for which [the founder]464-the founder was so deeply concerned , are best consulted in enabling [[its]466-its bishops]467-its bishops to reward [those shining lights , whose services have been most signally serviceable to Christianity]468-those shining lights , whose services have been most signally serviceable to christianity . In answer to this , it is asserted that [Henry de Blois]116-henry , [founder of [St. Cross]19-st. cross]469-founder of st. cross , was not greatly interested in the welfare of [the reformed church]470-the reformed church , and that [the masters of St. Cross]471-the masters of st. cross , for many years past , can not be called shining lights in the service of [Christianity]117-christianity ; it is , however , stoutly maintained , and no doubt felt , by [all [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's friends]472-all the archdeacon 's friends , that [his]102-mr. harding logic is conclusive , and has not , in fact , been answered . With such a tower of strength to back both [his]102-mr. harding arguments and [his]102-mr. harding conscience , it may be imagined that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding has never felt any compunction as to receiving [his]102-mr. harding quarterly sum of two hundred pounds . Indeed , the subject has never presented itself to [his]102-mr. harding mind in that shape . [He]102-mr. harding has talked not unfrequently , and heard very much about the wills of [old founders]474-old founders and the incomes arising from [[their]474-old founders estates]475-their estates , during the last year or two ; [he]102-mr. harding did even , at one moment , feel a doubt ( since expelled by [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law 's logic ) as to whether [Lord Guildford]118-lord guildford was clearly entitled to receive so enormous an income as [he]118-lord guildford does from the revenues of [St. Cross]19-st. cross ; but that [he]118-lord guildford [himself]118-lord guildford was overpaid with [his]118-lord guildford modest eight hundred pounds ; — [he]118-lord guildford who , out of that , voluntarily gave up sixty - two pounds eleven shillings and fourpence a year to [[his]118-lord guildford twelve old neighbours;—he who , for the money , does [his]118-lord guildford precentor]477-his twelve old neighbours;—he who , for the money , does his precentor 's work as [no precentor]478-no precentor has done it before , since [Barchester Cathedral]8-barchester cathedral was built;—such an idea has never sullied [his]102-mr. harding quiet , or disturbed [his]102-mr. harding conscience . Nevertheless , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding is becoming uneasy at the rumour which [he]102-mr. harding knows to prevail in [Barchester]6-barchester on the subject . [He]102-mr. harding is aware that , at any rate , [two of [[his]102-mr. harding old men]480-his old men]479-two of his old men have been heard to say , that if [every one]481-every one had [his]481-every one own , [they]479-two of his old men might each have [their]479-two of his old men hundred pounds a year , and live like [gentlemen]482-gentlemen , instead of [a beggarly one shilling and sixpence a day]483-a beggarly one shilling and sixpence a day ; and that [they]479-two of his old men had slender cause to be thankful for a miserable dole of twopence , when [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding and [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , between [them]479-two of his old men , ran away with thousands of pounds which [good old John Hiram]107-john hiram never intended for the like of [them]479-two of his old men . It is the ingratitude of this which stings [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . One of [this discontented pair]484-this discontented pair , [Abel Handy]119-handy , was put into [the hospital]364-the hospital by [himself]119-handy ; [he]119-handy had been [a stonemason in [Barchester]6-barchester]486-a stonemason in barchester , and had broken [his]119-handy thigh by a fall from a scaffolding , while employed about [the cathedral]258-the cathedral ; and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had given [him]119-handy the first vacancy in [the hospital]364-the hospital after the occurrence , although [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly had been very anxious to put into it [an insufferable clerk of [his]106-dr. grantly at [Plumstead]20-plumstead Episcopi , who had lost all [his]106-dr. grantly teeth , and whom [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon hardly knew how to get rid of by other means]489-an insufferable clerk of his at plumstead episcopi , who had lost all his teeth , and whom the archdeacon hardly knew how to get rid of by other means . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly has not forgotten to remind [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding how well satisfied with [his]102-mr. harding one and sixpence a day [old Joe Mutters]120-joe would have been , and how injudicious it was on the part of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding to allow [a radical from [the town]254-the town]491-a radical from the town to get into the concern . [Probably Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly forgot , at the moment , that the charity was intended for [broken - down journeymen of [Barchester]6-barchester]493-broken - down journeymen of barchester . There is living at [Barchester]6-barchester , [a young man]494-a young man , [a surgeon]495-a surgeon , named [John Bold]121-bold , and both [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding and [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly are well aware that to [him]494-a young man is owing the pestilent rebellious feeling which has shown itself in [the hospital]364-the hospital ; yes , and the renewal , too , of that disagreeable talk about [Hiram]107-john hiram 's estates which is now again prevalent in [Barchester]6-barchester . Nevertheless , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding and [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold are acquainted with [each other]497-each other ; [we]498-we may say , are [friends]499-friends , considering the great disparity in [their]500-their years . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , however , has a holy horror of [the impious demagogue]501-the impious demagogue , as on one occasion [he]106-dr. grantly called [Bold]122-mr. bold , when speaking of [him]122-mr. bold to [the precentor]441-the precentor ; and being [a more prudent far - seeing man]503-a more prudent far - seeing man than [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , and possessed of a stronger head , [he]106-dr. grantly already perceives that [this John Bold]121-bold will work great trouble in [Barchester]6-barchester . [He]106-dr. grantly considers that [he]121-bold is to be regarded as [an enemy]504-an enemy , and thinks that [he]121-bold should not be admitted into [the camp]505-the camp on anything like friendly terms . As [John Bold]121-bold will occupy much of [our]498-we attention , [we]498-we must endeavour to explain who [he]121-bold is , and why [he]121-bold takes the part of [[John Hiram]107-john hiram 's bedesmen]506-john hiram 's bedesmen . [John Bold]121-bold is [a young surgeon]507-a young surgeon , who passed many of [his]121-bold boyish years at [Barchester]6-barchester . [[His]121-bold father]508-his father was [a physician in [[the city of]510-the city of [London]13-london , where [he]508-his father made a moderate fortune , which [he]508-his father invested in houses in [that city]512-that city]511-the city of london , where he made a moderate fortune , which he invested in houses in that city]509-a physician in the city of london , where he made a moderate fortune , which he invested in houses in that city . [The Dragon - of - Wantly inn]513-the dragon - of - wantly inn and [posting - house]514-posting - house , belonged to [him]508-his father , also [four shops in [the High Street]516-the high street]515-four shops in the high street , and a moiety of [the new row of [genteel villas]518-genteel villas]517-the new row of genteel villas ( so called in the advertisements ) , built outside [the town]254-the town just beyond [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's Hospital]387-hiram 's hospital . To one of these [Dr. Bold]123-dr. bold retired to spend the evening of [his]123-dr. bold life , and to die ; and here [[his]123-dr. bold son]521-his son [John]121-bold spent [his]121-bold holidays , and afterwards [his]121-bold Christmas vacation , when [he]121-bold went from [school]522-school to study surgery in [the London hospitals]523-the london hospitals . Just as [John Bold]121-bold was entitled to write [himself]121-bold [surgeon and apothecary]524-surgeon and apothecary , [old Dr. Bold]123-dr. bold died , leaving [[his]123-dr. bold [Barchester]6-barchester property]525-his barchester property to [[his]123-dr. bold son]521-his son , and a certain sum in the three per cents to [[his]123-dr. bold daughter [Mary]124-johnny bell , who is some four or five years older than [[her]124-johnny bell brother]528-her brother]527-his daughter mary , who is some four or five years older than her brother . [John Bold]121-bold determined to settle [himself]121-bold at [Barchester]6-barchester , and look after [[his]121-bold own property]529-his own property , as well as the bones and bodies of [such of [[his]121-bold neighbours]531-his neighbours as would call upon [him]121-bold for assistance in [their]531-his neighbours troubles]530-such of his neighbours as would call upon him for assistance in their troubles . [He]121-bold therefore put up a large brass plate , with " [John Bold]121-bold , [Surgeon]2724-surgeon , "[121-bold] on it , to the great disgust of [the nine practitioners who were already trying to get a living out of [the bishop , dean]533-the bishop , dean , and [canons]262-canons]532-the nine practitioners who were already trying to get a living out of the bishop , dean , and canons ; and began [house]535-house - keeping with the aid of [[his]121-bold sister]536-his sister . At this time [he]121-bold was not more than twenty - four years old ; and though [he]121-bold has now been three years in [Barchester]6-barchester , [we]537-we have not heard that [he]121-bold has done much harm to [the nine worthy practitioners]538-the nine worthy practitioners . Indeed , [their]538-the nine worthy practitioners dread of [him]121-bold has died away ; for in three years [he]121-bold has not taken three fees . Nevertheless , [John Bold]121-bold is [a clever man]539-a clever man , and would , with practice , be [a clever surgeon]540-a clever surgeon ; but [he]121-bold has got quite into another line of life . Having enough to live on , [he]121-bold has not been forced to work for bread ; [he]121-bold has declined to subject [himself]121-bold to what [he]121-bold calls the drudgery of the profession , by which , [I]0-i believe , [he]121-bold means the general work of [a practising surgeon]541-a practising surgeon ; and has found other employment . [He]121-bold frequently binds up the bruises and sets the limbs of such of [the poorer classes]542-the poorer classes as profess [his]121-bold way of thinking — but this [he]121-bold does for love . Now [I]0-i will not say that [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon is strictly correct in stigmatising [John Bold]121-bold as [a demagogue]544-a demagogue ; for [I]0-i hardly know how extreme must be [a man]545-a man 's opinions before [he]545-a man can be justly so called ; but [Bold]121-bold is [a strong reformer]546-a strong reformer . [His]121-bold passion is the reform of all abuses ; state abuses , church abuses , corporation abuses ( [he]121-bold has got [himself]121-bold elected [a town councillor of [Barchester]6-barchester]547-a town councillor of barchester , and has so worried [three consecutive mayors]548-three consecutive mayors , that it became somewhat difficult to find a fourth ) , abuses in medical practice , and general abuses in [the world]325-the world at large . [Bold]121-bold is thoroughly sincere in [his]121-bold patriotic endeavours to mend mankind , and there is something to be admired in the energy with which [he]121-bold devotes [himself]121-bold to remedying evil and stopping injustice ; but [I]0-i fear that [he]121-bold is too much imbued with the idea that [he]121-bold has a special mission for reforming . It would be well if [one so young]550-one so young had a little more diffidence [himself]550-one so young , and more trust in the honest purposes of [others]551-others — if [he]121-bold could be brought to believe that old customs need not necessarily be evil , and that changes may possibly be dangerous ; but no , [Bold]121-bold has all the ardour , and all the self - assurance of [a Danton]552-a danton , and hurls [his]121-bold anathemas against time - honoured practices with the violence of [a French Jacobin]553-a french jacobin . No wonder that [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly should regard [Bold]121-bold as [a firebrand]554-a firebrand , falling , as [he]121-bold has done , almost in the centre of [the quiet ancient close of [Barchester Cathedral]8-barchester cathedral]555-the quiet ancient close of barchester cathedral . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly would have [him]121-bold avoided as the plague ; but [the old Doctor]556-the old doctor and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding were [fast friends]557-fast friends . [Young Johnny Bold]125-young johnny bold used to play as [a boy]558-a boy on [[Mr Harding]102-mr. harding 's lawn]559-mr harding 's lawn ; [he]121-bold has many a time won [the precentor]441-the precentor 's heart by listening with wrapt attention to [his]121-bold sacred strains ; and since those days , to tell the truth at once , [he]121-bold has nearly won another heart within the same walls . [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor has not plighted [her]104-eleanor troth to [John Bold]121-bold , nor has [she]104-eleanor , perhaps , owned to [herself]104-eleanor how dear to [her]104-eleanor [the young reformer]561-the young reformer is ; but [she]104-eleanor can not endure that [any one]431-any one should speak harshly of [him]121-bold . [She]104-eleanor does not dare to defend [him]121-bold when [[her]104-eleanor brother - in - law]563-her brother - in - law is so loud against [him]121-bold ; for [she]104-eleanor , like [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father , is somewhat afraid of [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly ; but [she]104-eleanor is beginning greatly to dislike [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . [She]104-eleanor persuades [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father that it would be both unjust and injudicious to banish [[his]293-her father young friend]567-his young friend because of [his]121-bold politics ; [she]104-eleanor cares little to go to houses where [she]104-eleanor will not meet [him]121-bold , and , in fact , [she]104-eleanor is in love . Nor is there any good reason why [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor should not love [John Bold]121-bold . [He]121-bold has all those qualities which are likely to touch [a girl]568-a girl 's heart . [He]121-bold is brave , eager , and amusing ; well - made and good - looking ; young and enterprising ; [his]121-bold character is in all respects good ; [he]121-bold has sufficient income to support [a wife]569-a wife ; [he]121-bold is [[[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father 's friend]571-her father 's friend ; and , above all , [he]121-bold is in love with [her]104-eleanor : then why should not [Eleanor Harding]102-mr. harding be attached to [John Bold]121-bold ? [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , who has as many eyes as [Argus]126-argus , and has long seen how the wind blows in that direction , thinks there are various strong reasons why this should not be so . [He]106-dr. grantly has not thought it wise as yet to speak to [[his]106-dr. grantly father - in - law]435-his father - in - law on the subject , for [he]106-dr. grantly knows how foolishly indulgent is [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding in everything that concerns [[his]106-dr. grantly daughter]280-his daughter ; but [he]106-dr. grantly has discussed the matter with [[his]106-dr. grantly all - trusted helpmate]574-his all - trusted helpmate , within that sacred recess formed by [the clerical bedcurtains at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi]575-the clerical bedcurtains at plumstead episcopi . How much sweet solace , how much valued counsel has [[our]576-our archdeacon]577-our archdeacon received within [that sainted enclosure]578-that sainted enclosure ! ' Tis there alone that [he]577-our archdeacon unbends , and comes down from [[his]577-our archdeacon high church pedestal]579-his high church pedestal to the level of [a mortal man]580-a mortal man . In [the world]325-the world [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly never lays aside that demeanour which so well becomes [him]106-dr. grantly . [He]106-dr. grantly has all the dignity of [an ancient saint]582-an ancient saint with the sleekness of [a modern bishop]583-a modern bishop ; [he]106-dr. grantly is always the same ; [he]106-dr. grantly is always [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon ; unlike [Homer]127-homer , [he]106-dr. grantly never nods . Even with [[his]106-dr. grantly father - in - law]435-his father - in - law , even with [the bishop]260-the bishop and [dean]261-dean , [he]106-dr. grantly maintains that sonorous tone and lofty deportment which strikes awe into [the young hearts of [Barchester]6-barchester]588-the young hearts of barchester , and absolutely cows [the whole parish of [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi]589-the whole parish of plumstead episcopi . ' Tis only when [he]106-dr. grantly has exchanged that ever - new shovel hat for a tasselled nightcap , and those shining black habiliments for [his]106-dr. grantly accustomed robe de nuit , that [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly talks , and looks , and thinks like [an ordinary man]590-an ordinary man . [Many of [us]592-our]591-many of us have often thought how severe a trial of faith must this be to [the wives of [[our]592-our great church dignitaries]594-our great church dignitaries]593-the wives of our great church dignitaries . To [us]592-our [these men]595-these men are [personifications of [St. Paul]83-st. paul 's]596-personifications of st. paul : [their]595-these men very gait is a speaking sermon ; [their]595-these men clean and sombre apparel exacts from [us]592-our faith and submission , and the cardinal virtues seem to hover round [their]595-these men sacred hats . [A dean]597-a dean or [archbishop]598-archbishop , in the garb of [his]106-dr. grantly order , is sure of [our]592-our reverence , and [a well got - up bishop]599-a well got - up bishop fills [our]592-our very souls with awe . But how can this feeling be perpetuated in the bosoms of [those who see [the bishops]601-the bishops without [their]601-the bishops aprons]600-those who see the bishops without their aprons , and [the archdeacons even in a lower state of dishabille]602-the archdeacons even in a lower state of dishabille ? Do [we]592-our not all know [some reverend , all but sacred , personage]603-some reverend , all but sacred , personage , before whom [our]592-our tongue ceases to be loud , and [our]592-our step to be elastic ? But were [we]592-our once to see [him]106-dr. grantly stretch [himself]106-dr. grantly beneath the bed - clothes , yawn widely , and bury [his]106-dr. grantly face upon [his]106-dr. grantly pillow , [we]592-our could chatter before [him]106-dr. grantly as glibly as before [a doctor]604-a doctor or [a lawyer]605-a lawyer . From some such cause , doubtless , it arose that [[our]592-our archdeacon]577-our archdeacon listened to the counsels of [[his]577-our archdeacon wife]607-his wife , though [he]577-our archdeacon considered [himself]577-our archdeacon entitled to give counsel to [every other being whom [he]577-our archdeacon met]608-every other being whom he met . " [[My]577-our archdeacon dear]2725-my dear , "[577-our archdeacon] [he]577-our archdeacon said , as [he]577-our archdeacon adjusted the copious folds of [his]577-our archdeacon nightcap , " there was that [John Bold]121-bold at [[your]2725-my dear father]2726-your father 's again to - day . [I]577-our archdeacon must say [[your]2725-my dear father]2726-your father is very imprudent . "[577-our archdeacon] " [He]2726-your father is imprudent — [he]2726-your father always was , "[129-mrs. grantly] replied [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly , speaking from under the comfortable bedclothes . " There 's nothing new in that . "[129-mrs. grantly] " No , [[my]129-mrs. grantly dear]2725-my dear , there 's nothing new — [I]129-mrs. grantly know that ; but , at the present juncture of affairs , such imprudence is — is — [I'll]129-mrs. grantly tell [you]2725-my dear what , [[my]129-mrs. grantly dear]2725-my dear , if [he]121-bold does not take care what [he]121-bold 's about , [John Bold]121-bold will be off with [Eleanor]104-eleanor . "[129-mrs. grantly] " [I]129-mrs. grantly think [he]121-bold will , whether [papa]2730-papa takes care or no ; and why not ? "[129-mrs. grantly] " Why not ! "[382-the archdeacon] almost screamed [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , giving so rough a pull at [his]382-the archdeacon nightcap as almost to bring it over [his]382-the archdeacon nose ; " why not!—that pestilent , [interfering upstart]2731-interfering upstart , [John Bold]121-bold — [the most vulgar young person [I]382-the archdeacon ever met]2732-the most vulgar young person i ever met ! Do [you]2725-my dear know that [he]121-bold is meddling with [[your]2725-my dear father]2726-your father 's affairs in a most uncalled for — most — "[382-the archdeacon] And being at a loss for an epithet sufficiently injurious , [he]382-the archdeacon finished [his]382-the archdeacon expressions of horror by muttering , " Good heavens ! "[382-the archdeacon] in a manner that had been found very efficacious in clerical meetings of [the diocese]610-the diocese . [He]382-the archdeacon must for the moment have forgotten where [he]382-the archdeacon was . " As to [his]121-bold vulgarity , [archdeacon]2734-archdeacon , "[382-the archdeacon] ( [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly had never assumed a more familiar term than this in addressing [[her]129-mrs. grantly husband]611-her husband ) , " [I]612-the lady do n't agree with [you]2734-archdeacon . Not that [I]612-the lady like [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold — [he]122-mr. bold is a great deal too conceited for [me]612-the lady ; but then [Eleanor]104-eleanor does , and it would be the best thing in [the world]325-the world for [papa]2730-papa if [they]2737-they were to marry . [Bold]122-mr. bold would never trouble [himself]122-mr. bold about [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's Hospital]21-hiram 's hospital if [he]122-mr. bold were [[papa]2730-papa 's son - in - law]2739-papa 's son - in - law . "[612-the lady] And [the lady]612-the lady turned [herself]612-the lady round under the bed - clothes , in a manner to which [the doctor]613-the doctor was well accustomed , and which told [him]613-the doctor , as plainly as words , that as far as [she]612-the lady was concerned the subject was over for that night . " Good heavens ! "[613-the doctor] murmured [the doctor]613-the doctor again — [he]613-the doctor was evidently much put beside [himself]613-the doctor . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly is by no means [a bad man]615-a bad man ; [he]106-dr. grantly is exactly the man which such an education as [his]106-dr. grantly was most likely to form ; [his]106-dr. grantly intellect being sufficient for such a place in [the world]325-the world , but not sufficient to put [him]106-dr. grantly in advance of it . [He]106-dr. grantly performs with a rigid constancy such of the duties of [a parish clergyman]617-a parish clergyman as are , to [his]106-dr. grantly thinking , above the sphere of [[his]106-dr. grantly curate]618-his curate , but it is as [an archdeacon]619-an archdeacon that [he]106-dr. grantly shines . [We]620-we believe , as a general rule , that either [a bishop]621-a bishop or [[his]621-a bishop archdeacons]622-his archdeacons have sinecures : where [a bishop]621-a bishop works , [archdeacons]624-archdeacons have but little to do , and vice versâ . In [the diocese of [Barchester]6-barchester [the Archdeacon of]626-the archdeacon of [Barchester]6-barchester]625-the diocese of barchester the archdeacon of barchester does the work . In that capacity [he]626-the archdeacon of is diligent , authoritative , and , as [[his]626-the archdeacon of friends]627-his friends particularly boast , judicious . [His]626-the archdeacon of great fault is an overbearing assurance of the virtues and claims of [his]626-the archdeacon of order , and [his]626-the archdeacon of great foible is an equally strong confidence in the dignity of [his]626-the archdeacon of own manner and the eloquence of [his]626-the archdeacon of own words . [He]626-the archdeacon of is [a moral man]628-a moral man , believing the precepts which [he]626-the archdeacon of teaches , and believing also that [he]626-the archdeacon of acts up to [them]629-them ; though [we]630-we can not say that [he]626-the archdeacon of would give [his]626-the archdeacon of coat to [the man who took [his]626-the archdeacon of cloak , or that [he]626-the archdeacon of is prepared to forgive [[his]626-the archdeacon of brother]632-his brother even seven times]631-the man who took his cloak , or that he is prepared to forgive his brother even seven times . [He]626-the archdeacon of is severe enough in exacting [his]626-the archdeacon of dues , considering that any laxity in this respect would endanger the security of [the church]454-the church ; and , could [he]626-the archdeacon of have [his]626-the archdeacon of way , [he]626-the archdeacon of would consign to darkness and perdition , not only [every individual reformer]634-every individual reformer , but every committee and every commission that would even dare to ask a question respecting the appropriation of church revenues . " They are church revenues : [the laity]2740-the laity admit it . Surely [the church]454-the church is able to administer [her]454-the church own revenues . "[626-the archdeacon of] ' T was thus [he]626-the archdeacon of was accustomed to argue , when the sacrilegious doings of [Lord John Russell]130-lord john russell and [others]551-others were discussed either at [Barchester]6-barchester or at [Oxford]17-oxford . It was no wonder that [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly did not like [John Bold]121-bold , and that [[his]106-dr. grantly wife]607-his wife 's suggestion , that [he]626-the archdeacon of should become closely connected with [such a man]637-such a man dismayed [him]626-the archdeacon of . To give [him]626-the archdeacon of [his]626-the archdeacon of due , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon never wanted courage ; [he]626-the archdeacon of was quite willing to meet [[his]626-the archdeacon of enemy]639-his enemy on any field , and with any weapon . [He]626-the archdeacon of had that belief in [his]626-the archdeacon of own arguments that [he]626-the archdeacon of felt sure of success , could [he]626-the archdeacon of only be sure of a fair fight on the part of [[his]626-the archdeacon of adversary]640-his adversary . [He]626-the archdeacon of had no idea that [John Bold]121-bold could really prove that the income of [the hospital]364-the hospital was malappropriated ; why , then , should peace be sought for on such base terms ? What ! bribe [an unbelieving enemy of the church]642-an unbelieving enemy of the church with [the sister - in - law of [one dignitary]644-one dignitary]643-the sister - in - law of one dignitary , and [the daughter of another]645-the daughter of another — with [a young lady whose connections with [the diocese]610-the diocese and chapter of [Barchester]6-barchester]646-a young lady whose connections with the diocese and chapter of barchester were so close as to give [her]646-a young lady whose connections with the diocese and chapter of barchester an undeniable claim to [a husband endowed with some of [its]364-the hospital sacred wealth]648-a husband endowed with some of its sacred wealth ! When [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly talks of [unbelieving enemies]649-unbelieving enemies , [he]106-dr. grantly does not mean to imply want of belief in the doctrines of the church , but an equally dangerous scepticism as to its purity in money matters . [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly is not usually deaf to the claims of the high order to which [she]129-mrs. grantly belongs . [She]129-mrs. grantly and [[her]129-mrs. grantly husband]611-her husband rarely disagree as to the tone with which the church should be defended ; how singular , then , that in such a case as this [she]129-mrs. grantly should be willing to succumb ! [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon again murmurs " Good heavens ! "[106-dr. grantly] as [he]106-dr. grantly lays [himself]106-dr. grantly beside [her]129-mrs. grantly , but [he]106-dr. grantly does so in a voice audible only to [himself]106-dr. grantly , and [he]106-dr. grantly repeats it till sleep relieves [him]106-dr. grantly from deep thought . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding [himself]102-mr. harding has seen no reason why [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter should not love [John Bold]121-bold . [He]102-mr. harding has not been unobservant of [her]129-mrs. grantly feelings , and perhaps [his]102-mr. harding deepest regret at the part which [he]102-mr. harding fears [Bold]121-bold is about to take regarding [the hospital]364-the hospital , arises from a dread that [he]102-mr. harding may be separated from [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter , or that [she]129-mrs. grantly may be separated from [the man [she]129-mrs. grantly loves]655-the man she loves . [He]102-mr. harding has never spoken to [Eleanor]104-eleanor about [[her]104-eleanor lover]656-her lover ; [he]102-mr. harding is [the last man in [the world]325-the world to allude to such a subject unconsulted , even with [[his]102-mr. harding own daughter]659-his own daughter]657-the last man in the world to allude to such a subject unconsulted , even with his own daughter ; and had [he]102-mr. harding considered that [he]102-mr. harding had ground to disapprove of [Bold]121-bold , [he]102-mr. harding would have removed [her]129-mrs. grantly , or forbidden [him]102-mr. harding [[his]102-mr. harding house]660-his house ; but [he]102-mr. harding saw no such ground . [He]102-mr. harding would probably have preferred [a second clerical son - in - law]661-a second clerical son - in - law , for [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , also , is attached to [his]102-mr. harding order ; and , failing in that , [he]102-mr. harding would at any rate have wished that so near a connection should have thought alike with [him]102-mr. harding on church matters . [He]102-mr. harding would not , however , reject [the man [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter loved because [he]102-mr. harding differed on such subjects with [himself]102-mr. harding]662-the man his daughter loved because he differed on such subjects with himself . Hitherto [Bold]121-bold had taken no steps in the matter in any way annoying to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding personally . Some months since , after a severe battle , which cost [him]121-bold not a little , [he]121-bold gained a victory over [a certain old turnpike woman in [the neighbourhood]665-the neighbourhood , of whose charges [another old woman]666-another old woman had complained to [him]121-bold]664-a certain old turnpike woman in the neighbourhood , of whose charges another old woman had complained to him . [He]121-bold got the act of Parliament relating to the trust , found that [[his]121-bold protégée]667-his protégée had been wrongly taxed , rode through the gate [himself]121-bold , paying the toll , then brought an action against [the gate - keeper]668-the gate - keeper , and proved that all people coming up [a certain by - lane]669-a certain by - lane , and going down [a certain other by - lane]670-a certain other by - lane , were toll free . The fame of [his]121-bold success spread widely abroad , and [he]121-bold began to be looked on as [the upholder of the rights of [the poor of [Barchester]6-barchester]672-the poor of barchester]671-the upholder of the rights of the poor of barchester . Not long after this success , [he]121-bold heard from different quarters that [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's bedesmen]406-hiram 's bedesmen were treated as [paupers]674-paupers , whereas [the property to which [they]406-hiram 's bedesmen were , in effect , [heirs]676-heirs]675-the property to which they were , in effect , heirs , was very large ; and [he]121-bold was instigated by [the lawyer whom [he]121-bold had employed in the case of [the turnpike]678-the turnpike]677-the lawyer whom he had employed in the case of the turnpike , to call upon [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick for a statement as to the funds of [the estate]679-the estate . [Bold]121-bold had often expressed [his]121-bold indignation at the malappropriation of church funds in general , in the hearing of [[his]121-bold friend]285-his friend [the precentor]441-the precentor ; but the conversation had never referred to anything at [Barchester]6-barchester ; and when [Finney]131-finney , [the attorney]682-the attorney , induced [him]121-bold to interfere with the affairs of [the hospital]364-the hospital , it was against [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick that [his]121-bold efforts were to be directed . [Bold]121-bold soon found that if [he]121-bold interfered with [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick as [steward]684-steward , [he]121-bold must also interfere with [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding as [warden]304-warden ; and though [he]121-bold regretted the situation in which this would place [him]121-bold , [he]121-bold was not the man to flinch from [his]121-bold undertaking from personal motives . As soon as [he]121-bold had determined to take the matter in hand , [he]121-bold set about [his]121-bold work with [his]121-bold usual energy . [He]121-bold got a copy of [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's will , of the wording of which [he]121-bold made [himself]121-bold perfectly master . [He]121-bold ascertained the extent of [the property]328-the property , and as nearly as [he]121-bold could the value of it ; and made out a schedule of what [he]121-bold was informed was the present distribution of its income . Armed with these particulars , [he]121-bold called on [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , having given [that gentleman]687-that gentleman notice of [his]121-bold visit ; and asked [him]109-mr. chadwick for a statement of the income and expenditure of [the hospital]364-the hospital for the last twenty - five years . This was of course refused , [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick alleging that [he]109-mr. chadwick had no authority for making public the concerns of a property in managing which [he]109-mr. chadwick was only [a paid servant]689-a paid servant . " And who is competent to give [you]109-mr. chadwick that authority , [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick ? "[121-bold] asked [Bold]121-bold . " Only those who employ [me]350-the steward , [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold , "[350-the steward] said [the steward]350-the steward . " And who are those , [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick ? "[121-bold] demanded [Bold]121-bold . [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick begged to say that if these inquiries were made merely out of curiosity , [he]109-mr. chadwick must decline answering them : if [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold had any ulterior proceeding in view , perhaps it would be desirable that any necessary information should be sought for in a professional way by [a professional man]691-a professional man . [[Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick 's attorneys]692-mr. chadwick 's attorneys were [Messrs. Cox]132-cox and [Cummins]133-cummins , of [Lincoln 's Inn]22-lincoln 's inn . [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold took down the address of [Cox]132-cox and [Cummins]133-cummins , remarked that the weather was cold for the time of the year , and wished [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick good morning . [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick said it was cold for [June]134-june , and bowed [him]109-mr. chadwick out . [He]109-mr. chadwick at once went to [[his]109-mr. chadwick lawyer]693-his lawyer , [Finney]131-finney . Now , [Bold]122-mr. bold was not very fond of [[his]122-mr. bold attorney]694-his attorney , but , as [he]122-mr. bold said , [he]122-mr. bold merely wanted [a man who knew the forms of law]695-a man who knew the forms of law , and who would do what [he]122-mr. bold was told for [his]122-mr. bold money . [He]122-mr. bold had no idea of putting [himself]122-mr. bold in the hands of [a lawyer]605-a lawyer . [He]122-mr. bold wanted law from [a lawyer]605-a lawyer as [he]122-mr. bold did a coat from [a tailor]698-a tailor , because [he]122-mr. bold could not make it so well [himself]122-mr. bold ; and [he]122-mr. bold thought [[Finney]131-finney the fittest man in [Barchester]6-barchester for [his]122-mr. bold purpose]699-finney the fittest man in barchester for his purpose . "[133-cummins] " Suppose [I]122-mr. bold were to see [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding first , "[122-mr. bold] suggested [Bold]122-mr. bold . [Bold]122-mr. bold at once repaired to [the hospital]364-the hospital . The day was now far advanced , but [he]131-finney knew that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding dined in the summer at four , that [Eleanor]104-eleanor was accustomed to drive in the evening , and that [he]131-finney might therefore probably find [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding alone . It was between seven and eight when [he]131-finney reached the slight iron gate leading into [the precentor 's garden]703-the precentor 's garden , and though , as [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick observed , the day had been cold for June , the evening was mild , and soft , and sweet . The little gate was open . As [he]131-finney raised the latch [he]131-finney heard the notes of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's violoncello from the far end of [the garden]704-the garden , and , advancing before [the house]374-the house and across [the lawn]706-the lawn , [he]131-finney found [him]102-mr. harding playing : and not without [an audience]707-an audience . [The musician]708-the musician was seated in a garden - chair just within [the summer - house]709-the summer - house , so as to allow the violoncello which [he]708-the musician held between [his]708-the musician knees to rest upon the dry stone flooring ; before [him]708-the musician stood a rough music desk , on which was open a page of that dear sacred book , that much - laboured and much - loved volume of church music , which had cost so many guineas ; and around sat , and lay , and stood , and leaned , [ten of [the twelve old men who dwelt with [him]708-the musician beneath [old John Hiram]107-john hiram 's roof]711-the twelve old men who dwelt with him beneath old john hiram 's roof]710-ten of the twelve old men who dwelt with him beneath old john hiram 's roof . [The two reformers]712-the two reformers were not [there]713-there . [I]0-i will not say that in [their]712-the two reformers hearts [they]712-the two reformers were conscious of any wrong done or to be done to [[their]712-the two reformers mild warden]714-their mild warden , but latterly [they]712-the two reformers had kept aloof from [him]708-the musician , and [his]708-the musician music was no longer to [their]712-the two reformers taste . It was amusing to see the positions , and eager listening faces of [these well - to - do old men]715-these well - to - do old men . [I]0-i will not say that [they]715-these well - to - do old men all appreciated the music which [they]715-these well - to - do old men heard , but [they]715-these well - to - do old men were intent on appearing to do so ; pleased at being where [they]715-these well - to - do old men were , [they]715-these well - to - do old men were determined , as far as in [them]715-these well - to - do old men lay , to give pleasure in return ; and [they]715-these well - to - do old men were not unsuccessful . It gladdened [the precentor]441-the precentor 's heart to think that [the old bedesmen whom [he]708-the musician loved so well]717-the old bedesmen whom he loved so well , admired the strains which were to [him]708-the musician so full of almost ecstatic joy ; and [he]708-the musician used to boast that such was the air of [the hospital]364-the hospital , as to make [it]364-the hospital [a precinct specially fit for the worship of [St. Cecilia]135-st. cecilia]719-a precinct specially fit for the worship of st. cecilia . Immediately before [him]708-the musician , on the extreme corner of the bench which ran round [the summer - house]709-the summer - house , sat [one old man]721-one old man , with [his]721-one old man handkerchief smoothly lain upon [his]721-one old man knees , who did enjoy the moment , or acted enjoyment well . [He]721-one old man was [one on whose large frame many years]722-one on whose large frame many years , for [he]721-one old man was over eighty , had made small havoc,—he was still [an upright , burly , handsome figure , with an open , ponderous brow , round which clung a few , though very few , thin grey locks]723-an upright , burly , handsome figure , with an open , ponderous brow , round which clung a few , though very few , thin grey locks . The coarse black gown of [the hospital]364-the hospital , the breeches , and buckled shoes became [him]721-one old man well ; and as [he]721-one old man sat with [his]721-one old man hands folded on [his]721-one old man staff , and [his]721-one old man chin resting on [his]721-one old man hands , [he]721-one old man was such a listener as [most musicians]725-most musicians would be glad to welcome . [This man]726-this man was certainly [the pride of [the hospital]364-the hospital]727-the pride of the hospital . It had always been the custom that [one]729-one should be selected as being to some extent in authority over the others ; and though [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce , for such was [his]136-bunce name , and so [he]136-bunce was always designated by [[his]136-bunce inferior brethren]730-his inferior brethren , had no greater emoluments than [they]730-his inferior brethren , [he]136-bunce had assumed , and well knew how to maintain , the dignity of [his]136-bunce elevation . [The precentor]441-the precentor delighted to call [him]136-bunce [[his]441-the precentor sub - warden]732-his sub - warden , and was not ashamed , occasionally , when [no other guest]733-no other guest was there , to bid [him]136-bunce sit down by the same parlour fire , and drink the full glass of port which was placed near [him]136-bunce . [Bunce]136-bunce never went without the second glass , but no entreaty ever made [him]136-bunce take a third . " Well , well , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ; [you]102-mr. harding 're too good , much too good , "[136-bunce] [he]136-bunce 'd always say , as the second glass was filled ; but when that was drunk , and the halfhour over , [Bunce]136-bunce stood erect , and with a benediction which [[his]136-bunce patron]734-his patron valued , retired to [[his]136-bunce own abode]735-his own abode . [He]136-bunce knew [the world]325-the world too well to risk the comfort of such halcyon moments , by prolonging them till they were disagreeable . [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce , as may be imagined , was most strongly opposed to innovation . Not even [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly had a more holy horror of [those who would interfere in the affairs of [the hospital]364-the hospital]737-those who would interfere in the affairs of the hospital ; [he]106-dr. grantly was every inch [a churchman]739-a churchman , and though [he]106-dr. grantly was not very fond of [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly personally , that arose from there not being room in [the hospital]364-the hospital for [two people]741-two people so much alike as [the doctor]613-the doctor and [himself]106-dr. grantly , rather than from any dissimilarity in feeling . [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce was inclined to think that [the warden]318-the warden and [himself]136-bunce could manage [the hospital]364-the hospital without further assistance ; and that , though [the bishop]260-the bishop was [the constitutional visitor]746-the constitutional visitor , and as such entitled to special reverence from all connected with [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's will , [John Hiram]107-john hiram never intended that [his]107-john hiram affairs should be interfered with by [an archdeacon]619-an archdeacon . At the present moment , however , these cares were off [his]106-dr. grantly mind , and [he]106-dr. grantly was looking at [[his]106-dr. grantly warden]748-his warden , as though [he]106-dr. grantly thought the music heavenly , and [the musician]708-the musician hardly less so . As [Bold]122-mr. bold walked silently over [the lawn]706-the lawn , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding did not at first perceive [him]122-mr. bold , and continued to draw [his]102-mr. harding bow slowly across the plaintive wires ; but [he]102-mr. harding soon found from [[his]102-mr. harding audience]751-his audience that [some stranger]752-some stranger was there , and looking up , began to welcome [[his]102-mr. harding young friend]567-his young friend with frank hospitality . " Pray , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ; pray do n't let [me]122-mr. bold disturb [you]102-mr. harding , "[122-mr. bold] said [Bold]122-mr. bold ; " [you]102-mr. harding know how fond [I]122-mr. bold am of sacred music . "[122-mr. bold] " Oh ! it 's nothing , "[441-the precentor] said [the precentor]441-the precentor , shutting up the book , and then opening it again as [he]441-the precentor saw the delightfully imploring look of [[his]441-the precentor old friend]755-his old friend [Bunce]136-bunce . Oh , [Bunce]136-bunce , [Bunce]136-bunce , [Bunce]136-bunce , [I]0-i fear that after all [thou]756-thou art but [a flatterer]757-a flatterer . " Well , [I]0-i 'll just finish it then ; it 's a favourite little bit of [Bishop]137-bishop 's ; and then , [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold , [we]2745-we 'll have a stroll and a chat till [Eleanor]104-eleanor comes in and gives [us]2745-we tea . "[0-i] And so [Bold]122-mr. bold sat down on [the soft turf]758-the soft turf to listen , or rather to think how , after such sweet harmony , [he]122-mr. bold might best introduce a theme of so much discord , to disturb the peace of [him]122-mr. bold who was so ready to welcome [him]122-mr. bold kindly . [Bold]122-mr. bold thought that the performance was soon over , for [he]122-mr. bold felt that [he]122-mr. bold had a somewhat difficult task , and [he]122-mr. bold almost regretted the final leave - taking of [the last of [the old men]314-the old men]759-the last of the old men , slow as [they]759-the last of the old men were in going through [their]759-the last of the old men adieus . [Bold]122-mr. bold 's heart was in [his]122-mr. bold mouth , as [the precentor]441-the precentor made some ordinary but kind remark as to the friendliness of the visit . " One evening call , "[122-mr. bold] said [he]122-mr. bold , " is worth ten in the morning . It 's all formality in the morning ; real social talk never begins till after dinner . That 's why [I]122-mr. bold dine early , so as to get as much as [I]122-mr. bold can of it . "[122-mr. bold] " Quite true , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , "[762-the other] said [the other]762-the other ; " but [I]762-the other fear [I]762-the other 've reversed the order of things , and [I]762-the other owe [you]102-mr. harding much apology for troubling [you]102-mr. harding on business at such an hour ; but it is on business that [I]762-the other have called just now . "[762-the other] [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding looked blank and annoyed ; there was something in the tone of [the young man]763-the young man 's voice , which told [him]102-mr. harding that the interview was intended to be disagreeable , and [he]102-mr. harding shrank back at finding [his]763-the young man kindly greeting so repulsed . " [I]122-mr. bold wish to speak to [you]102-mr. harding about [the hospital]364-the hospital , "[122-mr. bold] continued [Bold]122-mr. bold . "[121-bold] " Only one word more , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . "[763-the young man] " [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold , "[762-the other] said [the other]762-the other , stopping , and speaking with some solemnity , " if [you]122-mr. bold act justly , say nothing in this matter but the truth , and use no unfair weapons in carrying out [your]122-mr. bold purposes , [I]762-the other shall have nothing to forgive . [I]762-the other presume [you]102-mr. harding think [I]762-the other am not entitled to the income [I]762-the other receive from [the hospital]364-the hospital , and that [others]551-others are entitled to it .
