Here comes [Eleanor]104-eleanor and the ponies , and [we]2758-us 'll go in to tea . "[762-the other] [Bold]122-mr. bold , however , felt that [he]122-mr. bold could not sit down at ease with [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding and [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter after what had passed , and therefore excused [himself]122-mr. bold with much awkward apology ; and merely raising [his]122-mr. bold hat and bowing as [he]122-mr. bold passed [Eleanor]104-eleanor and the poney chair , left [her]104-eleanor in disappointed amazement at [his]122-mr. bold departure . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's demeanour certainly impressed [Bold]122-mr. bold with a full conviction , that [the warden]318-the warden felt that [he]122-mr. bold stood on strong grounds , and almost made [him]122-mr. bold think that [he]122-mr. bold was about to interfere without due warrant in the private affairs of [a just and honourable man]769-a just and honourable man ; but [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding [himself]102-mr. harding was anything but satisfied with [his]102-mr. harding own view of the case . In the first place , [he]102-mr. harding wished for [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's sake to think well of [Bold]122-mr. bold and to like [him]122-mr. bold , and yet [he]102-mr. harding could not but feel disgusted at the arrogance of [his]122-mr. bold conduct . What right had [he]122-mr. bold to say that [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's will was not fairly carried out ? But then the question would arise within [his]122-mr. bold heart , Was that will fairly acted on ? Did [John Hiram]107-john hiram mean that [the warden of [[his]107-john hiram hospital]771-his hospital]770-the warden of his hospital should receive considerably more out of the legacy than [all the twelve old men together for whose behoof [the hospital]364-the hospital was built]772-all the twelve old men together for whose behoof the hospital was built ? Could it be possible that [John Bold]121-bold was right , and that [the reverend warden of [the hospital]364-the hospital]774-the reverend warden of the hospital had been for the last ten years and more [the unjust recipient of an income legally and equitably belonging to [others]551-others]776-the unjust recipient of an income legally and equitably belonging to others ? What if it should be proved before the light of day that [he]774-the reverend warden of the hospital , whose life had [been so happy , so quiet , so respected]778-been so happy , so quiet , so respected , had absorbed 8000 l . , to which [he]774-the reverend warden of the hospital had no title , and which [he]774-the reverend warden of the hospital could never repay ? [I]0-i do not say that [he]774-the reverend warden of the hospital feared that such was really the case ; but the first shade of doubt now fell across [his]774-the reverend warden of the hospital mind , and from this evening , for many a long , long day , [[our]779-our [good , kind , loving warden]781-good , kind , loving warden]780-our good , kind , loving warden was neither happy nor at ease . Thoughts of this kind , these first moments of much misery , oppressed [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding as [he]102-mr. harding sat sipping [his]102-mr. harding tea , absent and ill at ease . [Poor Eleanor]104-eleanor felt that all was not right , but [her]104-eleanor ideas as to the cause of the evening 's discomfort did not go beyond [[her]104-eleanor lover]656-her lover , and [his]774-the reverend warden of the hospital sudden and uncivil departure : [she]104-eleanor thought there must have been some quarrel between [Bold]121-bold and [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father , and [she]104-eleanor was half angry with both , though [she]104-eleanor did not attempt to explain to [herself]104-eleanor why [she]104-eleanor was so . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding thought long and deeply over these things , both before [he]102-mr. harding went to bed , and after it , as [he]102-mr. harding lay awake , questioning within [himself]102-mr. harding the validity of [his]102-mr. harding claim to the income which [he]102-mr. harding enjoyed . It seemed clear at any rate that , however unfortunate [he]102-mr. harding might be at having been placed in such a position , [no one]283-no one could say that [he]102-mr. harding ought either to have refused the appointment first , or to have rejected the income afterwards . All [the world]325-the world — meaning the ecclesiastical world as confined to [the English church]786-the english church — knew that [the wardenship of [the Barchester Hospital]788-the barchester hospital]787-the wardenship of the barchester hospital was a snug sinecure , but [no one]283-no one had ever been blamed for accepting it . To how much blame , however , would [he]102-mr. harding have been open had [he]102-mr. harding rejected it ! How mad would [he]102-mr. harding have been thought had [he]102-mr. harding declared , when the situation was vacant and offered to [him]102-mr. harding , that [he]102-mr. harding had scruples as to receiving 800 l . a year from [[John Hiram]107-john hiram 's property]375-john hiram 's property , and that [he]102-mr. harding had rather [some stranger]752-some stranger should possess it ! How would [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly have shaken [his]106-dr. grantly wise head , and have consulted with [[his]106-dr. grantly friends]627-his friends in the close as to some decent retreat for the coming insanity of [the poor minor canon]793-the poor minor canon ! If [he]106-dr. grantly was right in accepting [the place]794-the place , it was clear to [him]106-dr. grantly also that [he]106-dr. grantly would be wrong in rejecting any part of the income attached to it . The patronage was a valuable appanage of [the bishopric]795-the bishopric ; and surely it would not be [his]106-dr. grantly duty to lessen the value of that preferment which had been bestowed on [himself]106-dr. grantly ; surely [he]106-dr. grantly was bound to stand by [his]106-dr. grantly order . But somehow these arguments , though they seemed logical , were not satisfactory . Was [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's will fairly carried out ? that was the true question : and if not , was it not [his]106-dr. grantly especial duty to see that this was done,—his especial duty , whatever injury it might do to [his]106-dr. grantly order,—however ill such duty might be received by [[his]106-dr. grantly patron]734-his patron and [[his]106-dr. grantly friends]627-his friends ? At the idea of [[his]106-dr. grantly friends]627-his friends , [his]106-dr. grantly mind turned unhappily to [[his]106-dr. grantly son - in - law]440-his son - in - law : [he]106-dr. grantly knew well how strongly [he]106-dr. grantly would be supported by [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , if [he]106-dr. grantly could bring [himself]106-dr. grantly to put [his]106-dr. grantly case into [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's hands , and to allow [him]106-dr. grantly to fight the battle ; but [he]106-dr. grantly knew also that [he]106-dr. grantly would find no sympathy there for [his]106-dr. grantly doubts , no friendly feeling , no inward comfort . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly would be ready enough to take up [his]106-dr. grantly cudgel against [all comers on behalf of [the church militant]802-the church militant]801-all comers on behalf of the church militant , but [he]106-dr. grantly would do so on the distasteful ground of [the church]454-the church 's infallibility . Such a contest would give no comfort to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's doubts ; [he]106-dr. grantly was not so anxious to prove [himself]106-dr. grantly right , as to be so . [I]0-i have said before that [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly was [the working man of [the diocese]610-the diocese]804-the working man of the diocese , and that [[his]106-dr. grantly father]508-his father [the bishop]260-the bishop was somewhat inclined to an idle life : so it was ; but [the bishop]260-the bishop , though [he]260-the bishop had never been [an active man]809-an active man , was one whose qualities had rendered [him]260-the bishop dear to [all who knew [him]260-the bishop]810-all who knew him . [He]260-the bishop was the very opposite to [[his]260-the bishop son]521-his son ; [he]260-the bishop was [a bland and a kind old man , opposed by every feeling to authoritative demonstrations and episcopal ostentation]812-a bland and a kind old man , opposed by every feeling to authoritative demonstrations and episcopal ostentation . It was perhaps well for [him]260-the bishop , in [his]260-the bishop situation , that [[his]260-the bishop son]521-his son had early in life been able to do that which [he]521-his son could not well do when [he]521-his son was younger , and which [he]521-his son could not have done at all now that [he]521-his son was over seventy . [The bishop]260-the bishop knew how to entertain [the clergy of [his]260-the bishop diocese]815-the clergy of his diocese , to talk easy small talk with [[the rectors]816-the rectors ' wives]817-the rectors ' wives , and put [curates]818-curates at [their]816-the rectors ease ; but it required the strong hand of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon to deal with such as were refractory either in [their]816-the rectors doctrines or [their]816-the rectors lives . [The bishop]260-the bishop and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding loved [each other]497-each other warmly . [They]816-the rectors had grown old together , and had together spent many , many years in clerical Pursuits and clerical conversation . When one of [them]816-the rectors was [a bishop]621-a bishop and [the other only a minor canon]823-the other only a minor canon [they]816-the rectors were even then much together ; but since [[their]816-the rectors children]824-their children had married , and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had become [warden]304-warden and [precentor]279-precentor , [they]816-the rectors were all in all to [each other]497-each other . [I]0-i will not say that [they]816-the rectors managed [the diocese]610-the diocese between [them]816-the rectors , but [they]816-the rectors spent much time in discussing [the man who did]829-the man who did , and in forming little plans to mitigate [his]102-mr. harding wrath against [church delinquents]830-church delinquents , and soften [his]102-mr. harding aspirations for church dominion . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding determined to open [his]102-mr. harding mind , and confess [his]102-mr. harding doubts to [[his]102-mr. harding old friend]755-his old friend ; and to [him]755-his old friend [he]102-mr. harding went on the morning after [John Bold]121-bold 's uncourteous visit . Up to this period no rumour of these cruel proceedings against [the hospital]364-the hospital had reached [the bishop]260-the bishop 's ears . [He]260-the bishop had doubtless heard that [men]453-men existed who questioned [his]260-the bishop right to present to a sinecure of 800 l . a year , as [he]260-the bishop had heard from time to time of some special immorality or disgraceful disturbance in [the usually decent and quiet city of [Barchester]6-barchester]835-the usually decent and quiet city of barchester : but all [he]260-the bishop did , and all [he]260-the bishop was called on to do , on such occasions , was to shake [his]260-the bishop head , and to beg [[his]260-the bishop son]521-his son , [the great dictator]837-the great dictator , to see that no harm happened to [the church]454-the church . It was a long story that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had to tell before [he]102-mr. harding made [the bishop]260-the bishop comprehend [his]260-the bishop own view of the case ; but [we]840-we need not follow [him]260-the bishop through the tale . At first [the bishop]260-the bishop counselled but one step , recommended but one remedy , had but one medicine in [his]260-the bishop whole pharmacopeia strong enough to touch so grave a disorder — [he]260-the bishop prescribed [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . " Refer [him]260-the bishop to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , "[260-the bishop] [he]260-the bishop repeated , as [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding spoke of [Bold]121-bold and [his]102-mr. harding visit . " [No man]2761-no man has got up all that so well as [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon ; "[260-the bishop] but the dose , though large , failed to quiet [the patient]844-the patient ; indeed it almost produced nausea . " [The bishop]260-the bishop thought probably [he]260-the bishop had , thirty - five years ago , when first instituted to [[his]260-the bishop see]2764-his see , but could not state positively : however , [he]260-the bishop very well knew that [he]260-the bishop had the absolute right to present to the wardenship , and that the income of [the warden]318-the warden had been regularly settled . "[845-bishop] But , [bishop]845-bishop , the question is , who has the power to settle it ? " [The bishop]260-the bishop had an indistinct idea that [they]2767-they altered [themselves]2767-they by the lapse of years ; that a kind of ecclesiastical statute of limitation barred the rights of [the twelve bedesmen]2768-the twelve bedesmen to any increase of income arising from the increased value of property . [He]260-the bishop said something about tradition ; [more of [the many learned men who by [their]2770-the many learned men who by their practice had confirmed the present arrangement practice had confirmed the present arrangement]2770-the many learned men who by their practice had confirmed the present arrangement ; then went at some length into the propriety of maintaining the due difference in rank and income between [a beneficed clergyman]2771-a beneficed clergyman , and [certain poor old men who were dependent on charity]2772-certain poor old men who were dependent on charity]2769-more of the many learned men who by their practice had confirmed the present arrangement ; then went at some length into the propriety of maintaining the due difference in rank and income between a beneficed clergyman , and certain poor old men who were dependent on charity ; and concluded [his]260-the bishop argument by another reference to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . [The precentor]441-the precentor sat thoughtfully gazing at the fire , and listening to the good - natured reasoning of [[his]441-the precentor friend]285-his friend . What [the bishop]260-the bishop said had a sort of comfort in it , but it was not a sustaining comfort . It made [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding feel that many others — indeed , [all others of [his]0-i own order]2777-all others of his own order — would think [him]0-i right ; but it failed to prove to [him]0-i that [he]0-i truly was so . "[137-bishop] [Bishop]137-bishop , " said [he]0-i , at last , after [both]2778-both had sat silent for a while , "[137-bishop] [I]0-i should deceive [you]137-bishop and [myself]0-i too , if [I]0-i did not tell [you]137-bishop that [I]0-i am very unhappy about this . Suppose that [I]0-i can not bring [myself]0-i to agree with [Dr. Grantly!—that]140-dr. grantly!—that [I]0-i find , after inquiry , that [the young man]763-the young man is right , and that [I]0-i am wrong — what then ? " [The two men]2779-the two men were sitting near [each other]497-each other — so near , that [the bishop]260-the bishop was able to lay [his]260-the bishop hand upon [the other]762-the other 's knee , and [he]260-the bishop did so with a gentle pressure . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding well knew what that pressure meant . [The bishop]260-the bishop had no further argument to adduce ; [he]260-the bishop could not fight for the cause as [[his]260-the bishop son]521-his son would do ; [he]260-the bishop could not prove all [the precentor]441-the precentor 's doubts to be groundless ; but [he]260-the bishop could sympathise with [[his]260-the bishop friend]285-his friend , and [he]260-the bishop did so ; and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding felt that [he]102-mr. harding had received that for which [he]102-mr. harding came . There was another period of silence , after which , [the bishop]260-the bishop asked with a degree of irritable energy , very unusual with [him]260-the bishop , whether [this "[0-i] pestilent intruder]2788-this " pestilent intruder " ( meaning [John Bold]121-bold ) had [any friends in [Barchester]6-barchester]2789-any friends in barchester . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had fully made up [his]102-mr. harding mind to tell [the bishop]260-the bishop everything ; to speak of [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter 's love , as well as [his]102-mr. harding own troubles ; to talk of [John Bold]121-bold in [his]121-bold double capacity of [future son - in - law]2792-future son - in - law and [present enemy]2793-present enemy ; and though [he]102-mr. harding felt it to be sufficiently disagreeable , now was [his]102-mr. harding time to do it . "[849-he] [He]849-he is very intimate at [[my]0-i own house]850-my own house , [bishop]845-bishop . " [The bishop]260-the bishop stared ; [he]260-the bishop was not so far gone in orthodoxy and church - military as [[his]260-the bishop son]521-his son , but still [he]260-the bishop could not bring [himself]260-the bishop to understand how so declared [an enemy of the establishment]2796-an enemy of the establishment could be admitted on terms of intimacy into [the house]374-the house , not only of [so firm a pillar as [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , but one so much injured as [the warden of [the hospital]364-the hospital]2799-the warden of the hospital]2798-so firm a pillar as mr. harding , but one so much injured as the warden of the hospital . "[849-he] Indeed , [I]0-i like [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold much , personally , " continued [the disinterested victim]2801-the disinterested victim ; "[0-i] and to tell [you]845-bishop the ' truth , ' " — [he]0-i hesitated as [he]0-i brought out the dreadful tidings,—"I[849-he] have sometimes thought it not improbable that [he]122-mr. bold would be [[my]0-i second son - in - law]852-my second son - in - law . " [The bishop]260-the bishop did not whistle ; [we]2803-we believe that [they]260-the bishop lose the power of doing so on being consecrated ; and that in these days [one]729-one might as easily meet [a corrupt judge]2805-a corrupt judge as [a whistling bishop]2806-a whistling bishop ; but [he]0-i looked as though [he]0-i would have done so , but for [his]0-i apron . What [a brother - in - law]2807-a brother - in - law for [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon ! what an alliance for [Barchester]6-barchester close ! what a connexion for even [the episcopal palace]2809-the episcopal palace ! [The bishop]260-the bishop , in [his]260-the bishop simple mind , felt no doubt that [John Bold]121-bold , had [he]121-bold so much power , would shut up all [cathedrals]2811-cathedrals , and probably all [parish churches]2812-parish churches ; distribute all tithes among [Methodists]2813-methodists , [Baptists]2814-baptists , and [other savage tribes]2815-other savage tribes ; utterly annihilate the sacred bench , and make shovel hats and lawn sleeves as illegal as cowls , sandals , and sackcloth ! Here was [a nice man to be initiated into the comfortable arcana of ecclesiastical snuggeries]2816-a nice man to be initiated into the comfortable arcana of ecclesiastical snuggeries ; one who doubted the integrity of [parsons]2817-parsons , and probably disbelieved [the Trinity]2818-the trinity ! [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding saw what an effect [his]102-mr. harding communication had made , and almost repented the openness of [his]102-mr. harding disclosure ; [he]102-mr. harding , however , did what [he]102-mr. harding could to moderate the grief of [[his]102-mr. harding friend]285-his friend and [patron]2820-patron . "[849-he] [I]0-i did not say that there is any engagement between [them]853-them . Had there been , [Eleanor]104-eleanor would have told [me]0-i : [I]0-i know [her]104-eleanor well enough to be assured that [she]104-eleanor would have done so ; but [I]0-i see that [they]853-them are fond of [each other]497-each other ; and as [a man]545-a man and [a father]856-a father , [I]0-i have had no objection to urge against [their]853-them intimacy . " "[102-mr. harding] But , [Harding]102-mr. harding , " said [the bishop]260-the bishop , "[102-mr. harding] how are [you]102-mr. harding to oppose [him]857-him , if [he]857-him is [[your]102-mr. harding son - in - law]858-your son - in - law ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't mean to oppose [him]857-him ; it is [he]857-him who opposes [me]0-i : if anything is to be done in defence , [I]0-i suppose [Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick will do it . [I]0-i suppose — " "[0-i] Oh , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon will see to that : were [the young man]763-the young man twice [[his]763-the young man brother - in - law]861-his brother - in - law , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon will never be deterred from doing what [he]382-the archdeacon feels to be right . " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding reminded [the bishop]260-the bishop that [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon and [the reformer]2824-the reformer were not yet [brothers]2825-brothers , and very probably never would be ; exacted from [him]260-the bishop a promise that [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's name should not be mentioned in any discussion between [the father bishop]2826-the father bishop and [son archdeacon]2827-son archdeacon respecting [the hospital]364-the hospital ; and then took [his]260-the bishop departure , leaving [[his]102-mr. harding poor old friend]2829-his poor old friend bewildered , amazed , and confounded . [The parties most interested in the movement which is about to set Barchester by the ears]2830-the parties most interested in the movement which is about to set barchester by the ears , were not the foremost to discuss the merit of the question , as is often the case ; but when [the bishop]260-the bishop , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , [the warden]318-the warden , [the steward]350-the steward , and [Messrs. Cox]132-cox and [Cummins]133-cummins , were all busy with the matter , each in [his]260-the bishop own way , it is not to be supposed that [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's bedesmen]406-hiram 's bedesmen [themselves]406-hiram 's bedesmen were altogether [passive spectators]2836-passive spectators . [Finney]131-finney , [the attorney]682-the attorney , had been among [them]406-hiram 's bedesmen , asking sly questions , and raising immoderate hopes , creating [a party hostile to [the warden]318-the warden , and establishing a corps in [[the enemy]2840-the enemy 's camp]2841-the enemy 's camp]2838-a party hostile to the warden , and establishing a corps in the enemy 's camp , as [he]131-finney figuratively calls it to [himself]131-finney . [Poor old men]2842-poor old men ; whoever may be righted or wronged by this inquiry , [they]2842-poor old men at any rate will assuredly be only injured ; to [them]2842-poor old men it can only be an unmixed evil . How can [their]2842-poor old men lot be improved ? all [their]2842-poor old men wants are supplied ; every comfort is administered ; [they]2842-poor old men have warm houses , good clothes , plentiful diet , and rest after a life of labour ; and above all , that treasure so inestimable in declining years , [a true and kind friend]2843-a true and kind friend to listen to [their]2842-poor old men sorrows , watch over [their]2842-poor old men sickness , and administer comfort as regards [this world]2844-this world , and [the world]325-the world to come ! [John Bold]121-bold sometimes thinks of this , when [he]121-bold is talking loudly of the rights of [the bedesmen]353-the bedesmen , whom [he]121-bold has taken under [his]121-bold protection ; but [he]121-bold quiets the suggestion within [his]121-bold breast with the high - sounding name of justice—"fiat[382-the archdeacon] justitia ; ruat coelum . " [These old men]2847-these old men should , by rights , have one hundred pounds a year instead of one shilling and sixpence a day , and [the warden]318-the warden should have two hundred or three hundred pounds instead of eight hundred pounds . What is unjust must be wrong ; what is wrong should be righted ; and if [he]121-bold declined the task , who else would do it ? "[382-the archdeacon] [Each one of [you]864-you]863-each one of you is clearly entitled to one hundred pounds a year by common law : " such had been the important whisper made by [Finney]131-finney into the ears of [Abel Handy]119-handy , and by [him]119-handy retailed to [[his]119-handy eleven brethren]2849-his eleven brethren . Too much must not be expected from the flesh and blood even of [[John Hiram]107-john hiram 's bedesmen]506-john hiram 's bedesmen , and the positive promise of one hundred a year to [each of [the twelve old men]2852-the twelve old men]2851-each of the twelve old men , had its way with most of [them]2852-the twelve old men . [The great Bunce]136-bunce was not to be wiled away , and was upheld in [his]136-bunce orthodoxy by [two adherents]2853-two adherents . [Abel Handy]119-handy , who was [the leader of [the aspirants after wealth]2855-the aspirants after wealth]2854-the leader of the aspirants after wealth , had , alas , a stronger following . [No less than five of [the twelve]2857-the twelve]2856-no less than five of the twelve soon believed that [his]119-handy views were just , making with [[their]2856-no less than five of the twelve leader a moiety of [the hospital]364-the hospital]2858-their leader a moiety of the hospital . The other three , volatile unstable minds , vacillated between [the two chieftains]2860-the two chieftains , now led away by the hope of gold , now anxious to propitiate the powers that still existed . It had been proposed to address a petition to [the bishop]260-the bishop as [visiter]2862-visiter , praying [[his]260-the bishop lordship]2863-his lordship to see justice done to [the legal recipients of [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's Charity]2864-the legal recipients of john hiram 's charity , and to send copies of this petition and of the reply [it]2865-it would elicit , to all the leading [London]13-london papers , and thereby to obtain notoriety for the subject . This it was thought would pave the way for ulterior legal proceedings . It would have been a great thing to have had the signatures and marks of [all the twelve injured legatees]2866-all the twelve injured legatees ; but this was impossible : [Bunce]136-bunce would have cut [his]136-bunce hand off sooner than have signed it . It was then suggested by [Finney]131-finney that if [even eleven]2867-even eleven could be induced to sanction the document , [the one obstinate recusant]2868-the one obstinate recusant might have been represented as unfit to judge on such a question,—in fact , as being [non compos mentis]2869-non compos mentis , — and the petition would have been taken as representing the feeling of [the men]378-the men . But this could not be done : [[Bunce]136-bunce 's friends]2871-bunce 's friends were as firm as [himself]136-bunce , and as yet only six crosses adorned the document . It was the more provoking , as [Bunce]136-bunce [himself]136-bunce could write [his]136-bunce name legibly , and [one of [those three doubting souls]2873-those three doubting souls]2872-one of those three doubting souls had for years boasted of like power , and possessed , indeed , a Bible , in which [he]136-bunce was proud to show [his]136-bunce name written by [himself]136-bunce some thirty years [ago—"Job[382-the archdeacon] Skulpit]141-skulpit ; " but it was thought that [Job Skulpit]141-skulpit , having forgotten [his]141-skulpit scholarship , on that account recoiled from the petition , and that [the other doubters]2874-the other doubters would follow as [he]141-skulpit led [them]2874-the other doubters . A petition signed by half [the hospital]364-the hospital would have but a poor effect . It was in [[Skulpit]141-skulpit 's room]2876-skulpit 's room that the petition was now lying , waiting such additional signatures as [Abel Handy]119-handy , by [his]119-handy eloquence , could obtain for it . The six marks it bore were duly attested , thus : — [Abel]119-handy [his]119-handy + [mark Handy]119-handy , [Greg]142-greg y [his]119-handy + mark [Moody]143-moody , [Mathew]144-mathew [his]119-handy + [mark Spriggs]145-spriggs , & c. , and places were duly designated in pencil for [those brethren who were now expected to join]2877-those brethren who were now expected to join : for [Skulpit]141-skulpit alone was left a spot on which [his]141-skulpit genuine signature might be written in fair clerklike style . [Handy]119-handy had brought in the document , and spread it out on the small deal table , and was now standing by it persuasive and eager . [Moody]143-moody had followed with an inkhorn , carefully left behind by [Finney]131-finney ; and [Spriggs]145-spriggs bore aloft , as though it were a sword , a well - worn ink - black pen , which from time to time [he]141-skulpit endeavoured to thrust into [Skulpit]141-skulpit 's unwilling hand . With [the learned man]2878-the learned man were [his]141-skulpit two abettors in indecision , [William Gazy]146-billy gazy and [Jonathan Crumple]147-jonathan crumple . If ever the petition were to be forwarded , now was the time , so said [Mr. Finney]131-finney ; and great was the anxiety on the part of those whose one hundred pounds a year , as [they]2879-they believed , mainly depended on the document in question . "[382-the archdeacon] To be kept out of all that money , " as the avaricious [Moody]143-moody had muttered to [[his]143-moody friend]285-his friend [Handy]119-handy , "[865-an old fool] by [an old fool]865-an old fool saying that [he]865-an old fool can write [his]865-an old fool own name like [his]865-an old fool betters . " "[865-an old fool] Well Job , " said [Handy]119-handy , trying to impart to [his]119-handy own sour , ill - omened visage a smile of approbation , in which [he]119-handy greatly failed ; "[865-an old fool] so [you]866-you 're ready now , [Mr. Finney]131-finney says ; here 's the place , [d'ye]867-d'ye see,"—and [he]0-i put [his]0-i huge brown finger down on the dirty paper , — "[131-finney] name or mark , it 's all one . Come along , [old boy]868-old boy ; if so be [we]869-we 're to have the spending of this money , why the sooner the better — that 's [my]0-i maxim . " "[0-i] To be sure , " said [Moody]143-moody ; "[869-we] [we]869-we a'n't none of [us]869-we so young : [we]869-we ca n't stay waiting for [old Catgut]148-old catgut no longer . " It was thus [these miscreants]2881-these miscreants named [[our]869-we excellent friend]2882-our excellent friend : the nickname [he]2882-our excellent friend could easily have forgiven , but the allusion to the divine source of all [his]2882-our excellent friend melodious joy would have irritated even [him]2882-our excellent friend . Let [us]869-we hope [he]2882-our excellent friend never knew the insult . "[148-old catgut] Only think , [old Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy , " said [Spriggs]145-spriggs , who rejoiced in greater youth than [[his]145-spriggs brethren]2883-his brethren , but having fallen into a fire when drunk , had had one eye burnt out , one cheek burnt through , and one arm nearly burnt off , and who , therefore , in regard to personal appearance , was not the most prepossessing of [men]453-men ; "[146-billy gazy] a hundred a year , and all to spend : only think , [old Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy ; " and [he]145-spriggs gave a hideous grin that showed off [his]145-spriggs misfortunes to their full extent . [Old Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy was not alive to much enthusiasm — even these golden prospects did not arouse [him]146-billy gazy to do more than rub [his]146-billy gazy poor old bleared eyes with the cuff of [his]146-billy gazy bedesman 's gown , and gently mutter ; ' [he]146-billy gazy did n't know , not [he]146-billy gazy ; [he]146-billy gazy did n't know . ' "[146-billy gazy] But [you]870-you 'd know , [Jonathan]147-jonathan crumple , " continued [Spriggs]145-spriggs , turning to [the other friend of [Skulpit]141-skulpit 's , who was sitting on a stool by the table , gazing vacantly at the petition]2885-the other friend of skulpit 's , who was sitting on a stool by the table , gazing vacantly at the petition . [Jonathan Crumple]147-jonathan crumple was [a meek , mild man]2886-a meek , mild man , who had known better days ; [his]147-jonathan crumple means had been wasted by [bad children]2887-bad children , who had made [his]147-jonathan crumple life wretched till [he]147-jonathan crumple had been received into [the hospital]364-the hospital , of which [he]147-jonathan crumple had not long been [a member]2889-a member . Since that day [he]147-jonathan crumple had known neither sorrow nor trouble , and this attempt to fill [him]147-jonathan crumple with new hopes was , indeed , a cruelty . "[147-jonathan crumple] A hundred a year 's a nice thing , for [sartain]871-sartain , [neighbour Spriggs]145-spriggs , " said [he]147-jonathan crumple : "[145-spriggs] [I]0-i once had nigh to that [myself]0-i , but it did n't do [me]0-i no good . " And [he]147-jonathan crumple gave a low sigh , as [he]147-jonathan crumple thought of [the children of [his]147-jonathan crumple own loins who had robbed [him]147-jonathan crumple]2890-the children of his own loins who had robbed him . "[145-spriggs] And shall have again , [Joe]120-joe , " said [Handy]119-handy ; "[120-joe] and will have [some one]872-some one to keep it right and tight for [you]120-joe this time . " [Crumple]147-jonathan crumple sighed again — [he]147-jonathan crumple had learned the impotency of worldly wealth , and would have been satisfied , if left untempted , to have remained happy with one and sixpence a day . "[872-some one] Come , [Skulpit]141-skulpit , " repeated [Handy]119-handy , getting impatient , "[141-skulpit] [you]141-skulpit 're not going to go along with [old Bunce]136-bunce in helping [that parson]873-that parson to rob [us]874-us all . Take the pen , [man]875-man , and right [yourself]141-skulpit . Well , " [he]119-handy added , seeing that [Skulpit]141-skulpit still doubted , "[545-a man] to see [a man]545-a man as is afraid to stand by hisself , is , to [my]0-i thinking , the meanest thing as is . " "[0-i] Sink [them]877-them all for parsons , says [I]0-i , " growled [Moody]143-moody ; "[0-i] [hungry beggars]878-hungry beggars , as never thinks [their]878-hungry beggars bellies full till [they]878-hungry beggars have robbed all and every thing . " "[878-hungry beggars] Who 's to harm [you]141-skulpit , [man]875-man ? " argued [Spriggs]145-spriggs : "[877-them] let [them]877-them look never so black at [you]141-skulpit , [they]877-them ca n't get [you]141-skulpit put out when [you]141-skulpit 're once in — no , not [old Catgut]148-old catgut , with [Calves]149-calves to help [him]148-old catgut ! " [I]149-calves am sorry to say [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon [himself]382-the archdeacon was designated by this scurrilous allusion to [[his]382-the archdeacon nether person]2892-his nether person . "[149-calves] A hundred a year to win , and nothing to lose , " continued [Handy]119-handy , "[149-calves] [my]0-i eyes!—Well , how [a man]545-a man 's to doubt about sich a bit of cheese as that passes [me]0-i — but [some men]881-some men is timorous — [some men]881-some men is born with no pluck in [them]881-some men — [some men]881-some men is cowed at the very first sight of [a gen'leman]884-a gen'leman 's coat and waistcoat . " Oh , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , if [you]886-you had but taken [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's advice in that disputed case , when [Joe Mutters]120-joe was [this ungrateful demagogue 's rival candidate]2894-this ungrateful demagogue 's rival candidate ! "[881-some men] Afraid of [a parson]885-a parson , " growled [Moody]143-moody , with a look of ineffable scorn ; "[0-i] [I]0-i tell [ye]886-you what [I]0-i 'd be afraid of — [I]0-i 'd be afraid of not getting nothing from 'em but just what [I]0-i could take by might and right — that 's the most [I]0-i 'd be afraid on of [any parson of 'em all]887-any parson of 'em all . " "[0-i] But , " said [Skulpit]141-skulpit , apologetically , "[102-mr. harding] [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's not so bad — [he]102-mr. harding did give [us]888-us twopence a day , did n't [he]102-mr. harding now ? " "[102-mr. harding] Twopence a day ! " exclaimed [Spriggs]145-spriggs with scorn , opening awfully the red cavern of [his]145-spriggs lost eye . "[102-mr. harding] Twopence a day ! " muttered [Moody]143-moody with a curse ; "[102-mr. harding] sink [his]102-mr. harding twopence ! " "[102-mr. harding] Twopence a day ! " exclaimed [Handy]119-handy ; "[0-i] and [I]0-i 'm to go , hat in hand , and thank [a chap]889-a chap for twopence a day , when [he]889-a chap owes [me]0-i a hundred pounds a year : no , thank [ye]886-you ; that may do for [you]886-you , but it wo n't for [me]0-i . Come , [I]0-i say [Skulpit]141-skulpit , are [you]141-skulpit a going to put [your]141-skulpit mark to this here paper , or are [you]141-skulpit not ? " [Skulpit]141-skulpit looked round in wretched indecision to [[his]141-skulpit two friends]2895-his two friends . "[0-i] What d'ye think , [Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy ? " said [he]141-skulpit . But [Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy could n't think : [he]146-billy gazy made a noise like the bleating of an old sheep , which was intended to express the agony of [his]146-billy gazy doubt , and again muttered that ' [he]146-billy gazy did ' nt know . ' "[146-billy gazy] Take hold , [you]141-skulpit old cripple , " said [Handy]119-handy , thrusting the pen into poor [Billy]146-billy gazy 's hand : "[141-skulpit] there , so — ugh ! [[you]141-skulpit old fool]890-you old fool , [you]141-skulpit 've been and smeared it all — there — that 'll do for [you,—that]891-you,—that 's as good as the best name as ever was written : " and a big blotch of ink was presumed to represent [Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy 's acquiescence . "[891-you,—that] Now [Jonathan]147-jonathan crumple , " said [Handy]119-handy , turning to [Crumple]147-jonathan crumple . "[147-jonathan crumple] A hundred a year 's a nice thing , for [sartain]871-sartain , " again argued [Crumple]147-jonathan crumple . "[871-sartain] Well , [neighbour Skulpit]141-skulpit , how 's it to be ? " "[141-skulpit] Oh , please [yourself]141-skulpit , " said [Skulpit]141-skulpit ; "[141-skulpit] please [yourself]141-skulpit , and [you]141-skulpit 'll please [me]0-i . " The pen was thrust into [Crumple]147-jonathan crumple 's hand , and a faint , wandering , meaningless sign was made , betokening such sanction and authority as [Jonathan Crumple]147-jonathan crumple was able to convey . "[141-skulpit] Come [Joe]120-joe , " said [Handy]119-handy , softened by success , "[120-joe] do n't let ['em]893-'em have to say that [old Bunce]136-bunce has [a man like [you]120-joe under [his]136-bunce thumb]894-a man like you under his thumb — [a man that always holds [his]136-bunce head in [the hospital]364-the hospital as high as [Bunce]136-bunce [himself]136-bunce]895-a man that always holds his head in the hospital as high as bunce himself , though [you]120-joe 're never axed to drink wine , and sneak , and tell lies about [your]120-joe betters , as [he]136-bunce does . " [Skulpit]141-skulpit held the pen , and made little flourishes with it in the air , but still hesitated . "[136-bunce] And if [you]120-joe 'll be said by [me]0-i , " continued [Handy]119-handy , "[120-joe] [you]120-joe 'll not - write [your]120-joe name to it at all , but just put [your]120-joe mark like the others,"—the cloud began to clear from [Skulpit]141-skulpit 's brow:—"we[120-joe] all know [you]120-joe can do it if [you]120-joe like , but maybe [you]120-joe would n't like to seem uppish , [you]120-joe know . " "[120-joe] Well , the mark would be best , " said [Skulpit]141-skulpit : "[120-joe] one name and the rest marks , would n't look well , would it ? " "[120-joe] The worst in [the world]325-the world , " said [Handy]119-handy ; "[120-joe] there — there : " and stooping over the petition , [the learned clerk]2896-the learned clerk made a huge cross on the place left for [his]2896-the learned clerk signature . "[120-joe] That 's the game , " said [Handy]119-handy , triumphantly pocketing the petition ; "[120-joe] [we]898-we 're all in [a boat]899-a boat now , that is , the nine of [us]898-we ; and as for [old Bunce]136-bunce , and [[his]136-bunce cronies]900-his cronies , [they]901-they may — " But as [he]119-handy was hobbling off to the door , with a crutch on one side and a stick on the other , [he]119-handy was met by [Bunce]136-bunce [himself]136-bunce . "[901-they] Well , [Handy]119-handy , and what may [old Bunce]136-bunce do ? " said [the grey - haired , upright senior]2897-the grey - haired , upright senior . [Handy]119-handy muttered something , and was departing ; but [he]119-handy was stopped in the doorway by the huge frame of [the new comer]2898-the new comer . "[136-bunce] [You]119-handy 've been doing no good here , [Abel Handy]119-handy , " said [he]0-i , "[119-handy] ' t is plain to see that ; and ' tisn't much good , [I]0-i 'm thinking , [you]119-handy ever do . " "[0-i] [I]0-i mind [my]0-i own business , [Master Bunce]136-bunce , " muttered [the other]762-the other , "[136-bunce] and do [you]119-handy do the same . It an't nothing to [you]119-handy what [I]0-i does — and [your]119-handy spying and poking here wo n't do no good nor yet no harm . " "[0-i] [I]0-i suppose then , [Joe]120-joe , " continued [Bunce]136-bunce , not noticing [[his]136-bunce opponent]2900-his opponent , "[0-i] if the truth must out , [you]120-joe 've stuck [your]120-joe name to that petition of theirs at last . " [Skulpit]141-skulpit looked as though [he]141-skulpit were about to sink into nothing with shame . "[120-joe] What is it to [you]120-joe what [he]136-bunce signs ? " said [Handy]119-handy . "[120-joe] [I]0-i suppose if [we]902-we all wants to ax for [our]902-we own , [we]902-we need n't ax leave of [you]119-handy first , [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce , [big a man]903-big a man as [you]119-handy are : and as to [your]119-handy sneaking in [here]904-here , into [[Job]141-skulpit 's room]905-job 's room when [he]141-skulpit 's busy , and where [you]119-handy 're not wanted — " "[0-i] [I]0-i 've knowed [Job Skulpit]141-skulpit , [man]875-man and [boy]907-boy , sixty years , " said [Bunce]136-bunce , looking at [the man of whom [he]136-bunce spoke]2901-the man of whom he spoke , "[141-skulpit] and that 's ever since the day [he]141-skulpit was born . [I]0-i knowed [the mother that bore [him]141-skulpit]908-the mother that bore him , when [she]908-the mother that bore him and [I]0-i were little wee things , picking daisies together in the close yonder ; and [I]0-i 've lived under the same roof with [him]141-skulpit more nor ten years ; and after that [I]0-i may come into [[his]141-skulpit room]909-his room without axing leave , and yet no sneaking neither . " "[0-i] So [you]0-i can , [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce , " said [Skulpit]141-skulpit ; "[0-i] so [you]0-i can , any hour , day or night . " "[141-skulpit] And [I]0-i 'm free also to tell [him]141-skulpit [my]0-i mind , " continued [Bunce]136-bunce , looking at [the one man]2902-the one man and addressing [the other]762-the other ; "[0-i] and [I]0-i tell [him]141-skulpit now that [he]141-skulpit 's done a foolish and a wrong thing : [he]141-skulpit 's turned [his]141-skulpit back upon [one who is [[his]141-skulpit best friend]911-his best friend]910-one who is his best friend ; and is playing the game of others , who care nothing for [him]141-skulpit , whether [he]141-skulpit be poor or rich , well or ill , alive or dead . A hundred a year ? Are the lot of [you]912-you soft enough to think that if a hundred a year be to be given , it 's the likes of [you]912-you that will get it?"—and [he]0-i pointed to [Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy , [Spriggs]145-spriggs , and Crumple . "[912-you] Did any of [us]913-we ever do anything worth half the money ? Was it to make [gentlemen of [us]913-we [we]913-we were brought in [here]904-here]914-gentlemen of us we were brought in here , when all [the world]325-the world turned against [us]913-we , and [we]913-we could't longer earn [our]913-we daily bread ? A n't [you]912-you all as rich in [your]912-you ways as [he]141-skulpit in his?"—and [the orator]2904-the orator pointed to the side on which [the warden]318-the warden lived . "[141-skulpit] A n't [you]912-you getting all [you]912-you hoped for , ay , and more than [you]912-you hoped for ? Would't [each of [you]912-you]917-each of you have given the dearest limb of [his]141-skulpit body to secure that which now makes [you]912-you so unthankful ? " "[913-we] [We]913-we wants what [John Hiram]107-john hiram left [us]913-we , " said [Handy]119-handy ; "[913-we] [we]913-we wants what 's ourn by law ; it do n't matter what [we]913-we expected ; what 's ourn by law should be ourn , and by goles [we]913-we 'll have it . " "[913-we] Law ! " said [Bunce]136-bunce , with all the scorn [he]136-bunce knew how to command,—"law[913-we] ! Did [ye]912-you ever know [a poor man]918-a poor man yet was the better for law , or for [a lawyer]605-a lawyer ? Will [Mr. Finney]131-finney ever be as good to [you]912-you , [Job]141-skulpit , as [that man]920-that man has been ? Will [he]920-that man see to [you]912-you when [you]912-you 're sick , and comfort [you]912-you when [you]912-you 're wretched ? Will [he]920-that man — " "[920-that man] No , nor give [you]912-you port wine , [old boy]868-old boy , on cold winter nights ! [he]920-that man wo n't do that , will [he]920-that man ? " asked [Handy]119-handy : and laughing at the severity of [his]119-handy own wit , [he]119-handy and [[his]119-handy colleagues]2906-his colleagues retired , carrying with [them]2907-them , however , the now powerful petition . There is no help for spilt milk ; and [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce could only retire to [[his]136-bunce own room]2908-his own room , disgusted at the frailty of human nature — [Job Skulpit]141-skulpit scratched [his]141-skulpit head — [Jonathan Crumple]147-jonathan crumple again remarked , that , ' for sartain , sure a hundred a year was very nice ' — and [Billy Gazy]146-billy gazy again rubbed [his]146-billy gazy eyes , and lowly muttered that ' [he]146-billy gazy did n't know . ' Though doubt and hesitation disturbed [the rest of [[our]2910-our poor warden]2911-our poor warden]2909-the rest of our poor warden , no such weakness perplexed [the nobler breast of [[his]136-bunce son - in - law]440-his son - in - law]2912-the nobler breast of his son - in - law . As [the indomitable cock preparing for the combat]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat sharpens [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat spurs , shakes [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat feathers , and erects [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat comb , so did [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon arrange [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat weapons for the coming war , without misgiving and without fear . That [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat was fully confident of the justice of [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat cause let [no one]283-no one doubt . Many [a man]545-a man can fight [his]545-a man battle with good courage , but with a doubting conscience ; such was not the case with [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly . [He]106-dr. grantly did not believe in [the Gospel]150-the gospel with more assurance than [he]106-dr. grantly did in the sacred justice of all ecclesiastical revenues . When [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat put [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat shoulder to the wheel to defend the income of the present and [future precentors of [Barchester]6-barchester]2918-future precentors of barchester , [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat was animated by as strong a sense of a holy cause , as that which gives courage to [a missionary in [Africa]25-africa]2919-a missionary in africa , or enables [a sister of mercy]2920-a sister of mercy to give up the pleasures of [the world]325-the world for the wards of [a hospital]2922-a hospital . [He]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat was about to defend the holy of holies from the touch of the profane ; to guard [the citadel of [[his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat church]2924-his church]2923-the citadel of his church from [the most rampant of its enemies]2925-the most rampant of its enemies ; to put on [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat good armour in the best of fights ; and secure , if possible , the comforts of [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat creed for coming generations of [ecclesiastical dignitaries]2926-ecclesiastical dignitaries . Such a work required no ordinary vigour ; and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon was , therefore , extraordinarily vigorous : it demanded a buoyant courage , and a heart happy in its toil ; and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's heart was happy , and [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat courage was buoyant . [He]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat knew that [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat would not be able to animate [[his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat father - in - law]435-his father - in - law with feelings like [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat own , but this did not much disturb [him]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat . [He]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat preferred to bear the brunt of the battle alone , and did not doubt that [the warden]318-the warden would resign [himself]318-the warden into [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat hands with passive submission . "[920-that man] Well , [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , " [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat said , walking into [[the steward]350-the steward 's office]2932-the steward 's office a day or two after the signing of the petition as commemorated in the last chapter ; "[920-that man] anything from [Cox]132-cox and [Cummins]133-cummins this morning ? " [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick handed [him]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat a letter , which [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat read , stroking the tight - gaitered calf of [his]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat right leg as [he]2914-the indomitable cock preparing for the combat did so . [Messrs. Cox]132-cox and [Cummins]133-cummins merely said that [they]922-them had as yet received no notice from [[their]922-them adversaries]2933-their adversaries ; that [they]922-them could recommend no preliminary steps ; but that should any proceeding really be taken by [the bedesmen]353-the bedesmen , it would be expedient to consult [[that very eminent Queen]2935-that very eminent queen 's Counsel]2936-that very eminent queen 's counsel , [Sir Abraham Haphazard]151-sir abraham . "[922-them] [I]0-i quite agree with [them]922-them , " said [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , refolding the letter . "[0-i] [I]0-i perfectly agree with [them]922-them . [Haphazard]151-sir abraham is no doubt [the best man]923-the best man ; [a thorough churchman]924-a thorough churchman , [a sound conservative]925-a sound conservative , and in every respect [the best man [we]927-we could get]926-the best man we could get — [he]151-sir abraham 's in [the house]374-the house , too , which is a great thing . " [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick quite agreed . "[151-sir abraham] [You]0-i remember how completely [he]151-sir abraham put down [that scoundrel Horseman]929-that scoundrel horseman about [the Bishop of [Beverly]26-beverly 's income]930-the bishop of beverly 's income ; how completely [he]151-sir abraham set [them]922-them all adrift in [the earl]931-the earl 's case . " With all [his]613-the doctor admiration for [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , [the doctor]613-the doctor seemed to think it not impossible that [that great man]2941-that great man might be induced to lend [his]2941-that great man gigantic powers to the side of [[the church]454-the church 's enemies]2943-the church 's enemies . Having settled this point to [his]613-the doctor satisfaction , [the doctor]613-the doctor stepped down to [the hospital]364-the hospital , to learn how matters were going on [there]713-there ; and as [he]613-the doctor walked across [the hallowed close]2947-the hallowed close , and looked up at the ravens who cawed with a peculiar reverence as [he]613-the doctor wended [his]613-the doctor way , [he]613-the doctor thought with increased acerbity of those whose impiety would venture to disturb the goodly grace of [cathedral institutions]2948-cathedral institutions . And who has not felt the same ? [We]927-we believe that [Mr. Horseman]153-mr. horseman [himself]153-mr. horseman would relent , and the spirit of [Sir Benjamin Hall]154-sir benjamin hall give way , were [those great reformers]2949-those great reformers to allow [themselves]2949-those great reformers to stroll by moonlight round the towers of [some of [[our]927-we ancient churches]2951-our ancient churches]2950-some of our ancient churches . Who would not feel charity for a prebendary , when walking the quiet length of that long aisle at [Winchester]27-winchester , looking at [those decent houses]2952-those decent houses , that trim grassplat , and feeling , as one must , the solemn , orderly comfort of the spot ? Who could be hard upon [a dean]597-a dean while wandering round [the sweet close of [Hereford]4-hereford]2954-the sweet close of hereford , and owning that in [that precinct]2955-that precinct , tone and colour , design and form , solemn tower and storied window , are all in unison , and all perfect ? Who could lie basking in [the cloisters of [Salisbury]2-salisbury]2956-the cloisters of salisbury , and gaze on [[Jewel]155-jewel 's library]2957-jewel 's library , and that unequalled spire , without feeling that [bishops]338-bishops should sometimes be rich ? The tone of [[our]927-we archdeacon]577-our archdeacon 's mind must not astonish [us]927-we ; it has been the growth of centuries of church ascendancy ; and though some fungi now disfigure the tree , though there be much dead wood , for how much good fruit have not [we]927-we to be thankful ? Who , without remorse , can batter down the dead branches of an old oak , now useless , but , ah ! still so beautiful , or drag out the fragments of [the ancient forest]2960-the ancient forest , without feeling that they sheltered the younger plants , to which they are now summoned to give way in a tone so peremptory and so harsh ? [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , with all [his]382-the archdeacon virtues , was not [a man of delicate feeling]2962-a man of delicate feeling ; and after having made [his]382-the archdeacon morning salutations in [[the warden]318-the warden 's drawing - room]2964-the warden 's drawing - room , [he]382-the archdeacon did not scruple to commence an attack on ' pestilent ' [John Bold]121-bold in the presence of [Miss Harding]156-miss harding , though [he]382-the archdeacon rightly guessed that [that lady]2965-that lady was not indifferent to the name of [[his]382-the archdeacon enemy]639-his enemy . "[934-the other party] [Nelly]104-eleanor , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear , fetch [me]0-i [my]0-i spectacles from [the back room]936-the back room , " said [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father , anxious to save both [her]104-eleanor blushes and [her]104-eleanor feelings . [Eleanor]104-eleanor brought the spectacles , while [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father was trying , in ambiguous phrases , to explain to [[her]104-eleanor too - practical brother - in - law]2969-her too - practical brother - in - law that it might be as well not to say anything about [Bold]121-bold before [her]104-eleanor , and then retreated . Nothing had been explained to [her]104-eleanor about [Bold]121-bold and [the hospital]364-the hospital ; but , with [a woman]2971-a woman 's instinct , [she]104-eleanor knew that things were going wrong . "[104-eleanor] [We]937-we must soon be doing something , " commenced [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , wiping [his]382-the archdeacon brows with a large , bright - coloured handkerchief ; for [he]382-the archdeacon had felt busy , and had walked quick , and it was a broiling summer 's day . "[937-we] Of course [you]938-you have heard of the petition ? " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding owned , somewhat unwillingly , that [he]102-mr. harding had heard of it . " [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , who was [a practical man]2975-a practical man , allowed [himself]382-the archdeacon the use of every - day expressive modes of speech when among [[his]382-the archdeacon closest intimates]2976-his closest intimates , though [no one]283-no one could soar into a more intricate labyrinth of refined phraseology when [the church]454-the church was the subject , and [[his]382-the archdeacon lower brethren]2979-his lower brethren were [[his]382-the archdeacon auditors]2980-his auditors . [The warden]318-the warden still looked mutely in [his]318-the warden face , making the slightest possible passes with an imaginary fiddle bow , and stopping , as [he]318-the warden did so , sundry imaginary strings with the fingers of [his]318-the warden other hand . ' T was [his]318-the warden constant consolation in conversational troubles . While these vexed [him]318-the warden sorely , the passes would be short and slow , and the upper hand would not be seen to work ; nay the strings on which it operated would sometimes lie concealed in [the musician]708-the musician 's pocket , and the instrument on which [he]318-the warden played would be beneath [his]318-the warden chair ; but as [his]318-the warden spirit warmed to the subject,—as [his]318-the warden trusting heart , looking to the bottom of that which vexed [him]318-the warden , would see its clear way out,—he would rise to a higher melody , sweep the unseen strings with a bolder hand , and swiftly fingering the cords from [his]318-the warden neck , down along [his]318-the warden waistcoat , and up again to [his]318-the warden very ear , create an ecstatic strain of perfect music , audible to [himself]318-the warden and to [St. Cecilia]135-st. cecilia , and not without effect . " [The warden]318-the warden played the slowest and saddest of tunes : it was but a dirge on one string . "[0-i] [I]0-i think [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham will not be long in letting [Master Bold]122-mr. bold know what [he]151-sir abraham 's about . " [The warden]318-the warden 's mind misgave [him]318-the warden , and even for a moment [he]318-the warden forgot to play . [He]318-the warden by no means wished to delegate to [[his]318-the warden son - in - law]440-his son - in - law [his]318-the warden place and authority of [warden]304-warden ; [he]318-the warden had expressly determined not to interfere in any step which [the men]378-the men might wish to take in the matter under dispute ; [he]318-the warden was most anxious neither to accuse [them]378-the men nor to defend [himself]318-the warden .
