" [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding knew not how to resist , and the disagreeable order was given . [The quad]953-the quad , as [it]953-the quad was familiarly called , was [a small quadrangle]2999-a small quadrangle , open on one side to [the river]396-the river , and surrounded on the others by the high wall of [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's garden]3001-mr. harding 's garden , by one gable end of [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's house]408-mr. harding 's house , and by the end of the row of buildings which formed [the residences of [the bedesmen]353-the bedesmen]3003-the residences of the bedesmen . [It]953-the quad was flagged all round , and the centre was stoned ; small stone gutters ran from the four corners of [the square]3005-the square to a grating in the centre ; and attached to the end of [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's house]408-mr. harding 's house was [a conduit with four cocks covered over from the weather , at which [the old men]314-the old men got [their]314-the old men water , and very generally performed [their]314-the old men morning toilet]3007-a conduit with four cocks covered over from the weather , at which the old men got their water , and very generally performed their morning toilet . It was [a quiet , sombre place , shaded over by the trees of [[the warden]318-the warden 's garden]3011-the warden 's garden]3009-a quiet , sombre place , shaded over by the trees of the warden 's garden . On the side towards [the river]396-the river , there stood a row of stone seats , on which [the old men]314-the old men would sit and gaze at the little fish , as [they]314-the old men flitted by in the running stream . On [the other side of [the river]396-the river]3014-the other side of the river was [a rich , green meadow]3016-a rich , green meadow , running up to and joining [the deanery]3017-the deanery , and as little open to [the public]2937-the public , as [the garden of [the dean]3020-the dean itself]3019-the garden of the dean itself . Nothing , therefore , could be more private than [the quad of [the hospital]364-the hospital]3021-the quad of the hospital ; and it was there that [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon determined to convey to [them]314-the old men [his]382-the archdeacon sense of [their]314-the old men refractory proceedings . [The servant]3024-the servant soon brought in word that [the men]378-the men were assembled in [the quad]953-the quad , and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , big with [his]382-the archdeacon purpose , rose to address [them]378-the men . "[0-i] Well , [warden]304-warden , of course [you]304-warden 're coming , " said [he]382-the archdeacon , seeing that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding did not prepare to follow [him]382-the archdeacon . "[304-warden] [I]0-i wish [you]955-you 'd excuse [me]0-i , " said [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . "[955-you] For heaven 's sake , do n't let [us]956-us have division in [the camp]505-the camp , " replied [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon : "[956-us] let [us]956-us have a long pull and a strong pull , but above all a pull altogether ; come , [warden]304-warden , come ; do n't be afraid of [your]304-warden duty . " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was afraid ; [he]102-mr. harding was afraid that [he]102-mr. harding was being led to do that which was not [his]102-mr. harding duty : [he]102-mr. harding was not , however , strong enough to resist , so [he]102-mr. harding got up and followed [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law . [The old men]314-the old men were assembled in groups in [the quadrangle]3031-the quadrangle — eleven of [them]314-the old men at least , for poor old [Johnny Bell]124-johnny bell was bed - ridden , and could n't come ; [he]3032-his had , however , put [his]3032-his mark to the petition , as [one of [[Handy]119-handy 's earliest followers]3034-handy 's earliest followers]3033-one of handy 's earliest followers . ' T is true [he]3032-his could not move from the bed where [he]3032-his lay ; ' t is true [he]3032-his had [no friend]3035-no friend on [earth]2752-earth , but those whom [the hospital]364-the hospital contained ; and of those [the warden]318-the warden and [[his]3032-his daughter]280-his daughter were the most constant and most appreciated ; ' t is true that every thing was administered to [him]3032-his which [his]3032-his failing body could require , or which [his]3032-his faint appetite could enjoy ; but still [his]3032-his dull eye had glistened for a moment at the idea of possessing a hundred pounds a year ' to [his]3032-his own cheek , ' as [Abel Handy]119-handy had eloquently expressed it ; and poor old [Johnny Bell]124-johnny bell had greedily put [his]3032-his mark to the petition . When [the two clergymen]3040-the two clergymen appeared , [they]3040-the two clergymen all uncovered [their]3040-the two clergymen heads . [Handy]119-handy was slow to do it , and hesitated ; but the black coat and waistcoat , of which [he]119-handy had spoken so irreverently in [[Skulpit]141-skulpit 's room]2876-skulpit 's room , had its effect even on [him]119-handy , and [he]119-handy too doffed [his]119-handy hat . [Bunce]136-bunce , advancing before [the others]3042-the others , bowed lowly to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , and with affectionate reverence expressed [his]0-i wish , that [the warden]318-the warden and [Miss Eleanor]158-eleanor were quite well ; "[613-the doctor] and [[the doctor]613-the doctor 's lady]960-the doctor 's lady , " [he]0-i added , turning to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , "[613-the doctor] and [the children]961-the children at [Plumstead]20-plumstead , and [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord ; " and having made [his]0-i speech , [he]0-i also retired among [the others]3042-the others , and took [his]0-i place with the rest upon the stone benches . As [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon stood up to make [his]0-i speech , erect in the middle of [that little square]3048-that little square , [he]0-i looked like [an ecclesiastical statue placed there]3049-an ecclesiastical statue placed there , as a fitting impersonation of [the church militant]802-the church militant [here on earth]3051-here on earth ; [his]0-i shovel hat , large , new , and well - pronounced , [a churchman]739-a churchman 's hat in every inch , declared the profession as plainly as does [the Quaker]3053-the quaker 's broad brim ; [his]0-i heavy eyebrow , large open eyes , and full mouth and chin expressed the solidity of [his]0-i order ; the broad chest , amply covered with fine cloth , told how well to do was [its]0-i estate ; one hand ensconced within [his]0-i pocket , evinced the practical hold which [[our]3054-our mother]3055-our mother church keeps on [her]3055-our mother temporal possessions ; and the other , loose for action , was ready to fight if need be in [her]3055-our mother defence ; and below these the decorous breeches , and neat black gaiters showing so admirably that well - turned leg , betokened the decency , the outward beauty , and grace of [[our]3054-our church establishment]3056-our church establishment . "[962-my lord] Now [[my]0-i men]963-my men , " [he]0-i began , when [he]0-i had settled [himself]0-i well in [his]0-i position ; "[962-my lord] [I]0-i want to say a few words to [you]963-my men . [[Your]963-my men good friend]964-your good friend , [the warden here]965-the warden here , and [myself]0-i , and [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord [the bishop]260-the bishop , on whose behalf [I]0-i wish to speak to [you]963-my men , would all be very sorry , very sorry indeed , that [you]963-my men should have any just ground of complaint . Any just ground of complaint on [your]963-my men part would be removed at once by [the warden]318-the warden , or by [[his]318-the warden lordship]2863-his lordship , or by [me]0-i on [his]318-the warden behalf , without the necessity of any petition on [your]963-my men part . " Here [the orator]2904-the orator stopped for a moment , expecting that some little murmurs of applause would show that [the weakest of [the men]378-the men]3058-the weakest of the men were beginning to give way ; but no such murmurs came . [Bunce]136-bunce , [himself]136-bunce , even sat with closed lips , mute and unsatisfactory . "[0-i] Without the necessity of any petition at all , " [he]0-i repeated . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm told [you]963-my men have addressed a petition to [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord . " [He]0-i paused for a reply from [the men]378-the men , and after a while , [Handy]119-handy plucked up courage , and said , "[971-we] Yes , [we]971-we has . " "[971-we] [You]963-my men have addressed a petition to [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord , in which , as [I]0-i am informed , [you]963-my men express an opinion that [you]963-my men do not receive from [Hiram]107-john hiram 's estate all that is [your]963-my men due . " Here [most of [the men]378-the men]3061-most of the men expressed [their]3061-most of the men assent . "[963-my men] Now what is it [you]963-my men ask for ? what is it [you]963-my men want that [you]963-my men hav'n't got [here]904-here ? what is it — " "[963-my men] A hundred a year , " muttered [old Moody]143-moody , with a voice as if it came out of the ground . "[963-my men] A hundred a year ! " ejaculated [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon militant , defying the impudence of [these claimants]3064-these claimants with one hand stretched out and closed , while with the other [he]143-moody tightly grasped , and secured within [his]143-moody breeches pocket , that symbol of [the church]454-the church 's wealth which [his]143-moody own loose half - crowns not unaptly represented . "[963-my men] A hundred a year ! Why , [[my]0-i men]963-my men , [you]963-my men must be mad ; and [you]963-my men talk about [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's will ! When [John Hiram]107-john hiram built [a hospital]2922-a hospital for [worn - out old men]976-worn - out old men , [worn - out old labouring men]977-worn - out old labouring men , [infirm old men]978-infirm old men past [their]978-infirm old men work , cripples , blind , bed - ridden , and such like , do [you]963-my men think [he]107-john hiram meant to make [gentlemen of [them]978-infirm old men]979-gentlemen of them ? Do [you]963-my men think [John Hiram]107-john hiram intended to give a hundred a year to [old single men , who earned perhaps two shillings or half - a - crown a day for [themselves]980-old single men , who earned perhaps two shillings or half - a - crown a day for themselves and families in the best of their time and [families]981-families in the best of [their]980-old single men , who earned perhaps two shillings or half - a - crown a day for themselves and families in the best of their time time]980-old single men , who earned perhaps two shillings or half - a - crown a day for themselves and families in the best of their time ? No , [[my]0-i men]963-my men , [I]0-i 'll tell [you]963-my men what [John Hiram]107-john hiram meant ; [he]107-john hiram meant that [twelve poor old worn - out labourers , men who could no longer support [themselves]983-twelve poor old worn - out labourers , men who could no longer support themselves , who had no friends to support them , who must starve and perish miserably if not protected by the hand of charity , who had [no friends]984-no friends to support [them]983-twelve poor old worn - out labourers , men who could no longer support themselves , who had no friends to support them , who must starve and perish miserably if not protected by the hand of charity , who must starve and perish miserably if not protected by the hand of charity]983-twelve poor old worn - out labourers , men who could no longer support themselves , who had no friends to support them , who must starve and perish miserably if not protected by the hand of charity ; [he]107-john hiram meant that [twelve such men as these]985-twelve such men as these should come in here in [their]985-twelve such men as these poverty and wretchedness , and find within these walls shelter and food before [their]985-twelve such men as these death , and a little leisure to make [their]985-twelve such men as these peace with [God]159-god . That was what [John Hiram]107-john hiram meant : [you]963-my men have not read [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's will , and [I]0-i doubt whether [those wicked men who are advising [you]963-my men]986-those wicked men who are advising you have done so . [I]0-i have ; [I]0-i know what [his]107-john hiram will was ; and [I]0-i tell [you]963-my men that that was [his]107-john hiram will , and that that was [his]107-john hiram intention . " Not a sound came from [the eleven bedesmen]3066-the eleven bedesmen , as [they]3066-the eleven bedesmen sat listening to what , according to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , was [their]3066-the eleven bedesmen intended estate . [They]3066-the eleven bedesmen grimly stared upon [his]107-john hiram burly figure , but did not then express , by word or sign , the anger and disgust to which such language was sure to give rise . "[0-i] Now let [me]0-i ask [you]963-my men , " [he]107-john hiram continued , "[963-my men] do [you]963-my men think [you]963-my men are worse off than [John Hiram]107-john hiram intended to make [you]963-my men ? Have [you]963-my men not shelter , and food , and leisure ? Have [you]963-my men not much more ? Have [you]963-my men not every indulgence which [you]963-my men are capable of enjoying ? Have [you]963-my men not twice better food , twice a better bed , ten times more money in [your]963-my men pocket than [you]963-my men were ever able to earn for [yourselves]963-my men before [you]963-my men were lucky enough to get into [this place]987-this place ? And now [you]963-my men send a petition to [the bishop]260-the bishop , asking for a hundred pounds a year ! [I]0-i tell [you]963-my men what , [[my]0-i friends]989-my friends ; [you]963-my men are deluded , and made fools of by [wicked men who are acting for [their]990-wicked men who are acting for their own ends own ends]990-wicked men who are acting for their own ends . [You]963-my men will never get a hundred pence a year more than what [you]963-my men have now : it is very possible that [you]963-my men may get less ; it is very possible that [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord [the bishop]260-the bishop , and [[your]963-my men warden]993-your warden may make changes — " "[260-the bishop] No , no , no , " interrupted [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , who had been listening with indescribable misery to the tirade of [[his]0-i son - in - law]440-his son - in - law ; "[260-the bishop] no , [[my]0-i friends]989-my friends . [I]0-i want no changes,—at least no changes that shall make [you]963-my men worse off than [you]963-my men now are , as long as [you]963-my men and [I]0-i live together . " "[0-i] God bless [you]0-i , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , " said [Bunce]136-bunce ; and "[102-mr. harding] God bless [you]0-i , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , God bless [you]0-i sir , [we]995-we know [you]0-i was always [[our]995-we friend]996-our friend , " was exclaimed by [enough of [the men]378-the men]3069-enough of the men to make it appear that the sentiment was general . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon had been interrupted in [his]382-the archdeacon speech before [he]382-the archdeacon had quite finished it ; but [he]382-the archdeacon felt that [he]382-the archdeacon could not recommence with dignity after this little ebullition , and [he]382-the archdeacon led the way back into [the garden]704-the garden , followed by [[his]382-the archdeacon father - in - law]435-his father - in - law . "[0-i] Well , " said [he]382-the archdeacon , as soon as [he]382-the archdeacon found [himself]382-the archdeacon within the cool retreat of [[the warden]318-the warden 's garden]3011-the warden 's garden ; "[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i spoke to [them]997-they plainly . " And [he]382-the archdeacon wiped the perspiration from [his]382-the archdeacon brow ; for making a speech under a broiling mid - day sun in summer , in a full suit of thick black cloth , is warm work . "[0-i] Yes , [you]998-you were plain enough , " replied [the warden]318-the warden , in a tone which did not express approbation . "[998-you] And that 's everything , " said [the other , who was clearly well satisfied with [himself]3077-the other , who was clearly well satisfied with himself]3077-the other , who was clearly well satisfied with himself ; "[0-i] that 's everything : with [those sort of people]999-those sort of people [one]729-one must be plain , or [one]729-one will not be understood . Now , [I]0-i think [they]997-they did understand [me]0-i — [I]0-i think [they]997-they knew what [I]0-i meant . " [The warden]318-the warden agreed . [He]318-the warden certainly thought [they]997-they had understood to the full what had been said to [them]997-they . "[997-they] [They]997-they know pretty well what [they]997-they have to expect from [us]1002-we ; [they]997-they know how [we]1002-we shall meet any refractory spirit on [their]997-they part ; [they]997-they know that [we]1002-we are not afraid of [them]997-they . And now [I]0-i 'll just step into [[Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick 's]1003-chadwick 's , and tell [him]109-mr. chadwick what [I]0-i 've done ; and then [I]0-i 'll go up to [the palace]947-the palace , and answer this petition of [theirs]997-they . " [The warden]318-the warden 's mind was very full — full nearly to overcharging itself ; and had it done so — had [he]318-the warden allowed [himself]318-the warden to speak the thoughts which were working within [him]318-the warden , [he]318-the warden would indeed have astonished [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon by the reprobation [he]318-the warden would have expressed as to the proceeding of which [he]318-the warden had been so unwilling [a witness]3081-a witness . But different feelings kept [him]318-the warden silent ; [he]318-the warden was as yet afraid of differing from [[his]318-the warden son - in - law]440-his son - in - law — [he]318-the warden was anxious beyond measure to avoid even a semblance of rupture with any of [his]318-the warden order , and was painfully fearful of having to come to an open quarrel with [any person on any subject]3083-any person on any subject . [His]318-the warden life had hitherto been so quiet , so free from strife ; [his]318-the warden little early troubles had required nothing but passive fortitude ; [his]318-the warden subsequent prosperity had never forced upon [him]318-the warden any active cares — had never brought [him]318-the warden into disagreeable contact with [any one]431-any one . [He]318-the warden felt that [he]318-the warden would give almost anything — much more than [he]318-the warden knew [he]318-the warden ought to do — to relieve [himself]318-the warden from the storm which [he]318-the warden feared was coming . It was so hard that the pleasant waters of [[his]318-the warden little stream]3085-his little stream should be disturbed and muddied by rough hands ; that [his]318-the warden quiet paths should be made a battle - field ; that [the unobtrusive corner of [the world]325-the world which had been allotted to [him]318-the warden]3086-the unobtrusive corner of the world which had been allotted to him , as though by [Providence]160-providence , should be invaded and desecrated , and all within [it]3086-the unobtrusive corner of the world which had been allotted to him made miserable and unsound . Money [he]318-the warden had none to give ; the knack of putting guineas together had never belonged to [him]318-the warden ; but how willingly , with what a foolish easiness , with what happy alacrity , would [he]318-the warden have abandoned the half of [his]318-the warden income for all time to come , could [he]318-the warden by so doing have quietly dispelled the clouds that were gathering over [him]318-the warden — could [he]318-the warden have thus compromised the matter between [the reformer]2824-the reformer and [the conservative]3089-the conservative , between [[his]318-the warden possible son - in - law]3090-his possible son - in - law , [Bold]122-mr. bold , and [[his]318-the warden positive son - in - law]3091-his positive son - in - law , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . And this compromise would not have been made from any prudential motive of saving what would yet remain , for [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding still felt little doubt but [he]318-the warden should be left for life in quiet possession of the good things [he]318-the warden had , if [he]318-the warden chose to retain them . No ; [he]318-the warden would have done so from the sheer love of quiet , and from a horror of being made the subject of public talk . [He]318-the warden had very often been moved to pity — to that inward weeping of the heart for [others]551-others ' woes ; but none had [he]318-the warden ever pitied more than [that old lord]3094-that old lord , whose almost fabulous wealth , drawn from [his]3094-that old lord church preferments , had become the subject of so much opprobrium , of such public scorn ; [that wretched clerical octogenarian Croesus]3095-that wretched clerical octogenarian croesus , whom [men would not allow to die in peace]3096-men would not allow to die in peace — whom all [the world]325-the world united to decry and to abhor . Was [he]318-the warden to suffer such a fate ? Was [his]318-the warden humble name to be bandied in [men]453-men 's mouths , as [the gormandizer of the resources of the poor]3099-the gormandizer of the resources of the poor , as of one who had filched from the charity of other ages wealth which had been intended to relieve [the old and the infirm]3100-the old and the infirm ? Was [he]318-the warden to be gibbeted in the press , to become a byword for oppression , to be named as an example of the greed of [the English church]786-the english church ? Should it ever be said that [he]318-the warden had robbed [those old men]3102-those old men , whom [he]318-the warden so truly and so tenderly loved in [his]318-the warden heart of hearts ? As [he]318-the warden slowly paced , hour after hour , under those noble lime - trees , turning these sad thoughts within [him]318-the warden , [he]318-the warden became all but fixed in [his]318-the warden resolve that some great step must be taken to relieve [him]318-the warden from the risk of so terrible a fate . In the meanwhile , [the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit , went about [his]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit business . [He]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit said a word or two to [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , and then finding , as [he]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit expected , the petition lying in [[his]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit father]508-his father 's library , [he]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit wrote a short answer to [the men]378-the men , in which [he]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit told [them]378-the men that [they]378-the men had no evils to redress , but rather great mercies for which to be thankful ; and having seen [the bishop]260-the bishop sign it , [he]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit got into [[his]3103-the archdeacon , with contented mind and unruffled spirit brougham]3107-his brougham and returned [home]3108-home to [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly , and [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi . After much painful doubting , on one thing only could [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding resolve . [He]102-mr. harding determined that at any rate [he]102-mr. harding would take no offence , and that [he]102-mr. harding would make this question no cause of quarrel either with [Bold]122-mr. bold or with [the bedesmen]353-the bedesmen . In furtherance of this resolution , [he]102-mr. harding [himself]102-mr. harding wrote a note to [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold , the same afternoon , inviting [him]122-mr. bold to meet [a few friends and hear some music on an evening named in the next week]3110-a few friends and hear some music on an evening named in the next week . Had not this little party been promised to [Eleanor]158-eleanor , in [his]122-mr. bold present state of mind [he]122-mr. bold would probably have avoided such gaiety ; but the promise had been given , the invitations were to be written , and when [Eleanor]158-eleanor consulted [[her]158-eleanor father]293-her father on the subject , [she]158-eleanor was not ill pleased to hear [him]0-i say , "[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i was thinking of [Bold]122-mr. bold , so [I]0-i took it into [my]0-i head to write to [him]122-mr. bold [myself]0-i , but [you]1005-you must write to [[his]122-mr. bold sister]536-his sister . " [Mary Bold]162-mary was older than [[her]162-mary brother]528-her brother , and , at the time of [our]3113-our story , was just over thirty . [She]162-mary was not [an unattractive young woman]3114-an unattractive young woman , though by no means beautiful . [Her]162-mary great merit was the kindliness of [her]162-mary disposition . [She]162-mary was not very clever , nor very animated , nor had [she]162-mary apparently the energy of [[her]162-mary brother]528-her brother ; but [she]162-mary was guided by a high principle of right and wrong ; [her]162-mary temper was sweet , and [her]162-mary faults were fewer in number than [her]162-mary virtues . [Those who casually met [Mary Bold]162-mary]3116-those who casually met mary bold thought little of [her]162-mary ; but those who knew [her]162-mary well loved [her]162-mary well , and the longer [they]3116-those who casually met mary bold knew [her]162-mary the more [they]3116-those who casually met mary bold loved [her]162-mary . Among those who were fondest of [her]162-mary was [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor , and though [Eleanor]104-eleanor had never openly talked to [her]104-eleanor of [[her]104-eleanor brother]528-her brother , [each]3118-each understood [the other]762-the other 's feelings about [him]528-her brother . [The brother]3120-the brother and [sister]3121-sister were sitting together when the two notes were brought in . "[1005-you] How odd , " said [Mary]162-mary , "[1005-you] that [they]1007-they should send two notes . Well , if [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding becomes fashionable , [the world]325-the world is going to change . " [[Her]162-mary brother]528-her brother understood immediately the nature and intention of the peace offering ; but it was not so easy for [him]528-her brother to behave well in the matter , as it was for [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . It is much less difficult for [the sufferer]3123-the sufferer to be generous than for [the oppressor]3124-the oppressor . [John Bold]121-bold felt that [he]121-bold could not go to [[the warden]318-the warden 's party]3126-the warden 's party : [he]121-bold never loved [Eleanor]104-eleanor better than [he]121-bold did now ; [he]121-bold had never so strongly felt how anxious [he]121-bold was to make [her]104-eleanor [[his]121-bold wife]607-his wife as now , when so many obstacles to [his]121-bold doing so appeared in view . Yet here was [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father [himself]293-her father , as it were clearing away those very obstacles , and still [he]293-her father felt that [he]293-her father could not go to [the house]374-the house any more as [an open friend]3130-an open friend . As [he]293-her father sat thinking of these things with the note in [his]293-her father hand , [[his]293-her father sister]536-his sister was waiting for [his]293-her father decision . "[1005-you] Well , " said [she]536-his sister , "[1005-you] [I]0-i suppose [we]1009-we must write separate answers , and both say [we]1009-we shall be very happy . " "[0-i] [You]0-i 'll go , of course , [Mary]162-mary , " said [he]293-her father ; to which [she]536-his sister readily assented . "[162-mary] [I]0-i can not , " [he]293-her father continued , looking serious and gloomy ; "[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could , with all [my]0-i heart . " "[0-i] And why not , [John]121-bold ? " said [she]536-his sister . [She]536-his sister had as yet heard nothing of the new - found abuse which [[her]536-his sister brother]528-her brother was about to reform ; at least , nothing which connected it with [[her]536-his sister brother]528-her brother 's name . [He]293-her father sat thinking for awhile till [he]293-her father determined that it would be best to tell [her]536-his sister at once what it was that [he]293-her father was about : it must be done sooner or later . "[121-bold] [I]0-i fear [I]0-i can not go to [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's house]408-mr. harding 's house any more as [a friend]1011-a friend , just at present . " "[102-mr. harding] Oh , [John]121-bold ! Why not ? Ah , [you]121-bold 've quarrelled with [Eleanor]104-eleanor ! " "[121-bold] No , indeed , " said [he]293-her father ; "[121-bold] [I]0-i 've no quarrel with [her]104-eleanor as yet . " "[104-eleanor] What is it , [John]121-bold ? " said [she]536-his sister , looking at [him]121-bold with an anxious , loving face ; for [she]536-his sister knew well how much of [his]121-bold heart was there in [that house which [he]121-bold said [he]121-bold could no longer enter]3134-that house which he said he could no longer enter . "[121-bold] Why , " said [he]121-bold at last , "[0-i] [I]0-i 've taken up the case of [these twelve old men of [[Hiram]107-john hiram 's Hospital]21-hiram 's hospital]1012-these twelve old men of hiram 's hospital , and of course that brings [me]0-i into contact with [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . [I]0-i may have to oppose [him]102-mr. harding , interfere with [him]102-mr. harding , perhaps injure [him]102-mr. harding . " [Mary]162-mary looked at [him]121-bold steadily for some time before [she]162-mary committed [herself]162-mary to reply , and then merely asked [him]121-bold what [he]121-bold meant to do for [the old men]314-the old men . "[0-i] Why , it 's a long story , and [I]0-i do n't know that [I]0-i can make [you]1013-you understand it . [John Hiram]107-john hiram made a will , and left [his]107-john hiram property in charity for [certain poor old men]1014-certain poor old men , and the proceeds , instead of going to the benefit of [these men]595-these men , goes chiefly into the pocket of [the warden]318-the warden , and [[the bishop]260-the bishop 's steward]334-the bishop 's steward . " "[1013-you] And [you]1013-you mean to take away from [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding [his]102-mr. harding share of it ? " "[1013-you] [I]0-i do n't know what [I]0-i mean yet . [I]0-i mean to inquire about it . [I]0-i mean to see who is entitled to [this property]1019-this property . [I]0-i mean to see , if [I]0-i can , that justice be done to [the poor of [the city of Barchester]1021-the city of barchester]1020-the poor of the city of barchester generally , who are , in fact , [the legatees under the will]1022-the legatees under the will . [I]0-i mean , in short , to put the matter right , if [I]0-i can . " "[0-i] And why are [you]1013-you to do this , [John]107-john hiram ? " "[1013-you] [You]1013-you might ask the same question of [anybody else]1023-anybody else , " said [he]107-john hiram ; "[1013-you] and according to that , the duty of righting [these poor men]1024-these poor men would belong to [nobody]1025-nobody . If [we]1026-we are to act on that principle , [the weak]1027-the weak are never to be protected , injustice is never to be opposed , and [no one]283-no one is to struggle for [the poor]1029-the poor ! " And [Bold]121-bold began to comfort [himself]121-bold in the warmth of [his]121-bold own virtue . "[283-no one] But is there [no one]283-no one to do this but [you]1013-you , who have known [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding so long ? Surely , [John]121-bold , as [a friend]1011-a friend , as [a young friend]1032-a young friend , so much younger than [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding — " "[102-mr. harding] That 's [woman]1033-woman 's logic , all over , [Mary]162-mary . What has age to do with it ? [Another man]2751-another man might plead that [he]2751-another man was too old ; and as to [his]2751-another man friendship , if the thing itself be right , private motives should never be allowed to interfere . Because [I]0-i esteem [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , is that a reason that [I]0-i should neglect a duty which [I]0-i owe to [these old men]2847-these old men ? or should [I]0-i give up a work which [my]0-i conscience tells [me]0-i is a good one , because [I]0-i regret the loss of [his]2751-another man society ? " "[104-eleanor] And [Eleanor]104-eleanor , [John]121-bold ? " said [the sister]3136-the sister , looking timidly into [[her]3136-the sister brother]528-her brother 's face . " [And Bold]121-bold consoled [himself]0-i with the consolation of [a Roman]3138-a roman . [Mary]162-mary sat silent for awhile , till at last [[her]162-mary brother]528-her brother reminded [her]162-mary that the notes must be answered , and [she]162-mary got up , and placed [her]162-mary desk before [her]162-mary , took out [her]162-mary pen and [her]162-mary paper , wrote on it slowly , — "[163-pakenham villas] [Pakenham Villas]163-pakenham villas , Tuesday morning . " And [she]104-eleanor came and knelt before [him]121-bold on the rug . "[121-bold] Pray give it up . " "[162-mary] [You]162-mary do n't understand it , [[my]0-i dear girl]1045-my dear girl , " said [he]0-i , smoothing [her]162-mary hair with [his]0-i hand . [I]0-i know well that no duty can require [you]121-bold to do this mad — this suicidal thing . If there was a plain , a positive duty before [you]121-bold , [I]0-i would be the last to bid [you]121-bold neglect it for [any woman]1046-any woman 's love ; but this — oh , think again , before [you]121-bold do anything to make it necessary that [you]121-bold and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding should be at variance . " [He]102-mr. harding did not answer , as [she]104-eleanor knelt there , leaning on [his]102-mr. harding knees , but by [his]102-mr. harding face [she]104-eleanor thought that [he]102-mr. harding was inclined to yield . " And [she]104-eleanor got up , hoping to conclude [her]104-eleanor note in the way [she]104-eleanor desired . "[0-i] [My]0-i mind is not in doubt , " at last [he]0-i said , rising ; "[0-i] [I]0-i could never respect [myself]0-i again , were [I]0-i to give way now , because [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor is beautiful . [I]0-i do love [her]104-eleanor : [I]0-i would give a hand to hear [her]104-eleanor tell [me]0-i what [you]121-bold have said , speaking on [her]104-eleanor behalf ; but [I]0-i can not for [her]104-eleanor sake go back from the task which [I]0-i have commenced . [I]0-i hope [she]104-eleanor may hereafter acknowledge and respect [my]0-i motives , but [I]0-i can not now go as a guest to [[[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father 's house]1050-her father 's house . " And [the Barchester Brutus]166-the barchester brutus went out to fortify [his]166-the barchester brutus own resolution by meditations on [his]166-the barchester brutus own virtue . [Poor Mary Bold]162-mary sat down , and sadly finished [her]162-mary note , saying that [she]162-mary would [herself]162-mary attend the party , but that [[her]162-mary brother]528-her brother was unavoidably prevented from doing so . [I]168-david fear that [she]162-mary did not admire as [she]162-mary should have done the self - devotion of [his]528-her brother singular virtue . The party went off as such parties do : there were [fat old ladies , in fine silk dresses]3143-fat old ladies , in fine silk dresses , and [slim young ladies]3144-slim young ladies , in gauzy muslin frocks ; [old gentlemen]3145-old gentlemen stood up with [their]3145-old gentlemen backs to the empty fire - place , looking by no means so comfortable as [they]3145-old gentlemen would have done in [their]3145-old gentlemen own armchairs at [home]3108-home ; and [young gentlemen , rather stiff about the neck]3147-young gentlemen , rather stiff about the neck , clustered near the door , not as yet sufficiently in courage to attack the muslin frocks , who awaited the battle , drawn up in a semicircular array . [The warden]318-the warden endeavoured to induce a charge , but failed signally , not having the tact of [a general]3149-a general : [[his]318-the warden daughter]280-his daughter did what [she]280-his daughter could to comfort [the forces under [her]280-his daughter command]3151-the forces under her command , who took in refreshing rations of cake and tea , and patiently looked for the coming engagement : but [she]280-his daughter [herself]280-his daughter , [Eleanor]104-eleanor , had no spirit for the work ; [the only enemy whose lance [she]280-his daughter cared to encounter]3152-the only enemy whose lance she cared to encounter was not there , and [she]280-his daughter and [others]551-others were somewhat dull . Loud above all voices was heard the clear sonorous tones of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon as [he]382-the archdeacon dilated to brother parsons of the danger of [the church]454-the church , of the fearful rumours of mad reforms even at [Oxford]17-oxford , and of the damnable heresies of [Dr. Whiston]115-dr. whiston . Soon , however , sweeter sounds began timidly to make themselves audible . Little movements were made in a quarter , notable for round stools and music stands . Wax candles were arranged in sconces , big books were brought from hidden recesses , and the work of the evening commenced . How often were those pegs twisted and retwisted before [[our]3156-our friend]996-our friend found that [he]996-our friend had twisted them enough ; how many discordant scrapes gave promise of the coming harmony ! How much the muslin fluttered and crumpled before [Eleanor]104-eleanor and [another nymph]3158-another nymph were duly seated at the piano ; how closely did that tall [Apollo]167-apollo pack [himself]167-apollo against the wall , with [his]167-apollo flute , long as [himself]167-apollo , extending high over the heads of [[his]167-apollo pretty neighbours]3159-his pretty neighbours ; into how small a corner crept that round and florid little minor canon , and there with skill amazing found room to tune [his]167-apollo accustomed fiddle ! And now the crash begins : away [they]3160-they go in full flow of harmony together — up hill and [down dale]3161-down dale — now louder and louder , then lower and lower : now loud , as though stirring the battle ; then low , as though mourning [the slain]3162-the slain . In all , through all , and above all , is heard the violoncello . Ah , not for nothing were those pegs so twisted and retwisted — listen , listen ! Now alone that saddest of instruments tells its touching tale . Silent , and in awe , stand fiddle , flute , and piano , to hear the sorrows of [[their]3160-they wailing brother]3163-their wailing brother . ' Tis but for a moment : before the melancholy of those low notes has been fully realised , again comes the full force of all [the band]3164-the band — down go the pedals , away rush twenty fingers scouring over the bass notes with all the impetus of passion . [Apollo]167-apollo blows till [his]167-apollo stiff neckcloth is no better than a rope , and the minor canon works both arms till [he]167-apollo falls in a syncope of exhaustion against the wall . How comes it that now , when all should be silent , when courtesy , if not taste , should make [men]453-men listen , — how is it at this moment [the black - coated corps]3166-the black - coated corps leave [their]3166-the black - coated corps retreat and begin skirmishing ? One by one [they]3166-the black - coated corps creep forth , and fire off little guns timidly , and without precision . Ah , [[my]168-david men]963-my men , efforts such as these will take [no cities]3168-no cities , even though the enemy should be never so open to assault . At length a more deadly artillery is brought to bear ; slowly , but with effect , the advance is made ; the muslin ranks are broken , and fall into confusion ; the formidable array of chairs gives way ; the battle is no longer between [opposing regiments]3169-opposing regiments , but hand to hand , and foot to foot with [single combatants]3170-single combatants , as in the glorious days of old , when fighting was really noble . In corners , and under the shadow of curtains , behind sofas and half hidden by doors , in retiring windows , and sheltered by hanging tapestry , are blows given and returned , fatal , incurable , dealing death . Apart from this another combat arises , more sober and more serious . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon is engaged against [two prebendaries]3172-two prebendaries , [a pursy full - blown rector]3173-a pursy full - blown rector assisting [him]382-the archdeacon , in all the perils and all the enjoyments of short whist . With solemn energy do [they]3166-the black - coated corps watch the shuffled pack , and , all - expectant , eye the coming trump . With what anxious nicety do [they]3166-the black - coated corps arrange [their]3166-the black - coated corps cards , jealous of each other 's eyes ! Why is [that lean doctor]3174-that lean doctor so slow — [cadaverous man with hollow jaw and sunken eye]3175-cadaverous man with hollow jaw and sunken eye , ill beseeming the richness of [[his]3174-that lean doctor mother church]3176-his mother church ! Ah , why so slow , [[thou]3174-that lean doctor [meagre doctor]3178-meagre doctor]3177-thou meagre doctor ? See how [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , speechless in [his]382-the archdeacon agony , deposits on the board [his]382-the archdeacon cards , and looks to heaven or to the ceiling for support . Hark , how [he]382-the archdeacon sighs , as with thumbs in [his]382-the archdeacon waistcoat pocket [he]382-the archdeacon seems to signify that the end of such torment is not yet even nigh at hand ! Vain is the hope , if hope there be , to disturb [that meagre doctor]3180-that meagre doctor . With care precise [he]382-the archdeacon places every card , weighs well the value of [each mighty ace]3181-each mighty ace , [each guarded king]3182-each guarded king , and [comfort - giving queen]3183-comfort - giving queen ; speculates on knave and ten , counts all [his]382-the archdeacon suits , and sets [his]382-the archdeacon price upon the whole . At length a card is led , and [quick three others fall upon the board]3184-quick three others fall upon the board . [The little doctor]3185-the little doctor leads again , while with lustrous eye [[his]3185-the little doctor partner]3186-his partner absorbs the trick . Now thrice has this been done — thrice has constant fortune favoured [the brace of [prebendaries]3188-prebendaries]3187-the brace of prebendaries , ere [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon rouses [himself]382-the archdeacon to the battle : but at the fourth assault [he]382-the archdeacon pins to [the earth]3190-the earth [a prostrate king]3191-a prostrate king , laying low [his]382-the archdeacon crown and sceptre , bushy beard , and lowering brow , with a poor deuce . "[168-david] As [David]168-david did [Goliath]28-goliath , " says [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , pushing over the four cards to [[his]382-the archdeacon partner]3186-his partner . And then a trump is led , then another trump ; then [a king]3194-a king — and then an ace — and then a long ten , which brings down from [the meagre doctor]3195-the meagre doctor [his]382-the archdeacon only remaining tower of strength — [his]382-the archdeacon cherished queen of trumps . "[168-david] What , no second club ? " says [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon to [[his]382-the archdeacon partner]3186-his partner . "[2730-papa] Only one club , " mutters from [his]382-the archdeacon inmost stomach [the pursy rector , who sits there red - faced , silent , impervious , careful , [a safe but not a brilliant ally]3199-a safe but not a brilliant ally]3198-the pursy rector , who sits there red - faced , silent , impervious , careful , a safe but not a brilliant ally . But [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon cares not for many clubs , or for none . [He]382-the archdeacon dashes out [his]382-the archdeacon remaining cards with a speed most annoying to [[his]382-the archdeacon antagonists]3201-his antagonists , pushes over to [them]3201-his antagonists some four cards as [their]3201-his antagonists allotted portion , shoves the remainder across the table to [the red - faced rector]3202-the red - faced rector : calls out "[2730-papa] two by cards and two by honours , and the odd trick last time , " marks a treble under the candle - stick , and has dealt round the second pack before [the meagre doctor]3195-the meagre doctor has calculated [his]382-the archdeacon losses . And so went off [the warden]318-the warden 's party , and [men]453-men and [women arranging shawls and shoes]3206-women arranging shawls and shoes declared how pleasant it had been ; and [Mrs. Goodenough]169-mrs. goodenough , [[the red - faced rector]3202-the red - faced rector 's wife]3208-the red - faced rector 's wife , pressing [the warden]318-the warden 's hand , declared [she]169-mrs. goodenough had never enjoyed [herself]169-mrs. goodenough better ; which showed how little pleasure [she]169-mrs. goodenough allowed [herself]169-mrs. goodenough in [this world]2844-this world , as [she]169-mrs. goodenough had sat the whole evening through in the same chair without occupation , not speaking , and unspoken to . And [Matilda Johnson]170-matilda johnson , when [she]170-matilda johnson allowed [young Dickson of [the bank]3212-the bank]3211-young dickson of the bank to fasten [her]170-matilda johnson cloak round [her]170-matilda johnson neck , thought that two hundred pounds a year and a little cottage would really do for happiness ; besides [he]3211-young dickson of the bank was sure to be manager some day . And [Apollo]167-apollo folding [his]167-apollo flute into [his]167-apollo pocket , felt that [he]167-apollo had acquitted [himself]167-apollo with honour ; and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon pleasantly gingled [his]382-the archdeacon gains ; but [the meagre doctor]3195-the meagre doctor went off without much audible speech , muttering ever and anon as [he]3195-the meagre doctor went "[2730-papa] three and thirty points , " "[2730-papa] three and thirty points ! " And so [they]3215-they all were gone , and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was left alone with [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter . What had passed between [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor and [Mary Bold]162-mary need not be told . It is indeed a matter of thankfulness that neither [the historian]3217-the historian nor [the novelist]3218-the novelist hears all that is said by [[their]3215-they heroes]3219-their heroes or [heroines]3220-heroines , or how would three volumes or twenty suffice ! In the present case so little of this sort have [I]2730-papa overheard , that [I]2730-papa live in hopes of finishing [my]2730-papa work within 300 pages , and of completing that pleasant task — a novel in one volume ; but something had passed between [them]3215-they , and as [the warden]318-the warden blew out the wax candles , and put [his]318-the warden instrument into its case , [[his]318-the warden daughter]280-his daughter stood sad and thoughtful by the empty fireplace , determined to speak to [[her]280-his daughter father]293-her father , but irresolute as to what [she]280-his daughter would say . "[2730-papa] Well , [Eleanor]104-eleanor , " said [he]318-the warden , "[2730-papa] are [you]104-eleanor for bed ? " "[104-eleanor] Yes , " said [she]104-eleanor , moving , "[104-eleanor] [I]0-i suppose so ; but , [papa]2730-papa — [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold was not here to - night : do [you]2730-papa know why not ? " "[104-eleanor] Well , [Eleanor]104-eleanor , [I]0-i could guess ; but it 's no use guessing at such things , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear . What makes [you]104-eleanor look so earnest about it ? " "[2730-papa] Oh [papa]2730-papa , do tell [me]0-i , " [she]104-eleanor exclaimed , throwing [her]104-eleanor arms round [him]2730-papa , and looking into [his]2730-papa face ; "[2730-papa] what is it [he]122-mr. bold is going to do ? What is it all about ? Is there any — any — any — " [she]104-eleanor did n't well know what word to use—"any[2730-papa] danger ? " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was not [the man to judge harshly of [any one]431-any one , much less of [the daughter whom [he]2730-papa now loved better than [any living creature]3228-any living creature]3227-the daughter whom he now loved better than any living creature]3225-the man to judge harshly of any one , much less of the daughter whom he now loved better than any living creature ; but still [he]2730-papa did judge [her]104-eleanor wrongly at this moment . [He]2730-papa knew that [she]104-eleanor loved [John Bold]121-bold ; [he]2730-papa fully sympathised in [her]104-eleanor affection ; day after day [he]2730-papa thought more of the matter , and , with the tender care of [a loving father]3229-a loving father , tried to arrange in [his]2730-papa own mind how matters might be so managed that [[his]2730-papa daughter]280-his daughter 's heart should not be made the sacrifice to the dispute which was likely to exist between [him]2730-papa and [Bold]121-bold . Now , when [she]104-eleanor spoke to [him]2730-papa for the first time on the subject , it was natural that [he]2730-papa should think more of [her]104-eleanor than of [himself]2730-papa , and that [he]2730-papa should imagine that [her]104-eleanor own cares , and not [his]2730-papa , were troubling [her]104-eleanor . [He]2730-papa stood silent before [her]104-eleanor awhile , as [she]104-eleanor gazed up into [his]2730-papa face , and then kissing [her]104-eleanor forehead [he]2730-papa placed [her]104-eleanor on the sofa . "[0-i] Tell [me]0-i , [Nelly]104-eleanor , " [he]2730-papa said ( [he]2730-papa only called [her]104-eleanor [Nelly]104-eleanor in [his]2730-papa kindest , softest , sweetest moods , and yet all [his]2730-papa moods were kind and sweet ) , "[104-eleanor] tell [me]0-i , [Nelly]104-eleanor , do [you]104-eleanor like [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold — much ? " [She]104-eleanor was quite taken aback by the question . [I]122-mr. bold will not say that [she]104-eleanor had forgotten [herself]104-eleanor , and [her]104-eleanor own love in thinking about [John Bold]121-bold , and while conversing with [Mary]162-mary : [she]104-eleanor certainly had not done so . [She]104-eleanor had been sick at heart to think , that [a man of whom [she]104-eleanor could not but own to [herself]104-eleanor]3231-a man of whom she could not but own to herself that [she]104-eleanor loved [him]121-bold , of whose regard [she]104-eleanor had been so proud , that [such a man]637-such a man should turn against [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father to ruin [him]121-bold . [She]104-eleanor had felt [her]104-eleanor vanity hurt , that [his]121-bold affection for [her]104-eleanor had not kept [him]121-bold from such a course ; had [he]121-bold really cared for [her]104-eleanor , [he]121-bold would not have risked [her]104-eleanor love by such an outrage ; but [her]104-eleanor main fear had been for [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father , and when [she]104-eleanor spoke of danger , it was of danger to [him]121-bold and not to [herself]104-eleanor . [She]104-eleanor was taken aback by the question altogether : "[122-mr. bold] Do [I]0-i like [him]1057-him , [papa]2730-papa ? " "[2730-papa] Yes , [Nelly]104-eleanor , do [you]104-eleanor like [him]1057-him ? Why should n't [you]104-eleanor like [him]1057-him ; but that 's a poor word — do [you]104-eleanor love [him]1057-him ? " [She]104-eleanor sat still in [his]121-bold arms without answering [him]121-bold . [She]104-eleanor certainly had not prepared [herself]104-eleanor for an avowal of affection , intending , as [she]104-eleanor had done , to abuse [John Bold]121-bold [herself]104-eleanor , and to hear [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father do so also . "[104-eleanor] Come , [[my]0-i love]1059-my love , " said [he]121-bold , "[1059-my love] let [us]1060-us make a clean breast of it : do [you]1059-my love tell [me]0-i what concerns [yourself]1059-my love , and [I]0-i will tell [you]1059-my love what concerns [me]0-i and [the hospital]364-the hospital . " And then , without waiting for an answer , [he]121-bold described to [her]1059-my love , as [he]121-bold best could , the accusation that was made about [Hiram]107-john hiram 's will , the clains which [the old men]314-the old men put forward ; what [he]121-bold considered the strength and what the weakness of [his]121-bold own position ; the course which [Bold]121-bold had taken , and that which [he]121-bold presumed [he]121-bold was about to take ; and then by degrees , without further question , [he]121-bold presumed on the fact of [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's love , and spoke of that love as a feeling which [he]121-bold could in no way disapprove : [he]121-bold apologised for [Bold]121-bold , excused what [he]121-bold was doing ; nay praised [him]121-bold for [his]121-bold energy and intentions : made much of [his]121-bold good qualities , and harped on none of [his]121-bold foibles ; then , reminding [[his]121-bold daughter]280-his daughter how late it was , and comforting [her]280-his daughter with much assurance which [he]121-bold hardly felt [himself]121-bold , [he]121-bold sent [her]280-his daughter to [[her]280-his daughter room]3238-her room , with flowing eyes and a full heart . When [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding met [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter at breakfast the next morning , there was no further discussion on the matter , nor was the subject mentioned between [them]3240-them for some days . Soon after the party [Mary Bold]162-mary called at [the hospital]364-the hospital , but there were [various persons in [the drawing - room]3243-the drawing - room at the time , and [she]162-mary therefore said nothing about [[her]162-mary brother]528-her brother]3242-various persons in the drawing - room at the time , and she therefore said nothing about her brother . On the day following , [John Bold]121-bold met [Miss Harding]156-miss harding in [one of [the quiet sombre shaded walks of the close]3246-the quiet sombre shaded walks of the close]3245-one of the quiet sombre shaded walks of the close : [he]121-bold was most anxious to see [her]156-miss harding , but unwilling to call at [[the warden]318-the warden 's house]3248-the warden 's house , and had in truth waylaid [her]156-miss harding in [[her]156-miss harding private haunts]3249-her private haunts . "[1062-my sister] [[My]0-i sister]1062-my sister tells [me]0-i , " said [he]121-bold , abruptly hurrying on with [his]121-bold premeditated speech , "[1062-my sister] [[my]0-i sister]1062-my sister tells [me]0-i that [you]1064-you had a delightful party the other evening . [I]0-i was so sorry [I]0-i could not be there . " "[0-i] [We]1065-we were all sorry , " said [Eleanor]104-eleanor , with dignified composure . "[0-i] [I]0-i believe , [Miss Harding]156-miss harding , [you]156-miss harding understood why , at this moment — " [And Bold]121-bold hesitated , muttered , stopped , commenced [his]122-mr. bold explanation again , and again broke down . [Eleanor]104-eleanor would not help [him]122-mr. bold in the least . " "[156-miss harding] Pray do n't apologise , [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold ; [[my]0-i father]942-my father will , [I]0-i am sure , always be glad to see [you]156-miss harding , if [you]156-miss harding like to come to [the house]374-the house now as formerly ; nothing has occurred to alter [his]942-my father feelings ; of [your]156-miss harding own views [you]156-miss harding are , of course , [the best judge]1069-the best judge . " "[2726-your father] [[Your]156-miss harding father]2726-your father is all that is kind and generous ; [he]942-my father always was so , but [you]156-miss harding , [Miss Harding]156-miss harding , [yourself]156-miss harding — [I]0-i hope [you]156-miss harding will not judge [me]0-i harshly , because — " "[156-miss harding] [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold , " said [she]156-miss harding , "[122-mr. bold] [you]122-mr. bold may be sure of one thing ; [I]0-i shall always judge [[my]0-i father]942-my father to be right , and those who oppose [him]942-my father [I]0-i shall judge to be wrong . " And then curtseying low [she]156-miss harding sailed on , leaving [[her]156-miss harding lover]656-her lover in anything but a happy state of mind . Though [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor rode off from [John Bold]121-bold on a high horse , it must not be supposed that [her]104-eleanor heart was so elate as [her]104-eleanor demeanour . In the first place , [she]104-eleanor had a natural repugnance to losing [[her]104-eleanor lover]656-her lover ; and in the next , [she]104-eleanor was not quite so sure that [she]104-eleanor was in the right as [she]104-eleanor pretended to be . [[Her]104-eleanor father]293-her father had told [her]104-eleanor , and that now repeatedly , that [Bold]121-bold was doing nothing unjust or ungenerous , and why then should [she]104-eleanor rebuke [him]121-bold , and throw [him]121-bold off , when [she]104-eleanor felt [herself]104-eleanor so ill able to bear [his]121-bold loss ? — but such is human nature , and [young - lady]3253-young - lady - nature especially . As [she]104-eleanor walked off from [him]121-bold beneath the shady elms of the close , [her]104-eleanor look , [her]104-eleanor tone , every motion and gesture of [her]104-eleanor body , belied [her]104-eleanor heart ; [she]104-eleanor would have given [the world]325-the world to have taken [him]121-bold by the hand , to have reasoned with [him]121-bold , persuaded [him]121-bold , cajoled [him]121-bold , coaxed [him]121-bold out of [his]121-bold project ; to have overcome [him]121-bold with all [her]104-eleanor female artillery , and to have redeemed [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father at the cost of [herself]104-eleanor ; but pride would not let [her]104-eleanor do this , and [she]104-eleanor left [him]121-bold without a look of love or a word of kindness . Had [Bold]121-bold been judging of [another lover]3256-another lover and of [another lady]3257-another lady [he]121-bold might have understood all this as well as [we]3258-we do ; but in matters of love [men]453-men do not see clearly in [their]453-men own affairs . [They]453-men say that faint heart never won [fair lady]3260-fair lady ; and it is amazing to [me]171-the jupiter how [fair ladies]3261-fair ladies are won , so faint are often [men]453-men 's hearts ! Were it not for the kindness of [their]453-men nature , that seeing the weakness of [our]3258-we courage [they]453-men will occasionally descend from [[their]453-men impregnable fortresses]3263-their impregnable fortresses , and [themselves]453-men aid [us]3258-we in effecting [their]453-men own defeat , too often would [they]453-men escape unconquered if not unscathed , and free of body if not of heart . [Poor Bold]162-mary crept off quite crest - fallen ; [he]121-bold felt that as regarded [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor [his]121-bold fate was sealed , unless [he]121-bold could consent to give up a task to which [he]121-bold had pledged [himself]121-bold , and which indeed it would not be easy for [him]121-bold to give up . [Lawyers]3264-lawyers were engaged , and the question had to a certain extent been taken up by [the public]2937-the public ; besides , how could [a high - spirited girl like [Eleanor Harding]104-eleanor]3266-a high - spirited girl like eleanor harding really learn to love [a man]545-a man for neglecting a duty which [he]121-bold assumed ! Could [she]104-eleanor allow [her]104-eleanor affection to be purchased at the cost of [his]121-bold own self - respect ? As regarded the issue of [his]121-bold attempt at reformation in [the hospital]364-the hospital , [Bold]121-bold had no reason hitherto to be discontented with [his]121-bold success . All [Barchester]6-barchester was by the ears about it . [The bishop]260-the bishop , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , [the warden]318-the warden , [the steward]350-the steward , and [several other clerical allies]3273-several other clerical allies , had daily meetings , discussing [their]3273-several other clerical allies tactics , and preparing for the great attack . [Sir Abraham Haphazard]151-sir abraham had been consulted , but [his]151-sir abraham opinion was not yet received : copies of [Hiram]107-john hiram 's will , copies of [warden]304-warden 's journals , copies of leases , copies of accounts , copies of everything that could be copied , and of some that could not , had been sent to [him]151-sir abraham ; and the case was assuming most creditable dimensions . But above all , it had been mentioned in the daily Jupiter . That [all powerful organ of the press in one of its leading thunderbolts launched at [St. Cross]19-st. cross]3275-all powerful organ of the press in one of its leading thunderbolts launched at st. cross , had thus remarked : ' Another case , of smaller dimensions indeed , but of similar import , is now likely to come under public notice . [We]3276-we are informed that [the warden or master of [an old almshouse attached to [Barchester Cathedral]8-barchester cathedral]3278-an old almshouse attached to barchester cathedral]3277-the warden or master of an old almshouse attached to barchester cathedral is in receipt of twenty - five times the annual income appointed for [him]3277-the warden or master of an old almshouse attached to barchester cathedral by the will of [the founder]464-the founder , while the sum yearly expended on the absolute purposes of [the charity]3280-the charity has always remained fixed . In other words , [the legatees under the founder]3281-the legatees under the founder 's will have received no advantage from the increase in the value of the property during the last four centuries , such increase having been absorbed by [the so - called warden]3282-the so - called warden . It is impossible to conceive a case of greater injustice . It is no answer to say that [some six or nine or twelve old men]3283-some six or nine or twelve old men receive as much of the goods of [this world]2844-this world as [such old men]3285-such old men require . On what foundation , moral or divine , traditional or legal , is grounded [the warden]318-the warden 's claim to the large income [he]318-the warden receives for doing nothing ? The contentment of [these almsmen]3287-these almsmen , if content [they]3287-these almsmen be , can give [him]318-the warden no title to this wealth ! Does [he]318-the warden ever ask [himself]318-the warden , when [he]318-the warden stretches wide [his]318-the warden clerical palm to receive the pay of [some dozen of [the working clergy]3289-the working clergy]3288-some dozen of the working clergy , for what service [he]318-the warden is so remunerated ? Does [his]318-the warden conscience ever entertain the question of [his]318-the warden right to such subsidies ? Or is it possible that the subject never so presents itself to [his]318-the warden mind ; that [he]318-the warden has received for many years , and intends , should [God]159-god spare [him]318-the warden , to receive for years to come , these fruits of the industrious piety of past ages , indifferent as to any right on [his]318-the warden own part , or of any injustice to [others]551-others ! [We]3291-we must express an opinion that nowhere but in [the Church of [England]14-england]3292-the church of england , and only there among [its priests]3293-its priests , could such a state of moral indifference be found . ' [I]171-the jupiter must for the present leave [[my]171-the jupiter readers]3294-my readers to imagine the state of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's mind after reading the above article . [They]3294-my readers say that forty thousand copies of the Jupiter are daily sold , and that each copy is read by [five persons at the least]3295-five persons at the least . [Two hundred thousand readers]3296-two hundred thousand readers then would hear this accusation against [him]318-the warden ; two hundred thousand hearts would swell with indignation at the griping injustice , the bare - faced robbery of [the warden of [Barchester Hospital]29-barchester hospital]3297-the warden of barchester hospital ! And how was [he]318-the warden to answer this ? How was [he]318-the warden to open [his]318-the warden inmost heart to [this multitude]3298-this multitude , to [these thousands]3299-these thousands , [the educated]3300-the educated , [the polished]3301-the polished , [the picked men of [[his]318-the warden own country]3303-his own country]3302-the picked men of his own country ; how show [them]3299-these thousands that [he]318-the warden was [no robber]3304-no robber , [no avaricious lazy priest]3305-no avaricious lazy priest scrambling for gold , but [a retiring humble - spirited man who had innocently taken what had innocently been offered to [him]318-the warden]3306-a retiring humble - spirited man who had innocently taken what had innocently been offered to him ? "[171-the jupiter] Write to [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter , " suggested [the bishop]260-the bishop . "[171-the jupiter] Yes , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , more worldly wise than [[his]382-the archdeacon father]508-his father , "[171-the jupiter] yes , and be smothered with ridicule ; tossed over and over again with scorn ; shaken this way and that , as a rat in the mouth of a practised terrier . [You]1074-you will leave out some word or letter in [your]1074-you answer , and the ignorance of [the cathedral clergy]1075-the cathedral clergy will be harped upon ; [you]1074-you will make some small mistake , which will be a falsehood , or some admission , which will be self - condemnation ; [you]1074-you will find [yourself]1074-you to have been vulgar , ill - tempered , irreverend , and illiterate , and the chances are ten to one , but that being [a clergyman]1076-a clergyman [you]1074-you will have been guilty of blasphemy ! [A man]545-a man may have the best of causes , the best of talents , and the best of tempers ; [he]545-a man may write as well as [Addison]172-addison , or as strongly as [Junius]173-junius ; but even with all this [he]545-a man can not successfully answer , when attacked by [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter . In such matters it is omnipotent . What [the Czar]1078-the czar is in [Russia]30-russia , or [the mob in [America]31-america]1079-the mob in america , that [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter is in [England]14-england . Answer such an article ! No , [warden]304-warden ; whatever [you]304-warden do , do n't do that . [We]1081-we were to look for this sort of thing [you]304-warden know ; but [we]1081-we need not draw down on [our]1081-we heads more of it than is necessary . " The article in [the Jupiter]3310-the jupiter , while it so greatly harassed [[our]1081-we poor warden]2911-our poor warden , was an immense triumph to [some of [the opposite party]3313-the opposite party]3312-some of the opposite party . There was no end to the glorious golden dreams which [this leader in the Jupiter]3320-this leader in the jupiter produced in the soaring mind of [Finney]131-finney . [Abel Handy]119-handy limped hither and thither through [the rooms]3323-the rooms , repeating all that [he]119-handy understood to have been printed , with some additions of [his]119-handy own which [he]119-handy thought should have been added . [He]119-handy told [them]3321-the old bedesmen how [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter had declared that [[their]3321-the old bedesmen warden]3324-their warden was no better than [a robber]3325-a robber , and that what [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter said was acknowledged by [the world]325-the world to be true . How [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter had affirmed that [each one of [them]1083-them]3327-each one of them — "[1082-each one of us] [each one of [us]1083-them]1082-each one of us , [Jonathan Crumple]147-jonathan crumple , think of that , " — had a clear right to a hundred a year ; and that if [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter had said so , it was better than a decision of [the Lord Chancellor]3328-the lord chancellor ; and then [he]119-handy carried about the paper , supplied by [Mr. Finney]131-finney , which , though none of [them]1083-them could read it , still afforded in its very touch and aspect positive corroboration of what was told [them]1083-them , and [Jonathan Crumple]147-jonathan crumple pondered deeply over [his]147-jonathan crumple returning wealth ; and [Job Skulpit]141-skulpit saw how right [he]141-skulpit had been in signing the petition , and said so many scores of times ; and [Spriggs]145-spriggs leered fearfully with [his]145-spriggs one eye ; and [Moody]143-moody , as [he]143-moody more nearly approached the coming golden age , hated more deeply than ever [those who still kept possession of what [he]143-moody so coveted]3329-those who still kept possession of what he so coveted . Even [Billy Gazy and poor bedridden Bell]174-billy gazy and poor bedridden bell became active and uneasy , and [the great Bunce]3330-the great bunce stood apart with lowering brow , with deep grief seated in [his]3330-the great bunce heart , for [he]3330-the great bunce perceived that evil days were coming . It had been decided , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon advising , that no remonstrance , explanation , or defence should be addressed from the Barchester conclave to [the Editor of the Jupiter]3332-the editor of the jupiter , but hitherto that was the only decision to which [they]1083-them had come . [Sir Abraham Haphazard]151-sir abraham was deeply engaged in preparing a bill for the mortification of [papists]3333-papists , to be called the "[147-jonathan crumple] Convent Custody Bill , " the purport of which was to enable [any protestant clergyman over fifty years of age]3334-any protestant clergyman over fifty years of age to search [any nun whom [he]151-sir abraham [suspected of being in possession of treasonable papers , or jesuitical symbols]3336-suspected of being in possession of treasonable papers , or jesuitical symbols]3335-any nun whom he suspected of being in possession of treasonable papers , or jesuitical symbols : and as there were to be a hundred and thirty - seven clauses in the bill , each clause containing a separate thorn for the side of [the papist]3337-the papist , and as it was known the bill would be fought inch by inch , by [fifty maddened Irishmen]3338-fifty maddened irishmen , the due construction and adequate dovetailing of it did consume much of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's time . The bill had all its desired effect . Of course it never passed into law ; but it so completely divided the ranks of [the Irish members]3339-the irish members , who had bound [themselves]3339-the irish members together to force on [the ministry]3340-the ministry a bill for compelling [all men]3341-all men to drink Irish whisky , and [all women]3342-all women to wear Irish poplins , that for the remainder of the session [the Great Poplin and Whisky League]3343-the great poplin and whisky league was utterly harmless . Thus it happened that [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's opinion was not at once forthcoming , and the uncertainty , the expectation , and suffering of [the folk of [Barchester]6-barchester]3344-the folk of barchester was maintained at a high pitch . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly felt keenly the injustice of this attack ; but what could [he]106-dr. grantly say ? [He]106-dr. grantly certainly had huffed [John Bold]121-bold ; [he]106-dr. grantly certainly had objected to [him]121-bold as [a brother - in - law]2807-a brother - in - law , and a very few months ago the very idea had excited [his]106-dr. grantly wrath : but now matters were changed ; [John Bold]121-bold had shown [his]121-bold power , and , though [he]121-bold was as odious as ever to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , power is always respected , and [the reverend dignitary]3364-the reverend dignitary began to think that such an alliance might not have been imprudent . Nevertheless , [his]121-bold motto was still "[121-bold] no surrender ; " [he]121-bold would still fight it out ; [he]121-bold still believed confidently in [Oxford]17-oxford , in the bench of [bishops]338-bishops , in [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham Haphazard , and in [himself]121-bold ; and it was only when alone with [[his]121-bold wife]607-his wife that doubts of defeat ever beset [him]121-bold . [He]121-bold once more tried to communicate this confidence to [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly , and for the twentieth time began to tell [her]129-mrs. grantly of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham .
