[I]0-i suppose [he]2730-papa wo n't take the case up for nothing ? " And so [the lady]612-the lady descended to family worship among [[her]612-the lady children]3368-her children and [servants]3369-servants , the pattern of [a good and prudent wife]3370-a good and prudent wife . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly was blessed with [a happy , thriving family]3371-a happy , thriving family . There were , first , [three boys]3372-three boys , now at [home]3108-home from [school]522-school for the holidays . [They]3372-three boys were called , respectively , [Charles James]178-charles james , [Henry]116-henry , and [Samuel]179-samuel . [The two younger ( there were five in all )]3375-the two younger ( there were five in all ) were [girls]3376-girls ; [the elder]3377-the elder , [Florinda]180-florinda , bore the name of [the Archbishop of [York]33-york 's wife]3378-the archbishop of york 's wife , whose godchild [she]3378-the archbishop of york 's wife was ; and [the younger]3379-the younger had been christened [Grizzel]181-grizzel , after [a sister of [the Archbishop of [Canterbury]34-canterbury]3381-the archbishop of canterbury]3380-a sister of the archbishop of canterbury . [The boys]3382-the boys were all clever , and gave good promise of being well able to meet the cares and trials of [the world]325-the world ; and yet [they]3382-the boys were not alike in [their]3382-the boys dispositions , and each had [his]178-charles james individual character , and [each [his]178-charles james separate admirers among [[the doctor]613-the doctor 's friends]3386-the doctor 's friends]3384-each his separate admirers among the doctor 's friends . [Charles James]178-charles james was [an exact and careful boy]3387-an exact and careful boy ; [he]178-charles james never committed [himself]178-charles james ; [he]178-charles james well knew how much was expected from [the eldest son of [the Archdeacon of [Barchester]6-barchester]3389-the archdeacon of barchester]3388-the eldest son of the archdeacon of barchester , and was therefore mindful not to mix too freely with [other boys]3390-other boys . [He]178-charles james had not the great talents of [[his]178-charles james younger brothers]3391-his younger brothers , but [he]178-charles james exceeded [them]3391-his younger brothers in judgment and propriety of demeanour ; [his]178-charles james fault , if [he]178-charles james had one , was an over - attention to words instead of things ; there was a thought too much finesse about [him]178-charles james , and , as even [[his]178-charles james father]508-his father sometimes told [him]178-charles james , [he]178-charles james was too fond of a compromise . [The second]3393-the second was [[the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's favourite son]3395-the archdeacon 's favourite son , and [Henry]116-henry was indeed [a brilliant boy]3396-a brilliant boy . The versatility of [his]116-henry genius was surprising , and [the visitors at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi]3397-the visitors at plumstead episcopi were often amazed at the marvellous manner in which [he]116-henry would , when called on , adapt [his]116-henry capacity to apparently most uncongenial pursuits . [He]116-henry appeared once before a large circle as [Luther]182-luther [the reformer]2824-the reformer , and delighted [them]3397-the visitors at plumstead episcopi with the perfect manner in which [he]116-henry assumed the character ; and within three days [he]116-henry again astonished [them]3397-the visitors at plumstead episcopi by acting the part of [a Capuchin friar to the very life]3399-a capuchin friar to the very life . For this last exploit [[his]116-henry father]508-his father gave [him]116-henry a golden guinea , and [[his]116-henry brothers]3401-his brothers said the reward had been promised beforehand in the event of the performance being successful . [He]116-henry was also sent on a tour into [Devonshire]35-devonshire ; a treat which [the lad]3402-the lad was most anxious of enjoying . [[[His]116-henry father]508-his father 's friends there]3404-his father 's friends there , however , did not appreciate [his]116-henry talents , and sad accounts were sent [home]3108-home of the perversity of [his]116-henry nature . [He]116-henry was [a most courageous lad]3406-a most courageous lad , game to the backbone . It was soon known , both at [home]3108-home , where [he]116-henry lived , and within some miles of [Barchester Cathedral]8-barchester cathedral , and also at [Westminster]36-westminster , where [he]116-henry was at [school]522-school , that [young Henry]116-henry could box well and would never own [himself]116-henry beat ; [other boys]3390-other boys would fight while [they]3390-other boys had a leg to stand on , but [he]116-henry would fight with no leg at all . [Those backing [him]116-henry]3410-those backing him would sometimes think [him]116-henry crushed by the weight of blows and faint with loss of blood , and [[his]116-henry friends]627-his friends would endeavour to withdraw [him]116-henry from the contest ; but no , [Henry]116-henry never gave in , was never weary of the battle . The ring was the only element in which [he]116-henry seemed to enjoy [himself]116-henry ; and while [other boys]3390-other boys were happy in the number of [[their]3390-other boys friends]3413-their friends , [he]116-henry rejoiced most in the multitude of [[his]116-henry foes]3414-his foes . [[His]116-henry relations]3415-his relations could not but admire [his]116-henry pluck , but [they]3415-his relations sometimes were forced to regret that [he]116-henry was inclined to be [a bully]3416-a bully ; and those not so partial to [him]116-henry as [[his]116-henry father]508-his father was , observed with pain that , though [he]116-henry could fawn to [the masters]3418-the masters and [[the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's friends]3420-the archdeacon 's friends , [he]116-henry was imperious and masterful to [the servants]3421-the servants and [the poor]1029-the poor . But perhaps [Samuel]179-samuel was [the general favourite]3423-the general favourite ; and [dear little Soapy]183-dear little soapy , as [he]183-dear little soapy was familiarly called , was as engaging [a child]2748-a child as [ever fond mother]3425-ever fond mother petted . [He]183-dear little soapy was soft and gentle in [his]183-dear little soapy manners , and attractive in [his]183-dear little soapy speech ; the tone of [his]183-dear little soapy voice was melody , and every action was a grace ; unlike [[his]183-dear little soapy brothers]3401-his brothers , [he]183-dear little soapy was courteous to all , [he]183-dear little soapy was affable to the lowly , and meek even to [the very scullery maid]3427-the very scullery maid . [He]183-dear little soapy was [a boy of great promise]3428-a boy of great promise , minding [his]183-dear little soapy books and delighting the hearts of [[his]183-dear little soapy masters]3429-his masters . [[His]183-dear little soapy brothers]3401-his brothers , however , were not particularly fond of [him]183-dear little soapy ; [they]3401-his brothers would complain to [[their]3401-his brothers mother]3431-their mother that [Soapy]183-dear little soapy 's civility all meant something ; [they]3401-his brothers thought that [his]183-dear little soapy voice was too often listened to at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi , and evidently feared that , as [he]183-dear little soapy grew up , [he]183-dear little soapy would have more weight in [the house]374-the house than either of [them]3401-his brothers ; there was , therefore , a sort of agreement among [them]3401-his brothers to put [young Soapy]183-dear little soapy down . This , however , was not so easy to be done ; [Samuel]179-samuel , though young , was sharp ; [he]179-samuel could not assume the stiff decorum of [Charles James]178-charles james , nor could [he]179-samuel fight like [Henry]116-henry ; but [he]179-samuel was [a perfect master of [his]179-samuel own weapons , and contrived , in the teeth of both of [them]3401-his brothers]3433-a perfect master of his own weapons , and contrived , in the teeth of both of them , to hold the place which [he]179-samuel had assumed . [Henry]116-henry declared that [he]179-samuel was [a false , cunning creature]3434-a false , cunning creature ; and [Charles James]178-charles james , though [he]178-charles james always spoke of [him]179-samuel as [[his]178-charles james dear brother]3435-his dear brother [Samuel]179-samuel , was not slow to say a word against [him]179-samuel when opportunity offered . To speak the truth , [Samuel]179-samuel was [a cunning boy]3436-a cunning boy , and those even who loved [him]179-samuel best could not but own that for [one so young]550-one so young , [he]179-samuel was too adroit in choosing [his]179-samuel words , and too skilled in modulating [his]179-samuel voice . [The two little girls]3438-the two little girls [Florinda]180-florinda and [Grizzel]181-grizzel were [nice little girls]3439-nice little girls enough , but [they]3438-the two little girls did not possess the strong sterling qualities of [[their]3438-the two little girls brothers]3440-their brothers ; [their]3438-the two little girls voices were not often heard at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi ; [they]3438-the two little girls were bashful and timid by nature , slow to speak before [company]3441-company even when asked to do so ; and though [they]3438-the two little girls looked very nice in [their]3438-the two little girls clean white muslin frocks and pink sashes , [they]3438-the two little girls were but little noticed by [[the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's visitors]3443-the archdeacon 's visitors . Whatever of submissive humility may have appeared in the gait and visage of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon during [his]382-the archdeacon colloquy with [[his]382-the archdeacon wife]607-his wife in [the sanctum of [their]3447-their dressing - rooms]3446-the sanctum of their dressing - rooms , was dispelled as [he]382-the archdeacon entered [[his]382-the archdeacon breakfast - parlour]3448-his breakfast - parlour with erect head and powerful step . In the presence of [a third person]3449-a third person [he]382-the archdeacon assumed [the lord and master]3450-the lord and master ; and [that wise and talented lady]3451-that wise and talented lady too well knew [the man to whom [her]3451-that wise and talented lady lot for life was bound , to stretch [her]3451-that wise and talented lady authority beyond the point at which it would be borne]3452-the man to whom her lot for life was bound , to stretch her authority beyond the point at which it would be borne . [[Strangers]3453-strangers at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi]3454-strangers at plumstead episcopi , when [they]3453-strangers saw the imperious brow with which [he]382-the archdeacon commanded silence from the large circle of [visitors]3455-visitors , [children]3456-children , and [servants who came together in the morning]3457-servants who came together in the morning to hear [him]382-the archdeacon read the word of [God]159-god , and watched how meekly [that wife]3458-that wife seated [herself]3458-that wife behind [her]3458-that wife basket of keys with [a little girl on each side]3459-a little girl on each side , as [she]3458-that wife caught that commanding glance ; [strangers]3453-strangers , [I]2730-papa say , seeing this , could little guess that some fifteen minutes since [she]3458-that wife had stoutly held [her]3458-that wife ground against [him]382-the archdeacon , hardly allowing [him]382-the archdeacon to open [his]382-the archdeacon mouth in [his]382-the archdeacon own defence . But such is the tact and talent of [women]3461-women ! And now let [us]3462-us observe [the well - furnished breakfast - parlour at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi]3463-the well - furnished breakfast - parlour at plumstead episcopi , and the comfortable air of all the belongings of [the rectory]3464-the rectory . Comfortable they certainly were , but neither gorgeous nor even grand ; indeed , considering the money that had been spent [there]713-there , the eye and taste might have been better served ; there was an air of heaviness about [the rooms]3323-the rooms which might have been avoided without any sacrifice of propriety ; colours might have been better chosen and lights more perfectly diffused : but perhaps in doing so the thorough clerical aspect of the whole might have been somewhat marred ; at any rate , it was not without ample consideration that those thick , dark , costly carpets were put down ; those embossed , but sombre papers hung up ; those heavy curtains draped so as to half - exclude the light of the sun : nor were these old - fashioned chairs , bought at a price far exceeding that now given for more modern goods , without a purpose . The breakfast - service on the table was equally costly and equally plain ; the apparent object had been to spend money without obtaining brilliancy or splendour . The urn was of thick and solid silver , as were also the tea - pot , coffee - pot , cream - ewer , and sugar - bowl ; the cups were old , dim dragon china , worth about a pound a piece , but very despicable in the eyes of the uninitiated . The silver forks were so heavy as to be disagreeable to the hand , and the bread - basket was of a weight really formidable to [any but robust persons]3467-any but robust persons . The tea consumed was the very best , the coffee the very blackest , the cream the very thickest ; there was dry toast and buttered toast , muffins and crumpets ; hot bread and cold bread , white bread and brown bread , [home]3108-home - made bread and [bakers]3469-bakers ' bread , wheaten bread and oaten bread , and if there be other breads than these , they were there ; there were eggs in napkins , and crispy bits of bacon under silver covers ; and there were little fishes in a little box , and devilled kidneys frizzling on a hot - water dish ; which , by the bye , were placed closely contiguous to the plate of [the worthy archdeacon [himself]3470-the worthy archdeacon himself]3470-the worthy archdeacon himself . Over and above this , on a snow - white napkin , spread upon the sideboard , was a huge ham and a huge sirloin ; the latter having laden the dinner table on the previous evening . Such was the ordinary fare at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi . And yet [I]2730-papa have never found [the rectory]3464-the rectory [a pleasant house]3472-a pleasant house . The fact that [man]875-man shall not live by bread alone seemed to be somewhat forgotten ; and noble as was the appearance of [the host]3474-the host , and sweet and good - natured as was the face of [the hostess]3475-the hostess , talented as were [the children]961-the children , and excellent as were the viands and the wines , in spite of these attractions , [I]2730-papa generally found [the rectory]3464-the rectory somewhat dull . After breakfast [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon would retire , of course to [his]382-the archdeacon clerical pursuits . [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly , [I]2730-papa presume , inspected [[her]129-mrs. grantly kitchen]3479-her kitchen , though [she]129-mrs. grantly had [a first - rate housekeeper]3480-a first - rate housekeeper , with sixty pounds a year ; and attended to the lessons of [Florinda]180-florinda and [Grizzel]181-grizzel , though [she]129-mrs. grantly had [an excellent governess with thirty pounds a year]3481-an excellent governess with thirty pounds a year : but at any rate [she]129-mrs. grantly disappeared : and [I]2730-papa never could make [companions of]3482-companions of [the boys]3382-the boys . [Charles James]178-charles james , though [he]178-charles james always looked as though there was something in [him]178-charles james , never seemed to have much to say ; and what [he]178-charles james did say [he]178-charles james would always unsay the next minute . [He]178-charles james told [me]2730-papa once , that [he]178-charles james considered cricket , on the whole , to be a gentleman - like game for [boys]3484-boys , provided [they]3484-boys would play without running about ; and that fives , also , was a seemly game , so that [those who played it]3485-those who played it never heated [themselves]3485-those who played it . [Henry]116-henry once quarrelled with [me]2730-papa for taking [[his]116-henry sister]536-his sister [Grizzel]181-grizzel 's part , in a contest between [them]3487-them as to the best mode of using a watering - pot for the garden flowers ; and from that day to this [he]116-henry has not spoken to [me]2730-papa , though [he]116-henry speaks at [me]2730-papa often enough . For half an hour or so [I]2730-papa certainly did like [Sammy]179-samuel 's gentle speeches ; but [one]729-one gets tired of honey , and [I]2730-papa found that [he]178-charles james preferred [the more admiring listeners whom [he]178-charles james met in [the [kitchen - garden]3491-kitchen - garden and back precincts of [the establishment]3492-the establishment]3490-the kitchen - garden and back precincts of the establishment]3489-the more admiring listeners whom he met in the kitchen - garden and back precincts of the establishment ; besides , [I]2730-papa think [I]2730-papa once caught [Sammy]179-samuel fibbing . On the whole , therefore , [I]2730-papa found [the rectory]3464-the rectory [a dull house]3494-a dull house , though it must be admitted that everything there was of the very best . After breakfast , on the morning of which [we]3495-we are writing , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , as usual , retired to [[his]382-the archdeacon study]3497-his study , intimating that [he]382-the archdeacon was going to be very busy , but that [he]382-the archdeacon would see [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick if [he]382-the archdeacon called . On entering [this sacred room]3498-this sacred room [he]382-the archdeacon carefully opened the paper case on which [he]382-the archdeacon was wo nt to compose [his]382-the archdeacon favourite sermons , and spread on it a fair sheet of paper , and one partly written on ; [he]382-the archdeacon then placed [his]382-the archdeacon inkstand , looked at [his]382-the archdeacon pen , and folded [his]382-the archdeacon blotting - paper ; having done so , [he]382-the archdeacon got up again from [his]382-the archdeacon seat , stood with [his]382-the archdeacon back to the fire - place , and yawned comfortably , stretching out vastly [his]382-the archdeacon huge arms , and opening [his]382-the archdeacon burly chest . [He]382-the archdeacon then walked across [the room]3355-the room and locked the door ; and having so prepared [himself]382-the archdeacon , [he]382-the archdeacon threw [himself]382-the archdeacon into [his]382-the archdeacon easy chair , took from a secret drawer beneath [his]382-the archdeacon table a volume of [Rabelais]184-rabelais , and began to amuse [himself]382-the archdeacon with the witty mischief of [Panurge]185-panurge ; and so passed [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's morning on that day . [He]382-the archdeacon was left undisturbed at [[his]382-the archdeacon studies]3501-his studies for an hour or two , when a knock came to the door , and [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick was announced . [Rabelais]184-rabelais retired into the secret drawer , the easy chair seemed knowingly to betake itself off , and when [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon quickly undid [his]382-the archdeacon bolt , [he]382-the archdeacon was discovered by [the steward working , as usual]3503-the steward working , as usual , for [that church of which [he]109-mr. chadwick was so useful a pillar]3504-that church of which he was so useful a pillar . [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick had just come from [London]13-london , and was , therefore , known to be [the bearer of important news]3505-the bearer of important news . "[2730-papa] [We]1105-we 've got [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's opinion at last , " said [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , as [he]109-mr. chadwick seated [himself]109-mr. chadwick . "[1105-we] Well , well , well ! " exclaimed [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon impatiently . "[1105-we] Oh , it 's as long as [my]0-i arm , " said [the other]762-the other ; "[1105-we] it ca n't be told in a word , but [you]1106-him can read it ; " and [he]762-the other handed [him]1106-him a copy , in heaven knows how many spun - out folios , of the opinion which [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general had managed to cram on the back and sides of the case as originally submitted to [him]1106-him . "[1106-him] The upshot is , " said [Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , "[1106-him] that there 's a screw loose in [their]1107-they case , and [we]1105-we had better do nothing . [They]1107-they are proceeding against [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding and [myself]0-i , and [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham holds that , under the wording of the will , and subsequent arrangements legally sanctioned , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding and [I]0-i are only paid [servants]3369-servants . [The defendants]1109-the defendants should have been either [the Corporation of [Barchester]6-barchester]322-the corporation of barchester , or possibly [the chapter]1111-the chapter or [[your]1106-him father]2726-your father . " "[2726-your father] W — hoo , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon ; "[2726-your father] so [Master Bold]122-mr. bold is on a wrong scent , is [he]122-mr. bold ? " "[122-mr. bold] That 's [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's opinion ; but any scent almost would be a wrong scent . [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham thinks that if [they]1107-they 'd taken [the corporation]1113-the corporation , or the chapter , [we]1114-we could have baffled [them]1107-they . [The bishop]260-the bishop , [he]151-sir abraham thinks , would be the surest shot ; but even there [we]1114-we could plead that [the bishop]260-the bishop is only [visitor]1117-visitor , and that [he]260-the bishop has never made [himself]260-the bishop [a consenting party]1118-a consenting party to the performance of other duties . " "[260-the bishop] That 's quite clear , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . "[260-the bishop] Not quite so clear , " said [the other]762-the other . "[1119-you] [You]1119-you see the will says , ' [[My]0-i lord]962-my lord , [the bishop]260-the bishop , being graciously pleased to see that due justice be done . ' Now , it may be a question whether , in accepting and administering the patronage , [[your]1119-you father]2726-your father has not accepted also the other duties assigned . It is doubtful , however ; but even if [they]1107-they hit that nail — and [they]1107-they are far off from that yet,—the point is so nice , as [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham says , that [you]1119-you would force [them]1107-they into fifteen thousand pounds ' cost before [they]1107-they could bring it to an issue ! and where 's that sum of money to come from ? " [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon rubbed [his]382-the archdeacon hands with delight ; [he]382-the archdeacon had never doubted the justice of [his]382-the archdeacon case , but [he]382-the archdeacon had begun to have some dread of unjust success on the part of [[his]382-the archdeacon enemies]3513-his enemies . " "[129-mrs. grantly] [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly is very interested in the matter , [I]0-i know , " said [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick . Did [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon wink , or did [he]382-the archdeacon not ? [The careful steward]3523-the careful steward then expressed [himself]3523-the careful steward contented . Ah ! [vain man]3524-vain man ! [he]382-the archdeacon could fasten up [his]382-the archdeacon Rabelais , and other things secret , with all the skill of [Bramah]186-bramah or of [Chubb]187-chubb ; but where could [he]382-the archdeacon fasten up the key which solved these mechanical mysteries ? It is probable to [us]1132-we that the contents of [no drawer in [that house]3526-that house]3525-no drawer in that house were unknown to [its mistress]3527-its mistress , and [we]1132-we think , moreover , that [she]3527-its mistress was entitled to all such knowledge . "[129-mrs. grantly] But , " said [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , "[129-mrs. grantly] [we]1132-we must , of course , tell [[your]1133-you father]2726-your father and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding so much of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's opinion as will satisfy [them]1135-them that the matter is doing well . " "[151-sir abraham] Oh , certainly,—yes , of course , " said [the doctor]613-the doctor . "[151-sir abraham] [You]1133-you had better let [them]1135-them know that [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham is of opinion that there is no case at any rate against [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ; and that as the action is worded at present , it must fall to the ground ; [they]1135-them must be nonsuited if [they]1135-them carry it on ; [you]1133-you had better tell [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , that [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham is clearly of opinion that [he]151-sir abraham is only [a servant]1136-a servant , and as such , not liable — or if [you]1133-you like it , [I]0-i 'll see [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding [myself]0-i . " "[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i must see [him]151-sir abraham to - morrow , and [[my]0-i father]942-my father too , and [I]0-i 'll explain to [them]1135-them exactly so much,—you wo n't go before lunch , [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick : well , if [you]1133-you will , [you]1133-you must , for [I]0-i know [your]1133-you time is precious ; " and [he]0-i shook hands with [the diocesan steward]3529-the diocesan steward , and bowed [him]3529-the diocesan steward out . And [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon had again recourse to [his]382-the archdeacon drawer , and twice read through the essence of [Sir Abraham Haphazard]151-sir abraham 's law - enlightened and law - bewildered brains . It was very clear that to [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , the justice of [the old men]314-the old men 's claim or the justice of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's defence were ideas that had never presented themselves . A legal victory over [an opposing party]3532-an opposing party was the service for which [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was , as [he]151-sir abraham imagined , to be paid ; and that [he]151-sir abraham , according to [his]151-sir abraham lights , had diligently laboured to achieve , and with probable hope of success . Of the intense desire which [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding felt to be assured on fit authority , that [he]151-sir abraham was wronging [no man]2761-no man , that [he]151-sir abraham was entitled in true equity to [his]151-sir abraham income , that [he]151-sir abraham might sleep at night without pangs of conscience , that [he]151-sir abraham was [no robber]3304-no robber , [no spoiler of the poor]3535-no spoiler of the poor ; that [he]151-sir abraham and all [the world]325-the world might be openly convinced that [he]151-sir abraham was not [the man which [the Jupiter]3310-the jupiter had described [him]151-sir abraham to be]3537-the man which the jupiter had described him to be ; of such longings on the part of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was entirely ignorant ; nor , indeed , could it be looked on as part of [his]151-sir abraham business to gratify such desires . Such was not the system on which [his]151-sir abraham battles were fought , and victories gained . Success was [his]151-sir abraham object , and [he]151-sir abraham was generally successful . [He]151-sir abraham conquered [[his]151-sir abraham enemies]3513-his enemies by [their]3513-his enemies weakness rather than by [his]151-sir abraham own strength , and it had been found almost impossible to make up a case , in which [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , as [an antagonist]3540-an antagonist , would not find a flaw . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon was delighted with the closeness of the reasoning . To do [him]151-sir abraham justice , it was not a selfish triumph that [he]151-sir abraham desired ; [he]151-sir abraham would personally lose nothing by defeat , or at least what [he]151-sir abraham might lose did not actuate [him]151-sir abraham ; but neither was it love of justice which made [him]151-sir abraham so anxious , nor even mainly solicitude for [[his]151-sir abraham father - in - law]435-his father - in - law . [He]151-sir abraham was fighting a part of a never - ending battle against [a never - conquered foe]3543-a never - conquered foe — that of [the church]454-the church against [its enemies]3545-its enemies . [He]151-sir abraham knew [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding could not pay all the expense of these doings ; for these long opinions of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's , these causes to be pleaded , these speeches to be made , these various courts through which the case was , [he]151-sir abraham presumed , to be dragged . [He]151-sir abraham knew that [he]151-sir abraham and [[his]151-sir abraham father]508-his father must at least bear the heavier portion of this tremendous cost ; but to do [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon justice , [he]151-sir abraham did not recoil from this . [He]151-sir abraham was [a man fond of obtaining money , greedy of a large income , but open - handed enough in expending it]3548-a man fond of obtaining money , greedy of a large income , but open - handed enough in expending it , and it was a triumph to [him]151-sir abraham to foresee the success of this measure , although [he]151-sir abraham might be called on to pay so dearly for it [himself]151-sir abraham . On the following morning [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon was with [[his]382-the archdeacon father]508-his father betimes , and a note was sent down to [the warden]318-the warden begging [his]151-sir abraham attendance at [the palace]947-the palace . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , as [he]106-dr. grantly cogitated on the matter , leaning back in [his]106-dr. grantly brougham as [he]106-dr. grantly journeyed into [Barchester]6-barchester , felt that it would be difficult to communicate [his]106-dr. grantly own satisfaction either to [[his]106-dr. grantly father]508-his father or [[his]106-dr. grantly father - in - law]435-his father - in - law . [He]106-dr. grantly wanted success on [his]106-dr. grantly own side and discomfiture on that of [[his]106-dr. grantly enemies]3513-his enemies . [The bishop]260-the bishop wanted peace on the subject ; a settled peace if possible , but peace at any rate till the short remainder of [his]260-the bishop own days had spun itself out ; but [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding required , not only success and peace , but [he]102-mr. harding also demanded that [he]102-mr. harding might stand justified before [the world]325-the world . [The bishop]260-the bishop , however , was comparatively easy to deal with , and before the arrival of [the other]762-the other , [the dutiful son]3560-the dutiful son had persuaded [[his]3560-the dutiful son father]508-his father that all was going on well , and then [the warden]318-the warden arrived . It was [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's wo nt , whenever [he]102-mr. harding spent a morning at [the palace]947-the palace , to seat [himself]102-mr. harding immediately at [the bishop]260-the bishop 's elbow , [the bishop]260-the bishop occupying a huge armchair fitted up with candle - sticks , a reading table , a drawer , and other paraphernalia , the position of which chair was never moved , summer or winter ; and when , as was very usual , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon was [there]713-there also , [he]382-the archdeacon confronted [the two elders]3568-the two elders , who thus were enabled to fight the battle against [him]382-the archdeacon together ; and together submit to defeat , for such was [their]3568-the two elders constant fate . [[Our]3569-our warden]3570-our warden now took [his]3570-our warden accustomed place , having greeted [[his]3570-our warden son - in - law]440-his son - in - law as [he]3570-our warden entered , and then affectionately inquired after [[his]3570-our warden friend]285-his friend 's health . There was a gentleness about [the bishop]260-the bishop to which the soft womanly affection of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding particularly endeared itself , and it was quaint to see how [the two mild old priests]3574-the two mild old priests pressed [each other]497-each other 's hands , and smiled and made little signs of love . "[151-sir abraham] [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's opinion has come at last , " began [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had heard so much , and was most anxious to know the result . "[151-sir abraham] It is quite favourable , " said [the bishop]260-the bishop , pressing [[his]260-the bishop friend]285-his friend 's arm . "[0-i] [I]0-i am so glad . " "[1139-they] But as how , [archdeacon]2734-archdeacon ? " "[2734-archdeacon] Yes , yes , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , impatient of poetry at such a time . "[2734-archdeacon] Well , [two paid servants]1145-two paid servants , [we]1149-we 'll say ; [one]729-one to look after [the men]378-the men , and [the other to look after the money]1152-the other to look after the money . [You]2734-archdeacon and [Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick are [these two servants]1153-these two servants , and whether either of [you]2734-archdeacon be paid too much , or too little , more or less in fact than [the founder]464-the founder willed , it 's as clear as daylight that [no one]283-no one can fall foul of either of [you]2734-archdeacon for receiving an allotted stipend . " "[464-the founder] That does seem clear , " said [the bishop]260-the bishop , who had winced visibly under the words [servants]3369-servants and stipend , which , however , appeared to have caused no uneasiness to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . "[464-the founder] Quite clear , " said [he]260-the bishop , "[464-the founder] and very satisfactory . " "[1160-the only judges of this] And who does manage [the hospital]364-the hospital ? " asked [the warden]318-the warden . "[1160-the only judges of this] Oh , let [them]1153-these two servants find that out ; that 's another question ; the action is brought against [you]2734-archdeacon and [Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , and that 's [your]2734-archdeacon defence , and a perfect and full defence it is . Now that [I]0-i think very satisfactory . " "[0-i] Well , " said [the bishop]260-the bishop , looking inquiringly up into [[his]260-the bishop friend]285-his friend 's face , who sat silent awhile , and apparently not so well satisfied . " "[1162-no twelve men in england] But according to that , " said [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , "[1162-no twelve men in england] [I]0-i might as well have sixteen hundred a year as eight , if [the managers]1163-the managers choose to allot it to [me]0-i ; and as [I]0-i am [one of [the managers]1163-the managers]1164-one of the managers , if not [the chief manager]1166-the chief manager , [myself]0-i , that can hardly be a just arrangement . " "[1166-the chief manager] Oh , well , all that 's nothing to the question ; the question is , whether [this intruding fellow]1167-this intruding fellow , and a lot of [cheating attorneys]1168-cheating attorneys and [pestilent dissenters]1169-pestilent dissenters , are to interfere with an arrangement which [every one]481-every one knows is essentially just and serviceable to [the church]454-the church . Pray do n't let [us]1172-us be splitting hairs , and that amongst [ourselves]1172-us , or there 'll never be an end of the cause or the cost . " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding again sat silent for awhile , during which [the bishop]260-the bishop once and again pressed [his]260-the bishop arm , and looked in [his]260-the bishop face to see if [he]260-the bishop could catch a gleam of a contented and eased mind ; but there was no such gleam , and [the poor warden]354-the poor warden continued playing sad dirges on invisible stringed instruments in all manner of positions : [he]260-the bishop was ruminating in [his]260-the bishop mind on this opinion of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , looking to it wearily and earnestly for satisfaction , but finding none . At last [he]260-the bishop said , "[1173-you] Did [you]1173-you see the opinion , [archdeacon]2734-archdeacon ? " [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon said [he]382-the archdeacon had not — that was to say , [he]382-the archdeacon had — that was , [he]382-the archdeacon had not seen the opinion itself ; [he]382-the archdeacon had seen what had been called a copy , but [he]382-the archdeacon could not say whether of a whole or part ; nor could [he]382-the archdeacon say that what [he]382-the archdeacon had seen were the ipsissima verba of [the great man]3592-the great man [himself]382-the archdeacon ; but what [he]382-the archdeacon had seen contained exactly the decision which [he]382-the archdeacon had announced , and which [he]382-the archdeacon again declared to be to [his]382-the archdeacon mind extremely satisfactory . " "[2734-archdeacon] Well , [I]0-i suppose [you]1173-you can if [you]1173-you make a point of it ; but [I]0-i do n't see the use [myself]0-i ; of course it is essential that the purport of it should not be known , and it is therefore unadvisable to multiply copies . " "[2734-archdeacon] Why should it not be known ? " asked [the warden]318-the warden . "[2734-archdeacon] What a question for [a man]545-a man to ask ! Ca n't [you]1173-you see that if [we]1177-we tell [them]1178-them that no action will lie against [you]1173-you , but that one may possibly lie against [some other person]1179-some other person or [persons]1180-persons , that [we]1177-we shall be putting weapons into [their]1178-them hands , and be teaching [them]1178-them how to cut [our]1177-we own throats ? " [The warden]318-the warden again sat silent , and [the bishop]260-the bishop again looked at [him]318-the warden wistfully : "[1177-we] The only thing [we]1177-we have now to do , " continued [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , "[1177-we] is to remain quiet , hold [our]1177-we peace , and let [them]1178-them play [their]1178-them own game as [they]1178-them please . " "[1177-we] [We]1177-we are not to make known then , " said [the warden]318-the warden , "[1177-we] that [we]1177-we have consulted [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general , and that [we]1177-we are advised by [him]3508-the attorney - general that [the founder]464-the founder 's will is fully and fairly carried out . " "[3508-the attorney - general] God bless [my]0-i soul ! " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , "[3508-the attorney - general] how odd it is that [you]1183-you will not see that all [we]1177-we are to do is to do nothing : why should [we]1177-we say anything about [the founder]464-the founder 's will ? [We]1177-we are in possession ; and [we]1177-we know that [they]1178-them are not in a position to put [us]1177-we out : surely that is enough for the present . " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding rose from [his]102-mr. harding seat and paced thoughtfully up and down [the library]3601-the library , [the bishop]260-the bishop the while watching [him]102-mr. harding painfully at every turn , and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon continuing to pour forth [his]382-the archdeacon convictions that the affair was in a state to satisfy any prudent mind . "[171-the jupiter] And [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter ? " said [the warden]318-the warden , stopping suddenly . "[171-the jupiter] Oh ! [the Jupiter]3310-the jupiter , " answered [the other]762-the other . "[3310-the jupiter] [The Jupiter]171-the jupiter can break no bones . [You]1183-you must bear with that ; there is much of course which it is [our]1177-we bounden duty to bear ; it can not be all roses for [us]1177-we here , " and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon looked exceedingly moral ; "[3310-the jupiter] besides the matter is too trivial , of too little general interest to be mentioned again in the Jupiter , unless [we]1177-we stir up the subject : " and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon again looked exceedingly knowing and worldly wise . [The warden]318-the warden continued [his]318-the warden walk ; the hard and stinging words of that newspaper article , each one of which had thrust a thorn as it were into [his]318-the warden inmost soul , were fresh in [his]318-the warden memory : [he]318-the warden had read it more than once , word by word , and what was worse , [he]318-the warden fancied it was as well known to [every one]481-every one as to [himself]318-the warden . Was [he]318-the warden to be looked on as [the unjust griping priest [he]318-the warden had been there described]3610-the unjust griping priest he had been there described ? Was [he]318-the warden to be pointed at as the consumer of the bread of [the poor]1029-the poor , and to be allowed no means of refuting such charges , of clearing [his]318-the warden begrimed name , of standing innocent in [the world]325-the world , as hitherto [he]318-the warden had stood ? Was [he]318-the warden to bear all this , to receive as usual [his]318-the warden now hated income , and be known as [one of [those greedy priests who by [their]3614-those greedy priests who by their rapacity have brought disgrace on their church rapacity have brought disgrace on [their]3614-those greedy priests who by their rapacity have brought disgrace on their church church]3614-those greedy priests who by their rapacity have brought disgrace on their church]3613-one of those greedy priests who by their rapacity have brought disgrace on their church ? and why ? Why should [he]318-the warden bear all this ? why should [he]318-the warden die , for [he]318-the warden felt that [he]318-the warden could not live , under such a weight of obloquy ? As [he]318-the warden paced up and down [the room]3355-the room [he]318-the warden resolved in [his]318-the warden misery and enthusiasm that [he]318-the warden could with pleasure , if [he]318-the warden were allowed , give up [[his]318-the warden place]3616-his place , abandon [[his]318-the warden pleasant home]3617-his pleasant home , leave [the hospital]364-the hospital , and live poorly , happily , and with an unsullied name , on the small remainder of [his]318-the warden means . [He]318-the warden was [a man somewhat shy of speaking of [himself]318-the warden , even before those who knew [him]318-the warden best , and whom [he]318-the warden loved the most]3619-a man somewhat shy of speaking of himself , even before those who knew him best , and whom he loved the most ; but at last it burst forth from [him]318-the warden , and with a somewhat jerking eloquence [he]318-the warden declared that [he]318-the warden could not , would not , bear this misery any longer . "[1177-we] If it can be proved , " said [he]318-the warden at last , "[159-god] that [I]0-i have a just and honest right to this , as [God]159-god well knows [I]0-i always deemed [I]0-i had ; if this salary or stipend be really [my]0-i due , [I]0-i am not less anxious than another to retain it . [I]0-i have the well - being of [[my]0-i child]1186-my child to look to . [I]0-i am too old to miss without some pain the comforts to which [I]0-i have been used ; and [I]0-i am , as others are , anxious to prove to [the world]325-the world that [I]0-i have been right , and to uphold the place [I]0-i have held ; but [I]0-i can not do it at such a cost as this . [I]0-i can not bear this . Could [you]1188-you tell [me]0-i to do so ? " and [he]0-i appealed , almost in tears , to [the bishop]260-the bishop , who had left [his]260-the bishop chair , and was now leaning on [the warden]318-the warden 's arm as [he]260-the bishop stood on the further side of the table facing [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . "[1188-you] Could [you]1188-you tell [me]0-i to sit there at ease , indifferent , and satisfied , while such things as these are said loudly of [me]0-i in [the world]325-the world ? " [The bishop]260-the bishop could feel for [him]0-i and sympathise with [him]0-i , but [he]260-the bishop could not advise [him]0-i , [he]260-the bishop could only say , "[1188-you] No , no , [you]0-i shall be asked to do nothing that is painful ; [you]0-i shall do just what [your]0-i heart tells [you]0-i to be right ; [you]0-i shall do whatever [you]0-i think best [yourself]0-i . [Theophilus]106-dr. grantly , do n't advise [him]106-dr. grantly , pray do n't advise [the warden]318-the warden to do anything which is painful . " But [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , though [he]382-the archdeacon could not sympathise , could advise ; and [he]382-the archdeacon saw that the time had come when it behoved [him]382-the archdeacon to do so in a somewhat peremptory manner . "[962-my lord] Why , [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord , " [he]382-the archdeacon said speaking to [[his]0-i father]508-his father : and when [he]382-the archdeacon called [[his]0-i father]508-his father ' [[my]962-my lord lord]962-my lord , ' [the good old bishop]3628-the good old bishop shook in [his]3628-the good old bishop shoes , for [he]3628-the good old bishop knew that an evil time was coming . "[962-my lord] Why , [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord , there are two ways of giving advice ; there is advice that may be good for the present day ; and there is advice that may be good for days to come : now [I]0-i can not bring [myself]0-i to give the former , if it be incompatible with the other . " "[0-i] No , no , no , [I]0-i suppose not , " said [the bishop]260-the bishop , reseating [himself]260-the bishop , and shading [his]260-the bishop face with [his]260-the bishop hands . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding sat down with [his]102-mr. harding back to the further wall , playing to [himself]102-mr. harding some air fitted for so calamitous an occasion , and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon said out [his]382-the archdeacon say standing , with [his]382-the archdeacon back to the empty fireplace . "[0-i] It is not to be supposed , but that much pain will spring out of this unnecessarily raised question . [We]1193-we must all have foreseen that , and the matter has in no wise gone on worse than [we]1193-we expected ; but it will be weak , yes , and wicked also , to abandon the cause and own [ourselves]1193-we wrong , because the inquiry is painful . It is not only [ourselves]1193-we [we]1193-we have to look to : to a certain extent the interest of [the church]454-the church is in [our]1193-we keeping . Should it be found that one after another of [those who hold preferment]1195-those who hold preferment abandoned it whenever it might be attacked , is it not plain that such attacks would be renewed till nothing was left [us]1193-we ? and , that if so deserted , [the Church of [England]14-england]3292-the church of england must fall to the ground altogether ? If this be true of many , it is true of [one]729-one . Were [you]1198-you , accused as [you]1198-you now are , to throw up the wardenship , and to relinquish the preferment which is [your]1198-you property , with the vain object of proving [yourself]1198-you disinterested , [you]1198-you would fail in that object , [you]1198-you would inflict a desperate blow on [[your]1198-you brother]1199-your brother [clergymen]1200-clergymen , [you]1198-you would encourage [every cantankerous dissenter in [England]14-england]1201-every cantankerous dissenter in england to make a similar charge against some source of clerical revenue , and [you]1198-you would do [your]1198-you best to dishearten [those who are most anxious to defend [you]1198-you and uphold [your]1198-you position]1202-those who are most anxious to defend you and uphold your position . [I]0-i can fancy nothing more weak , or more wrong . It is not that [you]1198-you think that there is any justice in these charges , or that [you]1198-you doubt [your]1198-you own right to the wardenship : [you]1198-you are convinced of [your]1198-you own honesty , and yet would yield to [them]1203-them through cowardice . " "[1198-you] Cowardice ! " said [the bishop]260-the bishop , expostulating . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding sat unmoved , gazing on [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law . "[1198-you] Well , would it not be cowardice ? would [he]1204-he not do so because [he]1204-he is afraid to endure the evil things which will be falsely spoken of [him]1204-he ? Would that not be cowardice ? And now let [us]1205-us see the extent of the evil which [you]1198-you dread . [The Jupiter]171-the jupiter publishes an article which [a great many]1206-a great many , no doubt , will read ; but of those who understand the subject how many will believe [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter ? [Every one]481-every one knows what [its]481-every one object is ; it has taken up the case against [Lord Guildford]118-lord guildford and against [the Dean of Rochester]1208-the dean of rochester , and that against [half a dozen bishops]1209-half a dozen bishops ; and does not [every one]481-every one know that it would take up any case of the kind , right or wrong , false or true , with known justice or known injustice , if by doing so it could further [its]481-every one own views ? Does not all [the world]325-the world know this of [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter ? Who that really knows [you]1198-you will think the worse of [you]1198-you for what [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter says ? And why care for [those who do not know [you]1198-you]1212-those who do not know you ? [I]0-i will say nothing of [your]1198-you own comfort , but [I]0-i do say that [you]1198-you could not be justified in throwing up , in a fit of passion , for such it would be , the only maintenance that [Eleanor]104-eleanor has ; and if [you]1198-you did so , if [you]1198-you really did vacate the wardenship , and submit to ruin , what would that profit [you]1198-you ? If [you]1198-you have no future right to the income , [you]1198-you have had no past right to it ; and the very fact of [your]1198-you abandoning [your]1198-you position , would create a demand for repayment of that which [you]1198-you have already received and spent . " [The poor warden]354-the poor warden groaned as [he]354-the poor warden sat perfectly still , looking up at [the hard - hearted orator who thus tormented [him]354-the poor warden]3634-the hard - hearted orator who thus tormented him , and [the bishop]260-the bishop echoed the sound faintly from behind [his]260-the bishop hands ; but [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon cared little for such signs of weakness , and completed [his]382-the archdeacon exhortation . "[1213-us] But let [us]1213-us suppose [the office]1214-the office to be left vacant , and that [your]1198-you own troubles concerning it were over ; would that satisfy [you]1198-you ? Are [your]1198-you only aspirations in the matter confined to [yourself]1198-you and [family]1215-family ? [I]0-i know [they]1216-they are not . [I]0-i know [you]1198-you are as anxious as any of [us]1213-us for [the church to which [we]1213-us belong]1217-the church to which we belong ; and what a grievous blow would such an act of apostasy give [her]1218-her ! [You]1198-you owe it to [the church of which [you]1198-you are [a member]2889-a member]1219-the church of which you are a member and [a minister]1221-a minister , to bear with this affliction , however severe it may be : [you]1198-you owe it to [[my]0-i father]942-my father , who instituted [you]1198-you , to support [his]942-my father rights : [you]1198-you owe it to [those who preceded [you]1198-you to assert the legality of [their]1223-those who preceded you to assert the legality of their position position]1223-those who preceded you to assert the legality of their position : [you]1198-you owe it to [those who are to come after [you]1198-you , to maintain uninjured for [them]1223-those who preceded you to assert the legality of their position that which [you]1198-you received uninjured from [others]551-others]1224-those who are to come after you , to maintain uninjured for them that which you received uninjured from others ; and [you]1198-you owe to [us]1226-us all the unflinching assistance of perfect brotherhood in this matter , so that upholding one another [we]1226-us may support [our]1226-us great cause without blushing and without disgrace . " And so [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon ceased , and stood self - satisfied , watching the effect of [his]382-the archdeacon spoken wisdom . [The warden]318-the warden felt [himself]318-the warden , to a certain extent , stifled ; [he]318-the warden would have given [the world]325-the world to get [himself]318-the warden out into the open air without speaking to , or noticing [those who were in [the room]3355-the room with [him]318-the warden]3640-those who were in the room with him ; but this was impossible . [He]318-the warden could not leave without saying something , and [he]318-the warden felt [himself]318-the warden confounded by [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's eloquence . There was a heavy , unfeeling , unanswerable truth in what [he]318-the warden had said ; there was so much practical , but odious common sense in it , that [he]318-the warden neither knew how to assent or to differ . If it were necessary for [him]318-the warden to suffer , [he]318-the warden felt that [he]318-the warden could endure without complaint and without cowardice , providing that [he]318-the warden was self - satisfied of the justice of [his]318-the warden own cause . What [he]318-the warden could not endure was , that [he]318-the warden should be accused by [others]551-others , and not acquitted by [himself]318-the warden . Doubting , as [he]318-the warden had begun to doubt , the justice of [his]318-the warden own position in [the hospital]364-the hospital , [he]318-the warden knew that [his]318-the warden own self - confidence would not be restored because [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold had been in error as to some legal form ; nor could [he]318-the warden be satisfied to escape , because , through some legal fiction , [he]318-the warden who received the greatest benefit from [the hospital]364-the hospital might be considered only as one of [[its]364-the hospital servants]3646-its servants . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's speech had silenced [him]318-the warden — stupefied [him]318-the warden — annihilated [him]318-the warden ; anything but satisfied [him]318-the warden . With [the bishop]260-the bishop it fared not much better . [He]318-the warden did not discern clearly how things were , but [he]318-the warden saw enough to know that a battle was to be prepared for ; a battle that would destroy [his]318-the warden few remaining comforts , and bring [him]318-the warden with sorrow to the grave . [The warden]318-the warden still sat , and still looked at [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , till [his]318-the warden thoughts fixed themselves wholly on the means of escape from [his]318-the warden present position , and [he]318-the warden felt like a bird fascinated by gazing on a snake . "[0-i] [I]0-i hope [you]1227-you agree with [me]0-i , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon at last , breaking the dread silence ; "[1227-you] [[my]0-i lord]962-my lord , [I]0-i hope [you]1227-you agree with [me]0-i . " Oh what a sigh [the bishop]260-the bishop gave ! "[962-my lord] [[My]0-i lord]962-my lord , [I]0-i hope [you]1227-you agree with [me]0-i , " again repeated [the merciless tyrant]3653-the merciless tyrant . "[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i suppose so , " groaned [the poor old man]3654-the poor old man , slowly . "[0-i] And [you]1227-you , [warden]304-warden ? " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was now stirred to action — [he]0-i must speak and move , so [he]0-i got up and took one turn before [he]0-i answered . "[1227-you] Do not press [me]0-i for an answer just at present ; [I]0-i will do nothing lightly in the matter , and of whatever [I]0-i do [I]0-i will give [you]1227-you and [the bishop]260-the bishop notice . " And so without another word [he]0-i took [his]0-i leave , escaping quickly through [the palace hall]3655-the palace hall , and down the lofty steps , nor did [he]0-i breathe freely till [he]0-i found [himself]0-i alone under the huge elms of [the silent close]3656-the silent close . Here [he]0-i walked long and slowly , thinking on [his]0-i case with a troubled air , and trying in vain to confute [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's argument . [He]0-i then went [home]3108-home , resolved to bear it all — ignominy , suspense , disgrace , self - doubt , and heart - burning — and to do as those would have [him]0-i , who [he]0-i still believed were most fit and most able to counsel [him]0-i aright . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was [a sadder man]3659-a sadder man than [he]0-i had ever yet been when [he]0-i returned to [[his]0-i own house]3660-his own house . [He]0-i had been wretched enough on that well remembered morning when [he]0-i was forced to expose before [[his]0-i son - in - law]440-his son - in - law [the publisher]433-the publisher 's account for ushering into [the world]325-the world [his]0-i dear book of sacred music ; when after making such payments as [he]0-i could do unassisted , [he]0-i found that [he]0-i was [a debtor of more than three hundred pounds]3664-a debtor of more than three hundred pounds : but [his]0-i sufferings then were as nothing to [his]0-i present misery;—then [he]0-i had done wrong , and [he]0-i knew it , and was able to resolve that [he]0-i would not sin in like manner again ; but now [he]0-i could make no resolution , and comfort [himself]0-i by no promises of firmness . [He]0-i had been forced to think that [his]0-i lot had placed [him]0-i in a false position , and [he]0-i was about to maintain that position against the opinion of [the world]325-the world and against [his]0-i own convictions . [He]0-i had read with pity , amounting almost to horror , the strictures which had appeared from time to time against [the Earl of [Guildford]18-guildford as [master of St. Cross]3666-master of st. cross]152-st. cross , and the invectives that had been heaped on [rich diocesan dignitaries]3667-rich diocesan dignitaries and [overgrown sinecure pluralists]3668-overgrown sinecure pluralists . In judging of [them]3669-they , [he]0-i judged leniently ; the whole bias of [his]0-i profession had taught [him]0-i to think that [they]3669-they were more sinned against than sinning , and that the animosity with which [they]3669-they had been pursued was venomous and unjust ; but [he]0-i had not the less regarded [their]3669-they plight as most miserable . [His]0-i hair had stood on end and [his]0-i flesh had crept as [he]0-i read the things which had been written ; [he]0-i had wondered how [men]453-men could live under such a load of disgrace ; how [they]453-men could face [[their]453-men fellow creatures]3671-their fellow creatures while [their]453-men names were bandied about so injuriously and so publicly — and now this lot was to be [his]0-i — [he]0-i , [that shy retiring man , who had so comforted [himself]0-i in the hidden obscurity of [his]0-i lot , who had so enjoyed the unassuming warmth of [his]0-i own little corner]3672-that shy retiring man , who had so comforted himself in the hidden obscurity of his lot , who had so enjoyed the unassuming warmth of his own little corner , [he]0-i was now to be dragged forth into the glaring day , and gibbeted before ferocious multitudes . [He]0-i entered [[his]0-i own house]3660-his own house [a crest - fallen , humiliated man]3674-a crest - fallen , humiliated man , without a hope of overcoming the wretchedness which affected [him]0-i . [He]0-i wandered into [the drawing - room]3243-the drawing - room where was [[his]0-i daughter]280-his daughter ; but [he]0-i could not speak to [her]280-his daughter now , so [he]0-i left it , and went into [the book room]3677-the book room . [He]0-i was not quick enough to escape [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's glance , or to prevent [her]104-eleanor from seeing that [he]0-i was disturbed ; and in a little while [she]104-eleanor followed [him]0-i . [She]104-eleanor found [him]0-i seated in [his]0-i accustomed chair , with no book open before [him]0-i , no pen ready in [his]0-i hand , no ill - shapen notes of blotted music lying before [him]0-i as was usual , none of those hospital accounts with which [he]0-i was so precise and yet so unmethodical : [he]0-i was doing nothing , thinking of nothing , looking at nothing ; [he]0-i was merely suffering . "[0-i] Leave [me]0-i [Eleanor]104-eleanor , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear , " [he]0-i said , "[0-i] leave [me]0-i [[my]0-i darling]1233-my darling for a few minutes , for [I]0-i am busy . " [Eleanor]104-eleanor saw well how it was , but [she]104-eleanor did leave [him]0-i , and glided silently back to [[her]104-eleanor drawing - room]3678-her drawing - room . When [he]0-i had sat awhile , thus alone and unoccupied , [he]0-i got up to walk again — [he]0-i could make more of [his]0-i thoughts walking than sitting , and was creeping out into [[his]0-i garden]3679-his garden , when [he]0-i met [Bunce]136-bunce on the threshold . "[0-i] Well , [Bunce]136-bunce , " said [he]0-i , in a tone that for [him]136-bunce was sharp , "[0-i] what is it ? do [you]136-bunce want [me]0-i ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i was only coming to ask after [your]136-bunce reverence , " said [the old bedesman]3680-the old bedesman , touching [his]0-i hat ; "[0-i] and to inquire about the news from [London]13-london , " [he]0-i added after a pause . [The warden]318-the warden winced , and put [his]318-the warden hand to [his]318-the warden forehead and felt bewildered . "[188-attorney finney] [Attorney Finney]188-attorney finney has been [there]713-there this morning , " continued [Bunce]136-bunce , "[188-attorney finney] and by [his]188-attorney finney looks [I]0-i guess [he]188-attorney finney is not so well pleased as [he]188-attorney finney once was , and it has got abroad somehow that [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon has had down great news from [London]13-london , and [Handy]119-handy and [Moody]143-moody are both as black as devils ; and [I]0-i hope , " said [the man]3682-the man , trying to assume a cheery tone , "[0-i] that things are looking up , and that there 'll be an end soon to all this stuff which bothers [your]0-i reverence so sorely . " "[136-bunce] Well , [I]0-i wish there may be , [Bunce]136-bunce . " "[136-bunce] But about the news , [your]0-i reverence ? " said [the old man]3683-the old man , almost whispering . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding walked on , and shook [his]102-mr. harding head impatiently . [Poor Bunce]136-bunce little knew how [he]136-bunce was tormenting [[his]136-bunce patron]734-his patron . "[0-i] If there was anything to cheer [you]0-i , [I]0-i should be so glad to know it , " said [he]0-i , with a tone of affection which [the warden]318-the warden in all [his]318-the warden misery could not resist . [He]0-i stopped , and took both [the old man]3683-the old man 's hands in [his]0-i . "[1236-my friend] [[My]0-i friend]1236-my friend , " said [he]0-i , "[1237-my dear old friend] [[my]0-i dear old friend]1237-my dear old friend , there is nothing : there is no news to cheer [me]0-i — [God]159-god 's will be done : " and two small hot tears broke away from [his]3683-the old man eyes and stole down [his]3683-the old man furrowed cheeks . "[159-god] Then [God]159-god 's will be done , " said [the other solemnly]3687-the other solemnly , "[159-god] but [they]1238-they told [me]0-i that there was good news from [London]13-london , and [I]0-i came to wish [your]1237-my dear old friend reverence joy ; but [God]159-god 's will be done ; " and so [the warden]318-the warden again walked on , and [the bedesman]3689-the bedesman looking wistfully after [him]318-the warden , and receiving no encouragement to follow , returned sadly to [[his]3689-the bedesman own abode]735-his own abode . For a couple of hours [the warden]318-the warden remained thus in [the garden]704-the garden , now walking , now standing motionless on the turf , and then , as [his]318-the warden legs got weary , sitting unconsciously on the garden seats , and then walking again . And [Eleanor]104-eleanor , hidden behind the muslin curtains of the window , watched [him]2730-papa through the trees as [he]2730-papa now came in sight , and then again was concealed by the turnings of the walk ; and thus the time passed away till five , when [the warden]318-the warden crept back to [the house]374-the house and prepared for dinner . It was but a sorry meal . [The demure parlour - maid]3695-the demure parlour - maid as [she]3695-the demure parlour - maid handed the dishes and changed the plates , saw that all was not right , and was more demure than ever : neither [father]3696-father nor [daughter]3697-daughter could eat , and the hateful food was soon cleared away , and the bottle of port placed upon the table . "[159-god] Would [you]1239-you like [Bunce]136-bunce to come in , [papa]2730-papa ? " said [Eleanor]104-eleanor , thinking that the company of [the old man]3683-the old man might lighten [his]3683-the old man sorrow . "[2730-papa] No [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear , thank [you]2725-my dear , not to - day ; but are not [you]2725-my dear going out , [Eleanor]104-eleanor , this lovely afternoon ? do n't stay in for [me]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear . " "[0-i] [I]0-i thought [you]1239-you seemed so sad , [papa]2730-papa . " "[2730-papa] Sad , " said [he]2730-papa irritated ; "[2730-papa] well , [people]1126-people must all have [their]1126-people share of sadness here ; [I]0-i am not more exempt than another : but kiss [me]0-i , [dearest]1245-dearest , and go now ; [I]0-i will , if possible , be more sociable when [you]2725-my dear return . " And [Eleanor]104-eleanor was again banished from [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father 's sorrow . Ah ! [her]104-eleanor desire now was not to find [him]293-her father happy , but to be allowed to share [his]293-her father sorrows ; not to force [him]293-her father to be sociable , but to persuade [him]293-her father to be trustful . [She]104-eleanor put on [her]104-eleanor bonnet as desired , and went up to [Mary Bold]162-mary ; this was now [her]104-eleanor daily haunt , for [John Bold]121-bold was up in [London]13-london among [lawyers]3264-lawyers and [church reformers]3701-church reformers , diving deep into other questions than that of [the wardenship of [Barchester]6-barchester]3702-the wardenship of barchester ; supplying information to [one member of parliament]3703-one member of parliament , and dining with [another]3704-another ; subscribing to funds for the abolition of clerical incomes , and seconding at that great national meeting at [the Crown]37-the crown and Anchor a resolution to the effect , that [no clergyman of [the Church of England]3292-the church of england]3705-no clergyman of the church of england , be [he]3705-no clergyman of the church of england who [he]3705-no clergyman of the church of england might , should have more than a thousand a year , and [none less than two hundred and fifty]3707-none less than two hundred and fifty . [His]293-her father speech on this occasion was short , for fifteen had to speak , and [the room]3355-the room was hired for two hours only , at the expiration of which [the Quakers]3709-the quakers and [Mr. Cobden]189-mr. cobden were to make use of it for an appeal to [the public]2937-the public in aid of [the Emperor of [Russia]30-russia]3711-the emperor of russia ; but it was sharp and effective : at least [he]293-her father was told so by [a companion with whom [he]293-her father now lived much , and on whom [he]293-her father greatly depended]3712-a companion with whom he now lived much , and on whom he greatly depended — one [Tom Towers]190-tom towers , [a very leading genius , and supposed to have high employment on the staff of the Jupiter]3713-a very leading genius , and supposed to have high employment on the staff of the jupiter . So [Eleanor]104-eleanor , as was now [[her]104-eleanor wo nt]3714-her wo nt , went up to [Mary Bold]162-mary , and [Mary]162-mary listened kindly , while [the daughter]3715-the daughter spoke much of [[her]3715-the daughter father]293-her father , and , perhaps kinder still , found [a listener]3717-a listener in [Eleanor]104-eleanor , while [she]3715-the daughter spoke about [[her]3715-the daughter brother]528-her brother . In the meantime [the warden]318-the warden sat alone , leaning on the arm of [his]318-the warden chair ; [he]318-the warden had poured out a glass of wine , but had done so merely from habit , for [he]318-the warden left it untouched : there [he]318-the warden sat gazing at the open window , and thinking , if [he]318-the warden can be said to have thought , of the happiness of [his]318-the warden past life . All manner of past delights came before [his]318-the warden mind , which at the time [he]318-the warden had enjoyed without considering them ; [his]318-the warden easy days , [his]318-the warden absence of all kind of hard work , [[his]318-the warden pleasant shady home]3720-his pleasant shady home , [those twelve old neighbours whose welfare till now had been the source of so much pleasant care]3721-those twelve old neighbours whose welfare till now had been the source of so much pleasant care , the excellence of [[his]318-the warden children]3722-his children , the friendship of [the dear old bishop]3723-the dear old bishop , the solemn grandeur of those vaulted aisles , through which [he]318-the warden loved to hear [his]318-the warden own voice pealing ; and then [that friend of [friends]499-friends]3724-that friend of friends , that choice ally that had never deserted [him]318-the warden , [that eloquent companion that would always , when asked , discourse such pleasant music]3726-that eloquent companion that would always , when asked , discourse such pleasant music , that violoncello of [his]318-the warden — ah , how happy [he]318-the warden had been ! but it was over now ; [his]318-the warden easy days and absence of work had been the crime which brought on [him]318-the warden [his]318-the warden tribulation ; [[his]318-the warden shady home]3727-his shady home was pleasant no longer ; may be it was no longer [his]318-the warden ; [the old neighbours]3728-the old neighbours , whose welfare had been so desired by [him]318-the warden , were [[his]318-the warden enemies]3513-his enemies ; [[his]318-the warden daughter]280-his daughter was as wretched as [himself]318-the warden , and even [the bishop]260-the bishop was made miserable by [his]318-the warden position . [He]318-the warden could never again lift up [his]318-the warden voice boldly as [he]318-the warden had hitherto done among [[his]318-the warden brethren]2883-his brethren , for [he]318-the warden felt that [he]318-the warden was disgraced ; and [he]318-the warden feared even to touch [his]318-the warden bow , for [he]318-the warden knew how grievous a sound of wailing , how piteous a lamentation , it would produce . [He]318-the warden was still sitting in the same chair and the same posture , having hardly moved a limb for two hours , when [Eleanor]104-eleanor came back to tea , and succeeded in bringing [him]318-the warden with [her]104-eleanor into [the drawing - room]3243-the drawing - room . The tea seemed as comfortless as the dinner , though [the warden , who had hitherto eaten nothing all day]3734-the warden , who had hitherto eaten nothing all day , devoured the plateful of bread and butter , unconscious of what [he]318-the warden was doing . [Eleanor]104-eleanor had made up [her]104-eleanor mind to force [him]318-the warden to talk to [her]104-eleanor , but [she]104-eleanor hardly knew how to commence : [she]104-eleanor must wait till the urn was gone , till [the servant]3024-the servant would no longer be coming in and out . At last everything was gone , and the drawingroom door was permanently closed ; then [Eleanor]104-eleanor , getting up and going round to [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father , put [her]104-eleanor arm round [his]191-papa neck , and said , "[191-papa] [Papa]191-papa , wo n't [you]191-papa tell [me]0-i what it is ? " "[191-papa] What what is , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear ? " "[191-papa] This new sorrow that torments [you]191-papa ; [I]0-i know [you]191-papa are unhappy , [papa]2730-papa . " "[2730-papa] New sorrow ! it 's no new sorrow , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear , [we]1249-we have all [our]1249-we cares sometimes , " and [he]191-papa tried to smile , but it was a ghastly failure ; "[1249-we] but [I]0-i should n't be so dull [a companion]1250-a companion ; come , [we]1249-we 'll have some music . " "[2730-papa] No [papa]2730-papa , not to - night — it would only trouble [you]2730-papa to - night : " and [she]2725-my dear sat upon [his]191-papa knee , as [she]2725-my dear sometimes would in [their]1249-we gayest moods , and with [her]2725-my dear arm round [his]191-papa neck , [she]2725-my dear said , "[191-papa] [Papa]191-papa , [I]0-i will not leave [you]191-papa till [you]191-papa talk to [me]0-i ; oh , if [you]191-papa only knew how much good it would do to [you]191-papa , to tell [me]0-i of it all . " [The father]3737-the father kissed [[his]3737-the father daughter]280-his daughter , and pressed [her]280-his daughter to [his]3737-the father heart ; but still [he]3737-the father said nothing : it was so hard to [him]3737-the father to speak of [his]3737-the father own sorrows ; [he]3737-the father was so shy [a man even with [[his]3737-the father own child]3740-his own child]3739-a man even with his own child . "[2730-papa] Oh , [papa]2730-papa , do tell [me]0-i what it is ; [I]0-i know it is about [the hospital]364-the hospital , and what [they]1254-they are doing up in [London]13-london , and what [that cruel newspaper]1255-that cruel newspaper has said ; but if there be such cause for sorrow , let [us]1256-us be sorrowful together ; [we]1256-us are all in all to [each other]497-each other now : dear , [dear papa]1258-dear papa , do speak to [me]0-i . " [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding could not well speak now , for the warm tears were running down [his]102-mr. harding cheeks like rain in May , but [he]102-mr. harding held [[his]102-mr. harding child]3741-his child close to [his]102-mr. harding heart , and squeezed [her]3741-his child hand as [a lover]3742-a lover might , and [she]3741-his child kissed [his]102-mr. harding forehead and [his]102-mr. harding wet cheeks , and lay upon [his]102-mr. harding bosom , and comforted [him]102-mr. harding as [a woman only can do]3743-a woman only can do . "[1258-dear papa] [[My]0-i own child]1259-my own child , " [he]0-i said , as soon as [his]0-i tears would let [him]0-i speak ; "[1258-dear papa] [my]0-i own , [own child]1260-own child , why should [you]1259-my own child too be unhappy before it is necessary : it may come to that , that [we]1261-we must leave [this place]987-this place , but till that time comes , why should [your]1259-my own child young days be clouded ? " "[2730-papa] And is that all , [papa]2730-papa ? If that be all , let [us]1261-we leave it , and have light hearts elsewhere : if that be all , let [us]1261-we go . Oh , [papa]2730-papa , [you]2730-papa and [I]0-i could be happy if [we]1261-we had only bread to eat , so long as [our]1261-we hearts were light . " And [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's face was lighted up with enthusiasm as [she]104-eleanor told [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father how [he]293-her father might banish all [his]293-her father care ; and a gleam of joy shot across [his]293-her father brow as this idea of escape again presented itself , and [he]293-her father again fancied for a moment that [he]293-her father could spurn away from [him]293-her father the income which [the world]325-the world envied [him]293-her father ; that [he]293-her father could give the lie to [that wielder of the tomahawk who had dared to write such things of [him]293-her father in [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter]3746-that wielder of the tomahawk who had dared to write such things of him in the jupiter . That [he]293-her father could leave [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , and [Bold]121-bold , and the rest of [them]3748-their with [their]3748-their lawsuit among [them]3748-their , and wipe [his]293-her father hands altogether of so sorrow - stirring a concern . Ah , what happiness might there be in the distance , with [Eleanor]104-eleanor and [him]293-her father in [some small cottage]3749-some small cottage , and nothing left of [their]3748-their former grandeur but [their]3748-their music ! Yes , [they]3748-their would walk forth with [their]3748-their music books , and [their]3748-their instruments , and shaking the dust from off [their]3748-their feet as [they]3748-their went , leave [the ungrateful place]3750-the ungrateful place . Never did [a poor clergyman]3751-a poor clergyman sigh for a warm benefice more anxiously than [[our]3752-our warden]3570-our warden did now to be rid of [his]293-her father . "[2730-papa] Give it up , [papa]2730-papa , " [she]104-eleanor said again , jumping from [his]2730-papa knees and standing on [her]104-eleanor feet before [him]2730-papa , looking boldly into [his]2730-papa face ; "[2730-papa] give it up , [papa]2730-papa . " Oh , it was sad to see how that momentary gleam of joy passed away ; how the look of hope was dispersed from that sorrowful face , as the remembrance of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon came back upon [[our]3752-our poor warden]2911-our poor warden , and [he]2730-papa reflected that [he]2730-papa could not stir from [[his]2730-papa now hated post]3756-his now hated post . [He]2730-papa was as [a man bound with iron , fettered with adamant]3757-a man bound with iron , fettered with adamant : [he]2730-papa was in no respect [a free agent]3758-a free agent ; [he]2730-papa had no choice . "[2730-papa] Give it up ! " oh if [he]2730-papa only could : what an easy way that were out of all [his]2730-papa troubles ! "[191-papa] [Papa]191-papa do n't doubt about it , " [she]3759-she continued , thinking that [his]2730-papa hesitation arose from [his]2730-papa unwillingness to abandon so comfortable [a home]3760-a home ; "[191-papa] is it on [my]0-i account that [you]191-papa would stay [here]904-here ? Do [you]191-papa think that [I]0-i can not be happy without [a pony - carriage]1268-a pony - carriage and [a fine drawing - room]1269-a fine drawing - room ? [Papa]191-papa , [I]0-i never can be happy [here]904-here , as long as there is a question as to [your]191-papa honour in staying [here]904-here ; but [I]0-i could be gay as the day is long in [the smallest tiny little cottage]1272-the smallest tiny little cottage , if [I]0-i could see [you]191-papa come in and go out with a light heart . Oh ! [papa]2730-papa , [your]191-papa face tells so much ; though [you]191-papa wo n't speak to [me]0-i with [your]191-papa voice , [I]0-i know how it is with [you]191-papa every time [I]0-i look at [you]191-papa . " How [he]191-papa pressed [her]3761-her to [his]191-papa heart again with almost a spasmodic pressure ! how [he]191-papa kissed [her]3761-her as the tears fell like rain from [his]191-papa old eyes ! how [he]191-papa blessed [her]3761-her , and called [her]3761-her by a hundred soft sweet names which now came new to [his]191-papa lips ! how [he]191-papa chid [himself]191-papa for ever having been unhappy with such a treasure in [[his]191-papa house]660-his house , such a jewel on [his]191-papa bosom , with so sweet a flower in [the choice garden of [his]191-papa heart]3763-the choice garden of his heart ! and then the flood - gates of [his]191-papa tongue were loosed , and , at length , with unsparing detail of circumstances , [he]191-papa told [her]3761-her all that [he]191-papa wished , and all that [he]191-papa could not do .
