" and [he]0-i threw a small pamphlet across the table , which was all but damp from the press . [Bold]121-bold had not seen it nor heard of it ; but [he]121-bold was well acquainted with [the author of it]4126-the author of it — a gentleman whose pamphlets , [condemnatory of all things in these modern days]4127-condemnatory of all things in these modern days , had been a good deal talked about of late . [Dr. Pessimist Anticant]219-dr. pessimist anticant was [a Scotchman]4128-a scotchman , who had passed a great portion of [his]219-dr. pessimist anticant early days in [Germany]75-germany ; [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant had studied [there]713-there with much effect , and had learnt to look with German subtilty into the root of things , and to examine for [himself]219-dr. pessimist anticant their intrinsic worth and worthlessness . [No man]2761-no man ever resolved more bravely than [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant to accept as good nothing that was evil ; to banish from [him]219-dr. pessimist anticant as evil nothing that was good . ' Tis a pity that [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant should not have recognised the fact , that in [this world]2844-this world no good is unalloyed , and that there is but little evil that has not in it some seed of what is goodly . Returning from [Germany]75-germany , [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant had astonished [the reading public]4132-the reading public by the vigour of [his]219-dr. pessimist anticant thoughts , put forth in the quaintest language . [He]219-dr. pessimist anticant can not write English , said [the critics]4133-the critics . No matter , said [the public]2937-the public ; [we]2937-the public can read what [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant does write , and that without yawning . And so [Dr. Pessimist Anticant]219-dr. pessimist anticant became popular . [Popularity]220-popularity spoilt [him]219-dr. pessimist anticant for all further real use , as it has done many another . While , with some diffidence , [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant confined [his]219-dr. pessimist anticant objurgations to the occasional follies or short - comings of mankind ; while [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant ridiculed the energy of [the squire devoted to the slaughter of partridges]4135-the squire devoted to the slaughter of partridges , or the mistake of [some noble patron]4136-some noble patron who turned [a poet into a gauger of beer barrels]4137-a poet into a gauger of beer barrels , it was all well ; [we]2937-the public were glad to be told [our]2937-the public faults and to look forward to the coming millennium , when [all men]3341-all men , having sufficiently studied the works of [Dr. Anticant]219-dr. pessimist anticant , would become truthful and energetic . But [the doctor]613-the doctor mistook the signs of the times and the minds of [men]453-men , instituted [himself]613-the doctor censor of things in general , and began the great task of reprobating everything and [everybody]4141-everybody , without further promise of any millennium at all . This was not so well ; and , to tell the truth , [[our]2937-the public author]4142-our author did not succeed in [his]219-dr. pessimist anticant undertaking . [His]219-dr. pessimist anticant theories were all beautiful , and the code of morals that [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant taught [us]2937-the public certainly an improvement on the practices of the age . [[We]2937-the public all of [us]2937-the public]4143-we all of us could , and many of [us]2937-the public did , learn much from [the doctor]613-the doctor while [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant chose to remain vague , mysterious , and cloudy ; but when [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant became practical , the charm was gone . [His]219-dr. pessimist anticant allusion to [the poet and the partridges]4145-the poet and the partridges was received very well . ' Oh , [[my]0-i poor brother]4146-my poor brother , ' said [he]0-i , ' slaughtered partridges a score of brace to each gun , and [poets]4147-poets gauging ale barrels , with sixty pounds a - year , at Dumfries , are not the signs of a great era ! perhaps of the smallest possible era yet written of . Whatever economies [we]2937-the public pursue , political or other , let [us]2937-the public see at once that this is the maddest of the uneconomic : partridges killed by [[our]2937-the public land magnates]4148-our land magnates at , shall [we]2937-the public say , a guinea a - head , to be retailed in Leadenhall at one shilling and ninepence , with one poacher in limbo for every fifty birds ! [[our]2937-the public poet]4149-our poet , [maker]4150-maker , [creator]4151-creator , gauging ale , and that badly , with no leisure for making or creating , only a little leisure for drinking , and such like beer - barrel avocations ! Truly , a cutting of blocks with fine razors while [we]2937-the public scrape [our]2937-the public chins so uncomfortably with rusty knives ! Oh , [[my]0-i political economist]4152-my political economist , [master of supply and demand , division of labour and high pressure]4153-master of supply and demand , division of labour and high pressure — oh , [[my]0-i loud - speaking friend]4154-my loud - speaking friend , tell [me]0-i , if so much be in [you]4154-my loud - speaking friend , what is the demand for poets in [these kingdoms of [Queen Victoria]221-queen victoria]4155-these kingdoms of queen victoria , and what the vouchsafed supply ? ' This was all very well ; this gave [us]2937-the public some hope . [We]2937-the public were unwilling , however , to take lessons in politics from [so misty a professor]4158-so misty a professor ; and when [he]4158-so misty a professor came to tell [us]2937-the public that [the heroes of Westminster]4159-the heroes of westminster were naught , [we]2937-the public began to think that [he]4158-so misty a professor had written enough . [His]4158-so misty a professor attack upon despatch boxes was not thought to have much in it ; but as it is short , [the doctor]613-the doctor shall again be allowed to speak [his]4158-so misty a professor sentiments : — ' Could utmost ingenuity in the management of red tape avail anything to [men lying gasping]4161-men lying gasping — [we]2937-the public may say , all but dead ; could despatch boxes with never - so - much velvet lining and Chubb 's patent , be of comfort to [a people in extremis]4162-a people in extremis , [I]0-i also , with so many others , would , with parched tongue , call on the name of [Lord John Russell]130-lord john russell ; or , [[my]0-i brother]4163-my brother , at [your]4164-your advice , on [Lord Aberdeen]222-lord aberdeen ; or , [[my]0-i cousin]4165-my cousin , on [Lord Derby]223-lord derby , at [yours]4164-your ; being , with [my]0-i parched tongue , indifferent in such matters . ' There might be truth in this , there might be depth of reasoning ; but [Englishmen]4179-englishmen did not see enough in the argument to induce [them]4179-englishmen to withdraw [their]4179-englishmen confidence from the present arrangements of [the government]1597-the government , and [Dr. Anticant]219-dr. pessimist anticant 's monthly pamphlet on the decay of [the world]325-the world did not receive so much attention as [his]219-dr. pessimist anticant earlier works . [He]219-dr. pessimist anticant did not confine [himself]219-dr. pessimist anticant to politics in these publications , but roamed at large over all matters of public interest , and found everything bad . According to [him]219-dr. pessimist anticant [nobody]1025-nobody was true , and not only [nobody]1025-nobody , but nothing ; [a man]545-a man could not take off [his]545-a man hat to [a lady]4185-a lady without telling a lie — [the lady]612-the lady would lie again in smiling . The ruffles of [the gentleman]3851-the gentleman 's shirt would be fraught with deceit , and [the ladies]4188-the ladies ' flounces full of falsehood . Was ever anything more severe than that attack of [his]219-dr. pessimist anticant on chip bonnets , or the anathemas with which [he]219-dr. pessimist anticant endeavoured to dust the powder out of [the bishops]601-the bishops ' wigs ? The pamphlet which [Tom Towers]190-tom towers now pushed across the table was entitled "[0-i] Modern Charity , " and was written with the view of proving how much in the way of charity was done by [[our]4190-our predecessors]4191-our predecessors — how little by the present age ; and it ended by a comparison between ancient and modern times , very little to the credit of [the latter]3357-the latter . "[0-i] Look at this , " said [Towers]190-tom towers , getting up and turning over the pages of the pamphlet , and pointing to a passage near the end ; "[1728-the warden , who is so little selfish] [[your]1726-your friend]1371-your friend [the warden , who is so little selfish]1728-the warden , who is so little selfish , wo n't like that , [I]0-i fear . " [Bold]121-bold read as follows : — ' Heavens , what a sight ! Let [us]4190-our with eyes wide open see [the godly man of four centuries since]4193-the godly man of four centuries since , [the man of the dark ages]4194-the man of the dark ages : let [us]4190-our see how [he]4193-the godly man of four centuries since does [his]4193-the godly man of four centuries since godlike work , and , again , how [the godly man of these latter days]4195-the godly man of these latter days does [his]4193-the godly man of four centuries since . ' Shall [we]4190-our say that [the former]4196-the former is one walking painfully through [the world]325-the world , regarding , as [a prudent man]4198-a prudent man , [his]4193-the godly man of four centuries since worldly work , prospering in it as [a diligent man]4199-a diligent man will prosper , but always with an eye to that better treasure to which [thieves]4200-thieves do not creep in ? Is there not much nobility in [that old man]4201-that old man , as , leaning on [his]4201-that old man oaken staff , [he]4201-that old man walks down [the high street of [[his]4201-that old man native town]4203-his native town]4202-the high street of his native town , and receives from all courteous salutation and acknowledgment of [his]4201-that old man worth ? [A noble old man]4204-a noble old man , [[my]1729-you august inhabitants of [Belgrave Square]78-belgrave square and such like [vicinity]4206-vicinity]4205-my august inhabitants of belgrave square and such like vicinity — [a very noble old man]4207-a very noble old man , though employed no better than in the wholesale carding of wool . ' This carding of wool , however , did in those days bring with it much profit , so that [[our]4190-our ancient friend]4208-our ancient friend , when dying , was declared , in whatever slang then prevailed , to cut up exceeding well . For [sons]4209-sons and [daughters]264-daughters there was ample sustenance , with assistance of due industry ; for [friends]499-friends and [relatives]4212-relatives some relief for grief at this great loss ; for [aged dependants]4213-aged dependants comfort in declining years . This was much for [one old man]721-one old man to get done in that dark fifteenth century . But this was not all : coming [generations of poor woolcarders]4215-generations of poor woolcarders should bless the name of [this rich one]4216-this rich one ; and [a hospital]2922-a hospital should be founded and endowed with [his]4201-that old man wealth for the feeding of such of the trade as could not , by diligent carding , any longer duly feed [themselves]4213-aged dependants . '' Twas thus that [an old man in the fifteenth century]4218-an old man in the fifteenth century did [his]4201-that old man godlike work to the best of [his]4201-that old man power , and not ignobly , as appears to [me]1729-you . ' [We]4190-our will now take [[our]4190-our godly man]4219-our godly man of latter days . [He]4201-that old man shall no longer be [a woolcarder]4220-a woolcarder , for such are not now [men of mark]4221-men of mark . [We]4190-our will suppose [him]4201-that old man to be [one of the best of the good]4222-one of the best of the good — [one who has lacked no opportunities]4223-one who has lacked no opportunities . [[Our]4190-our old friend]4224-our old friend was , after all , but illiterate ; [[our]4190-our modern friend]4225-our modern friend shall be [a man educated in all seemly knowledge]4226-a man educated in all seemly knowledge ; [he]4201-that old man shall , in short , be that blessed being — [a clergyman of the Church of [England]14-england]4227-a clergyman of the church of england ! ' And now , in what perfectest manner does [he]4201-that old man in [this lower world]4228-this lower world get [his]4201-that old man godlike work done and put out of hand ? Heavens ! in the strangest of manners . Oh , [[my]1729-you brother]4163-my brother ! in a manner not at all to be believed but by the most minute testimony of eyesight . [He]4201-that old man does it by the magnitude of [his]4201-that old man appetite — by the power of [his]4201-that old man gorge ; [his]4201-that old man only occupation is to swallow the bread prepared with so much anxious care for [these impoverished carders of wool]4230-these impoverished carders of wool — that , and to sing indifferently through [his]4201-that old man nose once in the week some psalm more or less long — the shorter the better , [we]4190-our should be inclined to say . ' Oh , [[my]1729-you civilised friends!—great Britons that never will be [slaves]4232-slaves]4231-my civilised friends!—great britons that never will be slaves , [men advanced to infinite state of freedom and knowledge of good and evil]4233-men advanced to infinite state of freedom and knowledge of good and evil — tell [me]1729-you , will [you]4163-my brother , what becoming monument [you]4163-my brother will erect to [an highly - educated clergyman of the Church of [England]14-england]4234-an highly - educated clergyman of the church of england ? ' [Bold]121-bold certainly thought that [[his]121-bold friend]285-his friend would not like that : [he]121-bold could not conceive anything that [he]121-bold would like less than this . To what a world of toil and trouble had [he]121-bold , [Bold]121-bold , given rise by [his]121-bold indiscreet attack upon [the hospital]364-the hospital ! "[1729-you] [You]1729-you see , " said [Towers]190-tom towers , "[1729-you] that this affair has been much talked of , and [the public]2937-the public are with [you]1729-you . [I]0-i am sorry [you]1729-you should give the matter up . Have [you]1729-you seen the first number of the ' Almshouse ? ' " No ; [Bold]121-bold had not seen the ' Almshouse . ' [He]121-bold had seen advertisements of [Mr. Popular Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment 's new novel of that name , but had in no way connected it with [Barchester Hospital]29-barchester hospital , and had never thought a moment on the subject . "[1729-you] It 's a direct attack on the whole system , " said [Towers]190-tom towers . It 'll go a long way to put down [Rochester]16-rochester , and [Barchester]6-barchester , and [Dulwich]79-dulwich , and [St. Cross]19-st. cross , and all such hotbeds of peculation . It 's very clear that [Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment has been down to [Barchester]6-barchester , and got up the whole story there ; indeed , [I]121-bold thought [he]226-mr. sentiment must have had it all from [you]1729-you . It 's very well done , as [you]1729-you 'll see : [his]226-mr. sentiment first numbers always are . "[121-bold] [Bold]121-bold declared that [Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment had got nothing from [him]121-bold , and that [he]121-bold was deeply grieved to find that the case had become so notorious . " The fire has gone too far to be quenched , "[190-tom towers] said [Towers]190-tom towers ; " [the building]403-the building must go now ; and as the timbers are all rotten , why , [I]190-tom towers should be inclined to say , the sooner the better . [I]190-tom towers expected to see [you]1729-you get some éclat in the matter . "[190-tom towers] This was all wormwood to [Bold]121-bold . [He]121-bold had done enough to make [[his]121-bold friend]285-his friend [the warden]318-the warden miserable for life , and had then backed out just when the success of [his]121-bold project was sufficient to make the question one of real interest . How weakly [he]121-bold had managed [his]121-bold business ! [He]121-bold had already done the harm , and then stayed [his]121-bold hand when the good which [he]121-bold had in view was to be commenced . How delightful would it have been to have employed all [his]121-bold energy in such a cause — to have been backed by [the Jupiter]171-the jupiter , and written up to by two of [the most popular authors of the day]1733-the most popular authors of the day ! The idea opened a view into [the very world in which [he]121-bold wished to live]1734-the very world in which he wished to live . To what might it not have given rise ? what delightful intimacies — what public praise — to what Athenian banquets and rich flavour of Attic salt ? This , however , was now past hope . [He]121-bold had pledged [himself]121-bold to abandon the cause ; and could [he]121-bold have forgotten the pledge , [he]121-bold had gone too far to retreat . [He]121-bold was now , this moment , sitting in [[Tom Towers]190-tom towers ' room]1735-tom towers ' room with the object of deprecating any further articles in [the Jupiter]3310-the jupiter , and , greatly as [he]121-bold disliked the job , [his]121-bold petition to that effect must be made . " [I]121-bold could n't continue it , "[121-bold] said [he]121-bold , " because [I]121-bold found [I]121-bold was in the wrong . " In that case , "[121-bold] said [he]121-bold , " of course [you]121-bold must abandon it . "[121-bold] " And [I]121-bold called this morning to ask [you]190-tom towers also to abandon it , "[121-bold] said [Bold]121-bold . " To ask [me]190-tom towers , "[190-tom towers] said [Tom Towers]190-tom towers with the most placid of smiles , and a consummate look of gentle surprise , as though [Tom Towers]190-tom towers was well aware that [he]121-bold of [all men]3341-all men was the last to meddle in such matters . "[121-bold] " [[My]190-tom towers dear]2725-my dear [Bold]121-bold , "[190-tom towers] said [Tom Towers]190-tom towers , " [I]190-tom towers have a sincere regard for [you]190-tom towers . "[190-tom towers] " Interference ! "[121-bold] said [Bold]121-bold , " [I]121-bold do n't want to interfere . "[121-bold] " Ah , but [[my]190-tom towers dear fellow]2747-my dear fellow , [you]190-tom towers do ; what else is it ? [You]190-tom towers think that [I]190-tom towers am able to keep certain remarks out of a newspaper . [Your]190-tom towers information is probably incorrect , as most public gossip on such subjects is ; but , at any rate , [you]190-tom towers think [I]190-tom towers have such power , and [you]190-tom towers ask [me]190-tom towers to use it : now that is interference . "[190-tom towers] " Well , if [you]190-tom towers choose to call it so . "[190-tom towers] " And now suppose for a moment that [I]121-bold had this power , and used it as [you]190-tom towers wish : is n't it clear that it would be a great abuse ? [Certain men]4245-certain men are employed in writing for the public press ; and if [they]4245-certain men are induced either to write or to abstain from writing by private motives , surely the public press would soon be of little value . Look at the recognised worth of different newspapers , and see if it does not mainly depend on the assurance which [the public]2937-the public feel that such a paper is , or is not , independent . [You]190-tom towers alluded to the Jupiter : surely [you]190-tom towers can not but see that the weight of the Jupiter is too great to be moved by any private request , even though it should be made to [a much more influential person]4247-a much more influential person than [myself]121-bold : [you]190-tom towers 've only to think of this , and [you]190-tom towers 'll see that [I]121-bold am right . "[121-bold] The discretion of [Tom Towers]190-tom towers was boundless : there was no contradicting what [he]190-tom towers said , no arguing against such propositions . " [The public]2937-the public is defrauded , "[190-tom towers] said [he]190-tom towers , " whenever private considerations are allowed to have weight . "[190-tom towers] Quite true , [[thou]1740-thou greatest oracle of the middle of the nineteenth century]1741-thou greatest oracle of the middle of the nineteenth century , [[thou]1740-thou sententious proclaimer of the purity of the press]1742-thou sententious proclaimer of the purity of the press — [the public]2937-the public is defrauded when it is purposely misled . [Poor public]1744-poor public ! how often is it misled ! against what a world of fraud has it to contend ! ' [I]0-i know [he]190-tom towers wrote those articles , ' said [Bold]121-bold to [himself]0-i ; ' [I]0-i know [he]190-tom towers got [his]190-tom towers information from [me]0-i . Confound [his]190-tom towers arrogance ! What is any public question but a conglomeration of private interests ? What is any newspaper article but an expression of the views taken by one side ? Truth ! it takes an age to ascertain the truth of any question ! The idea of [Tom Towers]190-tom towers talking of public motives and purity of purpose ! Why , it would n't give [him]190-tom towers a moment 's uneasiness to change [his]190-tom towers politics to - morrow , if the paper required it . ' Such were [John Bold]121-bold 's inward exclamations as [he]121-bold made [his]121-bold way out of [the quiet labyrinth of [the Temple]1632-the temple]1750-the quiet labyrinth of the temple ; and yet there was no position of worldly power so coveted in [Bold]121-bold 's ambition as that held by [the man of whom [he]121-bold was thinking]1752-the man of whom he was thinking . It was the impregnability of the place which made [Bold]121-bold so angry with [the possessor of it]1753-the possessor of it , and it was the same quality which made it appear so desirable . Passing into [the Strand]1754-the strand , [he]121-bold saw in [a bookseller]1755-a bookseller 's window an announcement of the first number of the " Almshouse ; "[1755-a bookseller] so [he]121-bold purchased a copy , and hurrying back to [[his]121-bold lodgings]1756-his lodgings , proceeded to ascertain what [Mr. Popular Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment had to say to [the public]2937-the public on the subject which had lately occupied so much of [his]121-bold own attention . In former times great objects were attained by great work . When evils were to be reformed , [reformers]1758-reformers set about [their]1758-reformers heavy task with grave decorum and laborious argument . An age was occupied in proving a grievance , and philosophical researches were printed in folio pages , which it took a life to write , and an eternity to read . [We]1759-we get on now with a lighter step , and quicker : ridicule is found to be more convincing than argument , imaginary agonies touch more than true sorrows , and monthly novels convince , when learned quartos fail to do so . If [the world]325-the world is to be set right , the work will be done by shilling numbers . Of [all such reformers]1761-all such reformers [Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment is the most powerful . It is incredible the number of evil practices [he]226-mr. sentiment has put down : it is to be feared [he]226-mr. sentiment will soon lack [subjects]1762-subjects , and that when [he]226-mr. sentiment has made [the working classes]1763-the working classes comfortable , and got bitter beer put into proper - sized pint bottles , there will be nothing further for [him]226-mr. sentiment left to do . [Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment is certainly [a very powerful man]1764-a very powerful man , and perhaps not the less so that [[his]226-mr. sentiment good poor people]1765-his good poor people are so very good ; [[his]226-mr. sentiment hard rich people]1766-his hard rich people so very hard ; and the genuinely honest so very honest . [Namby - pamby]227-namby - pamby in these days is not thrown away if it be introduced in [the proper quarters]1767-the proper quarters . [Divine peeresses]1768-divine peeresses are no longer interesting , though possessed of every virtue ; but [a pattern peasant]1769-a pattern peasant or [an immaculate manufacturing hero]1770-an immaculate manufacturing hero may talk as much twaddle as [one of [[Mrs. Ratcliffe]228-mrs. ratcliffe 's heroines]1772-mrs. ratcliffe 's heroines]1771-one of mrs. ratcliffe 's heroines , and still be listened to . Perhaps , however , [Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment 's great attraction is in [[his]226-mr. sentiment second - rate characters]1773-his second - rate characters . If [[his]226-mr. sentiment heroes]1774-his heroes and [heroines]3220-heroines walk upon stilts , as [heroes]3950-heroes and [heroines]3220-heroines , [I]0-i fear , ever must , [their]1778-their attendant satellites are as natural as though [one]729-one met [them]1778-their in [the street]3876-the street : [they]1778-their walk and talk like [men]453-men and [women]3461-women , and live among [[our]1783-our friends]1784-our friends a rattling , lively life ; yes , live , and will live till the names of [their]1778-their callings shall be forgotten in [their]1778-their own , and [Buckett and Mrs. Gamp]229-buckett and mrs. gamp will be the only words left to [us]1783-our to signify [a detective police officer]1785-a detective police officer or [a monthly nurse]1786-a monthly nurse . " [The Almshouse]4249-the almshouse "[1076-a clergyman] opened with a scene in [[a clergyman]1076-a clergyman 's house]1788-a clergyman 's house . Every luxury to be purchased by wealth was described as being [there]713-there : all the appearances of household indulgence generally found among [the most self - indulgent of [the rich]1791-the rich]1790-the most self - indulgent of the rich were crowded into [this abode]1792-this abode . Here [the reader]3345-the reader was introduced to [the demon of the book]1794-the demon of the book , [the Mephistopheles of the drama]1795-the mephistopheles of the drama . What story was ever written without a demon ? what novel , what history , what work of any sort , [what world]1796-what world , would be perfect without existing principles both of good and evil ? The demon of [the " Almshouse]4250-the " almshouse "[1799-he] was [the clerical owner of [this comfortable abode]1798-this comfortable abode]1797-the clerical owner of this comfortable abode . [He]1799-he was [a man well stricken in years , but still strong to do evil]1800-a man well stricken in years , but still strong to do evil : [he]1799-he was one who looked cruelly out of a hot , passionate , bloodshot eye ; [who had a huge red nose with a carbuncle , thick lips , and a great double , flabby chin , which swelled out into solid substance , like a turkey cock]1801-who had a huge red nose with a carbuncle , thick lips , and a great double , flabby chin , which swelled out into solid substance , like a turkey cock 's comb , when sudden anger inspired [him]1799-he : [he]1799-he had a hot , furrowed , low brow , from which a few grizzled hairs were not yet rubbed off by the friction of [his]1799-he handkerchief : [he]1799-he wore a loose unstarched white handkerchief , black loose ill - made clothes , and huge loose shoes , adapted to many corns and various bunions : [his]1799-he husky voice told tales of much daily port wine , and [his]1799-he language was not so decorous as became [a clergyman]1076-a clergyman . [Such]1803-such was [the master of [[Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment 's " Almshouse]81-mr. sentiment 's " almshouse]4251-the master of mr. sentiment 's " almshouse . "[1799-he] [He]1799-he was [a widower]275-a widower , but at present accompanied by [two daughters]1805-two daughters , and [a thin and somewhat insipid curate]1806-a thin and somewhat insipid curate . [One of [the young ladies]1808-the young ladies]1807-one of the young ladies was devoted to [[her]1807-one of the young ladies father]293-her father and the fashionable world , and [she]1807-one of the young ladies of course was [the favourite]1810-the favourite ; [the other]762-the other was equally addicted to Puseyism and [the curate]1812-the curate . The second chapter of course introduced [the reader]3345-the reader to [the more especial inmates of [the hospital]364-the hospital]1814-the more especial inmates of the hospital . Here were discovered [eight old men]1816-eight old men ; and it was given to be understood that four vacancies remained unfilled , through the perverse ill - nature of [the clerical gentleman with the double chin]1817-the clerical gentleman with the double chin . The state of [these eight paupers]1818-these eight paupers was touchingly dreadful : sixpence - farthing a - day had been sufficient for [their]1818-these eight paupers diet when [the almshouse]4249-the almshouse was founded ; and on sixpence - farthing a - day were [they]1818-these eight paupers still doomed to starve , though food was four times as dear , and money four times as plentiful . It was shocking to find how the conversation of [these eight starved old men]1820-these eight starved old men in [[their]1818-these eight paupers dormitory]1821-their dormitory shamed that of [[the clergyman]1822-the clergyman 's family]1823-the clergyman 's family in [[his]1822-the clergyman rich drawing - room]1824-his rich drawing - room . The absolute words [they]1818-these eight paupers uttered were not perhaps spoken in the purest English , and it might be difficult to distinguish from [their]1818-these eight paupers dialect to [what part of [the country]452-the country]1825-what part of the country [they]1818-these eight paupers belonged ; the beauty of the sentiment , however , amply atoned for the imperfection of the language ; and it was really a pity that [these eight old men]1827-these eight old men could not be sent through [the country]452-the country as [moral missionaries]1829-moral missionaries , instead of being immured and starved in [that wretched almshouse]1830-that wretched almshouse . [Bold]121-bold finished the number ; and as [he]121-bold threw it aside , [he]121-bold thought that that at least had no direct appliance to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , and that the absurdly strong colouring of the picture would disenable the work from doing either good or harm . [He]121-bold was wrong . [The artist who paints for the million]1831-the artist who paints for the million must use glaring colours , as [no one]283-no one knew better than [Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment when [he]1831-the artist who paints for the million described [the inhabitants of [[his]1831-the artist who paints for the million almshouse]1834-his almshouse]1833-the inhabitants of his almshouse ; and the radical reform which has now swept over [such establishments]1835-such establishments has owed more to the twenty numbers of [Mr. Sentiment]226-mr. sentiment 's novel , than to all the true complaints which have escaped from the public for the last half century . [The warden]318-the warden had to make use of all [his]318-the warden very moderate powers of intrigue to give [[his]318-the warden son - in - law]440-his son - in - law the slip , and get out of [Barchester]6-barchester without being stopped on [[his]318-the warden road]1838-his road . [No schoolboy]1839-no schoolboy ever ran away from [school]522-school with more precaution and more dread of detection ; [no convict]1841-no convict , slipping down from a prison wall , ever feared to see [the gaoler]1842-the gaoler more entirely than [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding did to see [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law , as [he]102-mr. harding drove up in [the pony carriage]1844-the pony carriage to [the railway station]1845-the railway station , on the morning of [his]102-mr. harding escape to [London]13-london . The evening before [he]102-mr. harding went , [he]102-mr. harding wrote a note to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , explaining that [he]102-mr. harding should start on the morrow on [his]102-mr. harding journey ; that it was [his]102-mr. harding intention to see [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general if possible , and to decide on [his]102-mr. harding future plans in accordance with what [he]102-mr. harding heard from [that gentleman]687-that gentleman ; [he]102-mr. harding excused [himself]102-mr. harding for giving [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly no earlier notice , by stating that [his]102-mr. harding resolve was very sudden ; and having entrusted this note to [Eleanor]104-eleanor , with the perfect , though not expressed , understanding that it was to be sent over to [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi without haste , [he]102-mr. harding took [his]102-mr. harding departure . [He]102-mr. harding also prepared and carried with [him]102-mr. harding a note for [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham Haphazard , in which [he]102-mr. harding stated [his]102-mr. harding name , explaining that [he]102-mr. harding was [the defendant]1849-the defendant in the case of " [The Queen]4252-the queen on behalf of [the Wool - carders of Barchester]4253-the wool - carders of barchester v. Trustees under the will of [the late John Hiram]107-john hiram , "[102-mr. harding] for so was the suit denominated , and begged [the illustrious and learned gentleman]1850-the illustrious and learned gentleman to vouchsafe to [him]102-mr. harding ten minutes ' audience at any hour on the next day . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding calculated that for that one day [he]102-mr. harding was safe ; [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law , [he]102-mr. harding had no doubt , would arrive in [town]1852-town by [an early train]1853-an early train , but not early enough to reach [the truant]1854-the truant till [he]102-mr. harding should have escaped from [[his]102-mr. harding hotel]1855-his hotel after breakfast ; and could [he]102-mr. harding thus manage to see [the lawyer]1856-the lawyer on that very day , the deed might be done before [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon could interfere . On [his]102-mr. harding arrival in [town]1852-town [the warden]318-the warden drove , as was [his]102-mr. harding wo nt , to [the Chapter Hotel]1860-the chapter hotel and [Coffee House]82-coffee house , near [St. Paul 's]83-st. paul 's . [His]102-mr. harding visits to [London]13-london of late had not been frequent ; but in those happy days when [Harding]102-mr. harding 's church music was going through the press , [he]102-mr. harding had been often [there]713-there ; and as [[the publisher]433-the publisher 's house]1863-the publisher 's house was in [Paternoster Row]84-paternoster row , and [[the printer]1864-the printer 's press in [Fleet Street]64-fleet street]1865-the printer 's press in fleet street , [the Chapter Hotel]1860-the chapter hotel and [Coffee House]82-coffee house had been convenient . It was [a quiet , sombre , clerical house]1867-a quiet , sombre , clerical house , beseeming [such a man]637-such a man as [the warden]318-the warden , and thus [he]102-mr. harding afterwards frequented [it]1867-a quiet , sombre , clerical house . Had [he]102-mr. harding dared , [he]102-mr. harding would on this occasion have gone [elsewhere]1870-elsewhere to throw [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon further off the scent ; but [he]102-mr. harding did not know what violent steps [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law might take for [his]102-mr. harding recovery if [he]102-mr. harding were not found at [[his]102-mr. harding usual haunt]1873-his usual haunt , and [he]102-mr. harding deemed it not prudent to make [himself]102-mr. harding the object of a hunt through [London]13-london . Arrived at [[his]102-mr. harding inn]1874-his inn , [he]102-mr. harding ordered dinner , and went forth to [[the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general 's chambers]1876-the attorney - general 's chambers . There [he]102-mr. harding learnt that [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was in [Court]1877-court , and would not probably return that day . [He]102-mr. harding would go direct from [Court]1877-court to [the House]374-the house ; all appointments were , as a rule , made at [the chambers]1880-the chambers ; [the clerk]1881-the clerk could by no means promise an interview for the next day ; was able , on the other hand , to say that such interview was , [he]102-mr. harding thought , impossible ; but that [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham would certainly be at [the House]374-the house in the course of the night , when an answer from [himself]151-sir abraham might possibly be elicited . To [the House]374-the house [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding went , and left [his]102-mr. harding note , not finding [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham [there]713-there . [He]102-mr. harding added a most piteous entreaty that [he]102-mr. harding might be favoured with an answer that evening , for which [he]102-mr. harding would return . [He]102-mr. harding then journeyed back sadly to [the Chapter Coffee House]85-the chapter coffee house , digesting [his]102-mr. harding great thoughts , as best [he]102-mr. harding might , in [a clattering omnibus]1885-a clattering omnibus , wedged in between [a wet old lady]1886-a wet old lady and [a journeyman glazier]1887-a journeyman glazier , returning from [his]102-mr. harding work with [his]102-mr. harding tools in [his]102-mr. harding lap . In melancholy solitude [he]102-mr. harding discussed [his]102-mr. harding mutton chop and pint of port . What is there in [this world]2844-this world more melancholy than such a dinner ? A dinner , though alone , in [a country hotel]1889-a country hotel may be worthy of some energy ; [the waiter]1890-the waiter , if [you]1891-you are known , will make much of [you]1891-you ; [the landlord]1892-the landlord will make [you]1891-you a bow , and perhaps put the fish on the table ; if [you]1891-you ring [you]1891-you are attended to , and there is some life about it . A dinner at [a London eatinghouse]1893-a london eatinghouse is also lively enough , if it have no other attraction . There is plenty of noise and stir about it , and the rapid whirl of voices and rattle of dishes disperses sadness . But a solitary dinner in [an old , respectable , sombre , solid [London]13-london inn]1894-an old , respectable , sombre , solid london inn , where nothing makes any noise but [the old waiter]1895-the old waiter 's creaking shoes ; where one plate slowly goes and another slowly comes without a sound ; where [the two or three guests]1896-the two or three guests would as soon think of knocking [each other down as of speaking]1897-each other down as of speaking ; where [the servants]3421-the servants whisper , and [the whole household]1899-the whole household is disturbed if an order be given above the voice — what can be more melancholy than a mutton chop and a pint of port in [such a place]1900-such a place ? Having gone through this , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding got into another omnibus , and again returned to [the House]374-the house . yes , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was there , and was that moment on [his]151-sir abraham legs , fighting eagerly for the hundred and seventh clause of the Convent Custody Bill . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's note had been delivered to [him]151-sir abraham ; and if [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding would wait some two or three hours , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham could be asked whether there was any answer . [The House]374-the house was not full , and perhaps [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding might get admittance into [the Strangers ' Gallery]1903-the strangers ' gallery , which admission , with the help of five shillings , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was able to effect . This bill of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's had been read a second time and passed into committee . A hundred and six clauses had already been discussed , and had occupied only four mornings and five evening sittings ; nine of the hundred and six clauses were passed , fifty - five were withdrawn by consent , fourteen had been altered so as to mean the reverse of the original proposition , eleven had been postponed for further consideration , and seventeen had been directly negatived . The hundred and seventh ordered the bodily searching of [nuns]1904-nuns for Jesuitical symbols by [aged clergymen]1905-aged clergymen , and was considered to be the real mainstay of the whole bill . No intention had ever existed to pass such a law as that proposed , but [the government]1597-the government did not intend to abandon it till [their]1597-the government object was fully attained by the discussion of this clause . It was known that it would be insisted on with terrible vehemence by [Protestant Irish members]1907-protestant irish members , and as vehemently denounced by [the Roman Catholic]1908-the roman catholic ; and it was justly considered that no further union between [the parties]1909-the parties would be possible after such a battle . [The innocent Irish]1910-the innocent irish fell into the trap as [they]1910-the innocent irish always do , and whisky and poplins became a drug in the market . [A florid - faced gentleman with a nice head of hair]1911-a florid - faced gentleman with a nice head of hair , from [the south of [Ireland]86-ireland]1912-the south of ireland , had succeeded in catching [the speaker]1913-the speaker 's eye by the time that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had got into [the gallery]1914-the gallery , and was denouncing the proposed sacrilege , [his]102-mr. harding whole face glowing with a fine theatrical frenzy . " And is this [a Christian country]4254-a christian country ? "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding . ( Loud cheers ; counter cheers from the ministerial benches . ' Some doubt as to that , ' from a voice below the gangway . ) " No , it can be [no Christian country]4255-no christian country , in which [the head of the bar]4256-the head of the bar , [the lagal adviser]4257-the lagal adviser ( loud laughter and cheers)—yes , [I]102-mr. harding say [the lagal adviser of the crown ( great cheers and laughter,—can]4258-the lagal adviser of the crown ( great cheers and laughter,—can stand up in [his]102-mr. harding seat in [this house]4259-this house ( prolonged cheers and laughter ) , and attempt to lagalise indacent assaults on the bodies of [religious ladies]4260-religious ladies . "[102-mr. harding] ( Deafening cheers and laughter , which were prolonged till [the honourable member]1915-the honourable member resumed [his]1915-the honourable member seat . ) When [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had listened to this and much more of the same kind of about three hours , [he]102-mr. harding returned to the door of [the house]374-the house , and received back from [the messenger]1452-the messenger [his]102-mr. harding own note with the following words scrawled in pencil on the back of it:—"To - morrow , 10 P.M. — [[my]102-mr. harding chambers]4261-my chambers . A. H. "[102-mr. harding] [He]102-mr. harding was so far successful,—but 10 P.M. : what an hour [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham had named for a legal interview ! [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding felt perfectly sure that long before that [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly would be in [London]13-london . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly could not , however , know that this interview had been arranged , nor could [he]106-dr. grantly learn it unless [he]106-dr. grantly managed to get hold of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham before that hour ; and as this was very improbable , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding determined to start from [[his]102-mr. harding hotel]1855-his hotel early , merely leaving word that [he]102-mr. harding should dine out , and unless luck were much against [him]102-mr. harding , [he]102-mr. harding might still escape [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon till [his]102-mr. harding return from [[the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general 's chambers]1876-the attorney - general 's chambers . [He]102-mr. harding was at breakfast at nine , and for the twentieth time consulted [his]102-mr. harding " Bradshaw , "[382-the archdeacon] to see at what earliest hour [Dr Grantly]230-dr grantly could arrive from [Barchester]6-barchester . As [he]102-mr. harding examined the columns , [he]102-mr. harding was nearly petrified by the reflection that perhaps [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon might come up by [the night mail - train]1923-the night mail - train ! [His]102-mr. harding heart sank within [him]102-mr. harding at the horrid idea , and for a moment [he]102-mr. harding felt [himself]102-mr. harding dragged back to [Barchester]6-barchester without accomplishing any portion of [his]102-mr. harding object . Then [he]102-mr. harding remembered that had [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly done so , [he]106-dr. grantly would have been in [the hotel]1924-the hotel , looking for [him]106-dr. grantly long since . " [Waiter]4262-waiter , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding , timidly . [The waiter]1890-the waiter approached , creaking in [his]1890-the waiter shoes , but voiceless . " Did [any gentleman]4263-any gentleman — [a clergyman]1076-a clergyman , arrive [here]904-here by [the night mail - train]1923-the night mail - train ? "[1890-the waiter] " No , [sir]1337-sir , [not one]4268-not one , "[1890-the waiter] whispered [the waiter]1890-the waiter , putting [his]1890-the waiter mouth nearly close to [the warden]318-the warden 's ear . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was reassured . " [Waiter]4262-waiter , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding again , and [the waiter]1890-the waiter again creaked up ; " If [any one]431-any one calls for [me]1890-the waiter , [I]1890-the waiter am going to dine out , and shall return about eleven o'clock . "[1890-the waiter] [The waiter]1890-the waiter nodded , but did not this time vouchsafe any reply ; and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , taking up [his]102-mr. harding hat , proceeded out to pass a long day in the best way [he]102-mr. harding could , somewhere out of sight of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . " [Bradshaw]231-bradshaw "[102-mr. harding] had told [him]102-mr. harding twenty times that [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly could not be at [Paddington station]1931-paddington station till 2 P.M. , and [[our]1932-our poor friend]1933-our poor friend might therefore have trusted to [the shelter of [the hotel]1924-the hotel]1934-the shelter of the hotel for some hours longer with perfect safety ; but [he]102-mr. harding was nervous . There was no knowing what steps [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon might take for [his]102-mr. harding apprehension : a message by electric telegraph might desire [the landlord of [the hotel]1924-the hotel]1937-the landlord of the hotel to set a watch upon [him]102-mr. harding ; some letter might come which [he]102-mr. harding might find [himself]102-mr. harding unable to disobey ; at any rate , [he]102-mr. harding could not feel [himself]102-mr. harding secure in any place at which [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon could expect to find [him]102-mr. harding ; and at 10 A.M. [he]102-mr. harding started forth to spend twelve hours in [London]13-london . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had [friends]499-friends in [town]1852-town , had [he]102-mr. harding chosen to seek [them]499-friends ; but [he]102-mr. harding felt that [he]102-mr. harding was in no humour for ordinary calls , and [he]102-mr. harding did not now wish to consult with [any one]431-any one as to the great step which [he]102-mr. harding had determined to take . As [he]102-mr. harding had said to [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter , [no one]283-no one knows where the shoe pinches but [the wearer]1945-the wearer . There are some points on which [no man]2761-no man can be contented to follow the advice of [another]3704-another — some subjects on which [a man]545-a man can consult [his]545-a man own conscience only . [Our warden]3570-our warden had made up [his]3570-our warden mind that it was good for [him]3570-our warden at any cost to get rid of this grievance ; [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter was [the only person whose concurrence]1951-the only person whose concurrence appeared necessary to [him]102-mr. harding , and [she]280-his daughter did concur with [him]102-mr. harding most heartily . Under such circumstances [he]3570-our warden would not , if [he]3570-our warden could help it , consult [any one]431-any one further , till advice would be useless . Should [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon catch [him]102-mr. harding , indeed , there would be much advice , and much consultation of a kind not to be avoided ; but [he]3570-our warden hoped better things ; and as [he]3570-our warden felt that [he]3570-our warden could not now converse on indifferent subjects , [he]3570-our warden resolved to see [no one]283-no one till after [his]3570-our warden interview with [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general . [He]3570-our warden determined to take sanctuary in [Westminster Abbey]87-westminster abbey , so [he]3570-our warden again went thither in [an omnibus]1956-an omnibus , and finding that the doors were not open for morning service , [he]3570-our warden paid [his]3570-our warden twopence , and went in as [a sight - seer]1957-a sight - seer . It occurred to [him]3570-our warden that [he]3570-our warden had no definite place of rest for the day , and that [he]3570-our warden should be absolutely worn out before [his]3570-our warden interview if [he]3570-our warden attempted to walk about from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. , so [he]3570-our warden sat [himself]3570-our warden down on a stone step , and gazed up at the figure of [William Pitt]232-william pitt , who looks as though [he]232-william pitt had just entered [the church]454-the church for the first time in [his]232-william pitt life , and was anything but pleased at finding [himself]232-william pitt [there]713-there . [He]232-william pitt had been sitting unmolested about twenty minutes , when [the verger]1960-the verger asked [him]232-william pitt whether [he]232-william pitt would n't like to walk round . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding did n't want to walk anywhere , and declined , merely observing that [he]232-william pitt was waiting for the morning service . [The verger]1960-the verger seeing that [he]232-william pitt was [a clergyman]1076-a clergyman , told [him]232-william pitt that the doors of [the choir]1963-the choir were now open , and showed [him]232-william pitt into a seat . This was a great point gained ; [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon would certainly not come to morning service at [Westminster Abbey]87-westminster abbey , even though [he]382-the archdeacon were in [London]13-london ; and [here]904-here [the warden]318-the warden could rest quietly , and when the time came , duly say [his]318-the warden prayers . [He]232-william pitt longed to get up from [his]232-william pitt seat , and examine the music - books of [the choristers]1967-the choristers , and the copy of the litany from which the service was chanted , to see how far the little details at [Westminster]36-westminster corresponded with those at [Barchester]6-barchester , and whether [he]232-william pitt thought [his]232-william pitt own voice would fill [the church]454-the church well from [the [Westminster]36-westminster precentor 's seat]1969-the westminster precentor 's seat . There would , however , be impropriety in such meddling , and [he]232-william pitt sat perfectly still , looking up at the noble roof , and guarding against the coming fatigues of the day . By degrees [two or three people]1970-two or three people entered : [the very same damp old woman who had nearly obliterated [him]232-william pitt in the omnibus]1971-the very same damp old woman who had nearly obliterated him in the omnibus , or [some other just like [her]1971-the very same damp old woman who had nearly obliterated him in the omnibus]1972-some other just like her ; [a couple of [young ladies]1974-young ladies , with [their]1973-a couple of young ladies , with their veils down , and gilt crosses conspicuous on their prayer -
