[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was not much edified by the manner of the service . [The minor canon in question]1981-the minor canon in question hurried in , somewhat late , in a surplice not in the neatest order , and was followed by [a dozen choristers]1982-a dozen choristers , who were also not as trim as [they]1982-a dozen choristers might have been : [they]1982-a dozen choristers all jostled into [their]1982-a dozen choristers places with a quick hurried step , and the service was soon commenced . Soon commenced , and soon over , for there was no music , and time was not unnecessarily lost in the chanting . On the whole , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was of opinion that things were managed better at [Barchester]6-barchester , though even [there]713-there [he]102-mr. harding knew that there was room for improvement . It appears to [us]1984-us a question whether [any clergyman]1985-any clergyman can go through [our]1984-us church service with decorum , morning after morning , in [an immense building]1986-an immense building , surrounded by [not more than a dozen listeners]1987-not more than a dozen listeners . [The best actors]1988-the best actors can not act well before empty benches , and though there is , of course , a higher motive in one case than the other , still even the best of [clergymen]1200-clergymen can not but be influenced by [[their]1988-the best actors audience]1990-their audience ; and to expect that a duty should be well done under such circumstances , would be to require from human nature more than human power . When [the two ladies with the gilt crosses]1991-the two ladies with the gilt crosses , [the old man]3683-the old man with [his]3683-the old man crutch , and [the still palpitating housemaid]1993-the still palpitating housemaid were going , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding found [himself]102-mr. harding obliged to go too . [The verger]1960-the verger stood in [his]102-mr. harding way , and looked at [him]102-mr. harding and looked at the door , and so [he]102-mr. harding went . But [he]102-mr. harding returned again in a few minutes , and re - entered with another twopence . There was [no other sanctuary so good for [him]102-mr. harding]1995-no other sanctuary so good for him . As [he]102-mr. harding walked slowly down [the nave]1996-the nave , and then up [one aisle]1997-one aisle , and then again down [the nave]1996-the nave and up [the other aisle]1999-the other aisle , [he]102-mr. harding tried to think gravely of the step [he]102-mr. harding was about to take . [He]102-mr. harding was going to give up eight hundred a year voluntarily ; and doom [himself]102-mr. harding to live for the rest of [his]102-mr. harding life on about a hundred and fifty . [He]102-mr. harding knew that [he]102-mr. harding had hitherto failed to realise this fact as [he]102-mr. harding ought to do . Could [he]102-mr. harding maintain [his]102-mr. harding own independence and support [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter on a hundred and fifty pounds a year without being a burden on any one ? [[His]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law was rich , but nothing could induce [him]102-mr. harding to lean on [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law after acting , as [he]102-mr. harding intended to do , in most direct opposition to [his]102-mr. harding counsel . [The bishop]260-the bishop was rich , but [he]102-mr. harding was about to throw away [the bishop]260-the bishop 's best gift , and that in a manner to injure materially the patronage of [the giver]2005-the giver : [he]102-mr. harding could neither expect nor accept anything further from [the bishop]260-the bishop . There would be not only no merit , but positive disgrace , in giving up [his]102-mr. harding wardenship , if [he]102-mr. harding were not prepared to meet [the world]325-the world without it . Yes , [he]102-mr. harding must from this time forward bound all [his]102-mr. harding human wishes for [himself]102-mr. harding and [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter to the poor extent of so limited an income . [He]102-mr. harding knew [he]102-mr. harding had not thought sufficiently of this , that [he]102-mr. harding had been carried away by enthusiasm , and had hitherto not brought [home]3108-home to [himself]102-mr. harding the full reality of [his]102-mr. harding position . [He]102-mr. harding thought most about [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter , naturally . It was true that [she]280-his daughter was engaged , and [he]102-mr. harding knew enough of [[his]102-mr. harding proposed son - in - law]2011-his proposed son - in - law to be sure that [his]102-mr. harding own altered circumstances would make no obstacle to such a marriage ; nay , [he]102-mr. harding was sure that the very fact of [his]102-mr. harding poverty would induce [Bold]121-bold more anxiously to press the matter ; but [he]102-mr. harding disliked counting on [Bold]121-bold in this emergency , brought on , as it had been , by [his]102-mr. harding doing . [He]102-mr. harding did not like saying to [himself]102-mr. harding , [Bold]121-bold has turned [me]0-i out of [[my]0-i house]1320-my house and income , and , therefore , [he]121-bold must relieve [me]0-i of [[my]0-i daughter]2013-my daughter ; [he]102-mr. harding preferred reckoning on [Eleanor]104-eleanor as the companion of [his]102-mr. harding poverty and exile,—as [the sharer of [his]102-mr. harding small income]2014-the sharer of his small income . Some modest provision for [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter had been long since made . [His]102-mr. harding life was insured for three thousand pounds , and this sum was to go to [Eleanor]104-eleanor . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , for some years past , had paid the premium , and had secured [himself]102-mr. harding by the immediate possession of a small property which was to have gone to [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly after [[her]104-eleanor father]293-her father 's death . This matter , therefore , had been out of [the warden]318-the warden 's hands long since , as , indeed , had all the business transactions of [[his]102-mr. harding family]2019-his family , and [his]102-mr. harding anxiety was , therefore , confined to [his]102-mr. harding own life income . Yes . A hundred and fifty per annum was very small , but still it might suffice ; but how was [he]102-mr. harding to chant the litany at [the cathedral]258-the cathedral on Sunday mornings , and get the service done at [Crabtree Parva]42-crabtree parva ? True , [Crabtree Church]88-crabtree church was not quite a mile and a half from [the cathedral]258-the cathedral ; but [he]102-mr. harding could not be in two places at once ! [Crabtree]41-crabtree was [a small village]2022-a small village , and afternoon service might suffice , but still this went against [his]102-mr. harding conscience ; it was not right that [[his]102-mr. harding parishioners]2023-his parishioners should be robbed of any of [their]2023-his parishioners privileges on account of [his]102-mr. harding poverty . [He]102-mr. harding might , to be sure , make some arrangement for doing weekday service at [the cathedral]258-the cathedral , but [he]102-mr. harding had chanted the litany at [Barchester]6-barchester so long , and had a conscious feeling that [he]102-mr. harding did it so well , that [he]102-mr. harding was unwilling to give up the duty . Thinking of such things , turning over in [his]102-mr. harding own mind together small desires and grave duties , but never hesitating for a moment as to the necessity of leaving [the hospital]364-the hospital , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding walked up and down [the abbey]1977-the abbey , or sat still meditating on the same stone step , hour after hour . [One verger]2027-one verger went and another came , but [they]2028-they did not disturb [him]102-mr. harding ; every now and then [they]2028-they crept up and looked at [him]102-mr. harding , but [they]2028-they did so with a reverential stare , and , on the whole , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding found [his]102-mr. harding retreat well chosen . About four o'clock [his]102-mr. harding comfort was disturbed by [an enemy in the shape of hunger]2029-an enemy in the shape of hunger ; it was necessary that [he]102-mr. harding should dine , and it was clear that [he]102-mr. harding could not dine in [the abbey]1977-the abbey ; so [he]102-mr. harding left [[his]102-mr. harding sanctuary]2031-his sanctuary not willingly , and betook [himself]102-mr. harding to [the neighbourhood of [the Strand]89-the strand]2032-the neighbourhood of the strand to look for food . [His]102-mr. harding eyes had become so accustomed to the gloom of [the church]454-the church , that they were dazed when [he]102-mr. harding got out into the full light of day , and [he]102-mr. harding felt confused and ashamed of [himself]102-mr. harding , as though [people]1126-people were staring at [him]102-mr. harding . [He]102-mr. harding hurried along , still in dread of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , till [he]102-mr. harding came to [Charing Cross]90-charing cross , and then remembered that in one of [his]102-mr. harding passages through [the Strand]1754-the strand [he]102-mr. harding had seen the words " Chops and Steaks "[382-the archdeacon] on a placard in a shop window . [He]102-mr. harding remembered [the shop]2037-the shop distinctly ; [it]2037-the shop was next door to [a trunkseller 's]2038-a trunkseller 's , and there was [a cigar shop]2039-a cigar shop on the other side . [He]102-mr. harding could n't go to [[his]102-mr. harding hotel]1855-his hotel for dinner , which to [him]102-mr. harding hitherto was the only known mode of dining in [London]13-london at [his]102-mr. harding own expense ; and , therefore , [he]102-mr. harding would get a steak at [the shop in [the Strand]1754-the strand]2041-the shop in the strand . [Archdeacon Grantly]113-archdeacon grantly would certainly not come to such a place for [his]102-mr. harding dinner . [He]102-mr. harding found [the house]374-the house easily — just as [he]102-mr. harding had observed [it]374-the house , between the trunks and the cigars . [He]102-mr. harding was rather daunted by the huge quantity of fish which [he]102-mr. harding saw in the window . There were barrels of oysters , hecatombs of lobsters , a few tremendous - looking crabs , and a tub full of pickled salmon ; not , however , being aware of any connexion between shell - fish and iniquity , [he]102-mr. harding entered , and modestly asked [a slatternly woman]2044-a slatternly woman , who was picking oysters out of a great watery reservoir , whether [he]102-mr. harding could have a mutton chop and a potatoe . [The woman]2045-the woman looked somewhat surprised , but answered in the affirmative , and [a slipshod girl]2046-a slipshod girl ushered [him]102-mr. harding into [a long back room , filled with boxes for the accommodation of parties]2047-a long back room , filled with boxes for the accommodation of parties , in one of which [he]102-mr. harding took [his]102-mr. harding seat . In [a more miserably forlorn place [he]102-mr. harding could not have found [himself]102-mr. harding]2048-a more miserably forlorn place he could not have found himself : [the room]3355-the room smelt of fish , and sawdust , and stale tobacco smoke , with a slight taint of escaped gas ; everything was rough , and dirty , and disreputable ; the cloth which [they]2050-they put before [him]102-mr. harding was abominable ; the knives and forks were bruised , and hacked , and filthy ; and everything was impregnated with fish . [He]102-mr. harding had one comfort , however : [he]102-mr. harding was quite alone ; there was [no one there]3952-no one there to look on [his]102-mr. harding dismay ; nor was it probable that [any one]431-any one would come to do so . It was [a London supper - house]2053-a london supper - house . About one o ' clock at night [the place]794-the place would be lively enough , but at the present time [his]102-mr. harding seclusion was as deep as it had been in [the abbey]1977-the abbey . In about half an hour [the untidy girl]2056-the untidy girl , not yet dressed for [her]2056-the untidy girl evening labours , brought [him]102-mr. harding [his]102-mr. harding chop and potatoes , and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding begged for a pint of sherry . [He]102-mr. harding was impressed with an idea , which was generally prevalent a few years since , and is not yet wholly removed from the minds of [men]453-men , that to order a dinner at [any kind of inn]2058-any kind of inn , without also ordering a pint of wine for the benefit of [the landlord]1892-the landlord , was a kind of fraud ; not punishable , indeed , by law , but not the less abominable on that account . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding remembered [his]102-mr. harding coming poverty , and would willingly have saved [his]102-mr. harding half - crown , but [he]102-mr. harding thought [he]102-mr. harding had no alternative ; and [he]102-mr. harding was soon put in possession of some horrid mixture procured from [the neighbouring public - house]2060-the neighbouring public - house . [His]102-mr. harding chop and potatoes , however , were eatable , and having got over as best [he]102-mr. harding might the disgust created by the knives and forks , [he]102-mr. harding contrived to swallow [his]102-mr. harding dinner . [He]102-mr. harding was not much disturbed : [one young man , with pale face and watery fish - like eyes]2061-one young man , with pale face and watery fish - like eyes , wearing [his]2061-one young man , with pale face and watery fish - like eyes hat ominously on one side , did come in and stare at [him]102-mr. harding , and ask [the girl]2062-the girl , audibly enough , ' Who [that old cock]2063-that old cock was ; ' but the annoyance went no further , and [the warden]318-the warden was left seated on [his]318-the warden wooden bench in peace , endeavouring to distinguish the different scents arising from lobsters , oysters , and salmon . Unknowing as [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was in the ways of [London]13-london , [he]102-mr. harding felt that [he]102-mr. harding had somehow selected [an ineligible dining - house]2065-an ineligible dining - house , and that [he]102-mr. harding had better leave [it]2065-an ineligible dining - house . It was hardly five o'clock — how was [he]102-mr. harding to pass the time till ten ? Five miserable hours ! [He]102-mr. harding was already tired , and it was impossible that [he]102-mr. harding should continue walking so long . [He]102-mr. harding thought of getting into [an omnibus]1956-an omnibus , and going out to [Fulham]91-fulham for the sake of coming back in another : this , however , would be weary work , and as [he]102-mr. harding paid [his]102-mr. harding bill to [the woman in [the shop]2037-the shop]2067-the woman in the shop , [he]102-mr. harding asked [her]2067-the woman in the shop if there were any place near where [he]102-mr. harding could get a cup of coffee . Though [she]2067-the woman in the shop did keep a shell - fish supper - house , [she]2067-the woman in the shop was very civil , and directed [him]102-mr. harding to [the cigar divan on the other side of [the street]3876-the street]2069-the cigar divan on the other side of the street . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding had not a much correcter notion of a cigar divan than [he]102-mr. harding had of [a London dinner - house]2071-a london dinner - house , but [he]102-mr. harding was desperately in want of rest , and went as [he]102-mr. harding was directed . [He]102-mr. harding thought [he]102-mr. harding must have made some mistake when [he]102-mr. harding found [himself]102-mr. harding in [a cigar shop]2039-a cigar shop , but [the man behind the counter]2073-the man behind the counter saw immediately that [he]102-mr. harding was [a stranger]3873-a stranger , and understood what [he]102-mr. harding wanted . " One shilling , [sir]1337-sir — thank [ye]1337-sir , [sir]1337-sir — cigar , [sir]1337-sir ? — ticket for coffee , [sir]1337-sir — [you'll]1337-sir only have to call [the waiter]1890-the waiter . Up [those stairs]4276-those stairs , if [you]1337-sir please , [sir]1337-sir . Better take the cigar , [sir]1337-sir — [you]1337-sir can always give it to [a friend [you]1337-sir know]4279-a friend you know . Well , [sir]1337-sir , thank [ye]1337-sir , [sir]1337-sir — as [you]1337-sir are so good , [I]102-mr. harding 'll smoke it [myself]102-mr. harding . "[102-mr. harding] And so [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ascended to [the divan]2075-the divan , with [his]102-mr. harding ticket for coffee , but minus the cigar . [The place]794-the place seemed much more suitable to [his]102-mr. harding requirements than [the room in which [he]102-mr. harding had dined]2077-the room in which he had dined : there was , to be sure , a strong smell of tobacco , to which [he]102-mr. harding was not accustomed ; but after the shellfish , the tobacco did not seem disagreeable . There were quantities of books , and long rows of sofas . What on earth could be more luxurious than a sofa , a book , and a cup of coffee ? [An old waiter]2078-an old waiter came up to [him]102-mr. harding , with a couple of magazines and an evening paper . Was ever anything so civil ? Would [he]102-mr. harding have a cup of coffee , or would [he]102-mr. harding prefer sherbet ? [Sherbet]233-sherbet ! Was [he]102-mr. harding absolutely in [an Eastern divan]2079-an eastern divan , with the slight addition of all the [London]13-london periodicals ? [He]102-mr. harding had , however , an idea that sherbet should be drank sitting cross - legged , and as [he]102-mr. harding was not quite up to this , [he]102-mr. harding ordered the coffee . The coffee came , and was unexceptionable . Why , [this divan]2080-this divan was [a paradise]2081-a paradise ! [The civil old waiter]2082-the civil old waiter suggested to [him]102-mr. harding a game of chess : though [a chess player]2083-a chess player [he]102-mr. harding was not equal to this , so [he]102-mr. harding declined , and , putting up [his]102-mr. harding weary legs on the sofa , leisurely sipped [his]102-mr. harding coffee , and turned over the pages of [his]102-mr. harding Blackwood . [He]102-mr. harding might have been so engaged for about an hour , for [the old waiter]1895-the old waiter enticed [him]102-mr. harding to a second cup of coffee , when a musical clock began to play . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding then closed [his]102-mr. harding magazine , keeping [his]102-mr. harding place with [his]102-mr. harding finger , and lay , listening with closed eyes to the clock . Soon the clock seemed to turn into a violoncello , with piano accompaniments , and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding began to fancy [the old waiter]1895-the old waiter was [the Bishop of [Barchester]6-barchester]2086-the bishop of barchester ; [he]102-mr. harding was inexpressibly shocked that [the bishop]260-the bishop should have brought [him]102-mr. harding [his]102-mr. harding coffee with [his]102-mr. harding own hands ; then [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly came in , with a basket full of lobsters , which [he]106-dr. grantly would not be induced to leave down [stairs]2088-stairs in [the kitchen]2089-the kitchen ; and then [the warden]318-the warden could n't quite understand why [so many people]2091-so many people would smoke in [[the bishop]260-the bishop 's drawing - room]2093-the bishop 's drawing - room ; and so [he]102-mr. harding fell fast asleep , and [his]102-mr. harding dreams wandered away to [[his]102-mr. harding accustomed stall in [Barchester Cathedral]8-barchester cathedral]2094-his accustomed stall in barchester cathedral , and [the twelve old men [he]102-mr. harding was so soon about to leave for ever]2095-the twelve old men he was so soon about to leave for ever . [He]102-mr. harding was fatigued , and slept soundly for some time . Some sudden stop in the musical clock woke [him]102-mr. harding at length , and [he]102-mr. harding jumped up with a start , surprised to find [the room]3355-the room quite full ; [it]3355-the room had been nearly empty when [his]102-mr. harding nap began . With nervous anxiety [he]102-mr. harding pulled out [his]102-mr. harding watch , and found that it was half - past nine . [He]102-mr. harding seized [his]102-mr. harding hat , and , hurrying down stairs , started at a rapid pace for [Lincoln 's Inn]22-lincoln 's inn . It still wanted twenty minutes to ten when [the warden]318-the warden found [himself]318-the warden at [the bottom of [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's stairs]2098-the bottom of sir abraham 's stairs , so [he]102-mr. harding walked leisurely up and down [the quiet inn]2099-the quiet inn to cool [himself]102-mr. harding . It was a beautiful evening at the end of August . [He]102-mr. harding had recovered from [his]102-mr. harding fatigue ; [his]102-mr. harding sleep and the coffee had refreshed [him]102-mr. harding , and [he]102-mr. harding was surprised to find that [he]102-mr. harding was absolutely enjoying [himself]102-mr. harding , when [the inn]2100-the inn clock struck ten . The sound was hardly over before [he]102-mr. harding knocked at [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham 's door , and was informed by [the clerk who received [him]102-mr. harding]2101-the clerk who received him that [the great man]3592-the great man would be with [him]102-mr. harding immediately . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was shown into [a comfortable inner sitting - room]2103-a comfortable inner sitting - room , looking more like [[a gentleman]2104-a gentleman 's book - room]2105-a gentleman 's book - room than [[a lawyer]605-a lawyer 's chambers]2107-a lawyer 's chambers , and there waited for [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham . Nor was [he]102-mr. harding kept waiting long : in ten or fifteen minutes [he]102-mr. harding heard a clatter of voices speaking quickly in [the passage]2108-the passage , and then [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general entered . " Very sorry to keep [you]102-mr. harding waiting , [Mr. Warden]234-mr. warden , "[151-sir abraham] said [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , shaking hands with [him]102-mr. harding ; " and sorry , too , to name so disagreeable an hour ; but [your]102-mr. harding notice was short , and as [you]102-mr. harding said to - day , [I]151-sir abraham named the very earliest hour that was not disposed of . "[151-sir abraham] [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding assured [him]151-sir abraham that [he]102-mr. harding was aware that it was [he]151-sir abraham that should apologise . [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was [a tall thin man]2110-a tall thin man , with hair prematurely grey , but bearing no other sign of age ; [he]151-sir abraham had a slight stoop , in [his]151-sir abraham neck rather than [his]151-sir abraham back , acquired by [his]151-sir abraham constant habit of leaning forward as [he]151-sir abraham addressed [[his]151-sir abraham various audiences]2111-his various audiences . [He]151-sir abraham might be fifty years old , and would have looked young for [his]151-sir abraham age , had not constant work hardened [his]151-sir abraham features , and given [him]151-sir abraham the appearance of [a machine with a mind]2112-a machine with a mind . [His]151-sir abraham face was full of intellect , but devoid of natural expression . [You]2113-you would say [he]151-sir abraham was [a man to use , and then have done with]2114-a man to use , and then have done with ; [a man to be sought for on great emergencies]2115-a man to be sought for on great emergencies , but ill adapted for ordinary services ; [a man whom [you]2113-you would ask to defend [your]2113-you property]2116-a man whom you would ask to defend your property , but to whom [you]2113-you would be sorry to confide [your]2113-you love . [He]151-sir abraham was bright as a diamond , and as cutting , and also as unimpressionable . [He]151-sir abraham knew [every one whom to know]2117-every one whom to know was an honour , but [he]151-sir abraham was without [a friend]1011-a friend ; [he]151-sir abraham wanted none , however , and knew not the meaning of the word in other than its parliamentary sense . [A friend]1011-a friend ! Had [he]151-sir abraham not always been sufficient to [himself]151-sir abraham , and now , at fifty , was it likely that [he]151-sir abraham should trust [another]3704-another ? [He]151-sir abraham was married , indeed , and had [children]3456-children , but what time had [he]151-sir abraham for the soft idleness of conjugal felicity ? [His]151-sir abraham working days or term times were occupied from [his]151-sir abraham time of rising to the late hour at which [he]151-sir abraham went to rest , and even [his]151-sir abraham vacations were more full of labour than the busiest days of [other men]2122-other men . [He]151-sir abraham never quarrelled with [[his]151-sir abraham wife]607-his wife , but [he]151-sir abraham never talked to [her]607-his wife , — [he]151-sir abraham never had time to talk , [he]151-sir abraham was so taken up with speaking . [She]607-his wife , [poor lady]2124-poor lady , was not unhappy ; [she]607-his wife had all that money could give [her]607-his wife , [she]607-his wife would probably live to be [a peeress]2125-a peeress , and [she]607-his wife really thought [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham the best of [husbands]2126-husbands . [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was [a man of wit , and sparkled among the brightest at the dinner - tables of political grandees]2127-a man of wit , and sparkled among the brightest at the dinner - tables of political grandees ; indeed , [he]151-sir abraham always sparkled ; whether in society , in [the House of Commons]446-the house of commons , or [the courts of law]2129-the courts of law , coruscations flew from [him]151-sir abraham ; glittering sparkles , as from hot steel , but no heat ; no cold heart was ever cheered by warmth from [him]151-sir abraham , [no unhappy soul]2130-no unhappy soul ever dropped a portion of its burden at [his]151-sir abraham door . With [him]151-sir abraham success alone was praiseworthy , and [he]151-sir abraham knew none so successful as [himself]151-sir abraham . [No one]283-no one had thrust [him]151-sir abraham forward ; [no powerful friends]2132-no powerful friends had pushed [him]151-sir abraham along on [his]151-sir abraham road to power . No , [he]151-sir abraham was [attorney - general]2133-attorney - general , and would , in all human probability , be [lord chancellor]2134-lord chancellor by sheer dint of [his]151-sir abraham own industry and [his]151-sir abraham own talent . Who else in [all the world]2135-all the world rose so high with so little help ? [A premier]2136-a premier , indeed ! Who had ever been [premier without mighty friends]2137-premier without mighty friends ? [An archbishop]2138-an archbishop ! Yes , [the son or grandson of [a great noble]2140-a great noble]2139-the son or grandson of a great noble , or else , probably , [[his]2139-the son or grandson of a great noble tutor]2141-his tutor . But [he]151-sir abraham , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , had had [no mighty lord]2142-no mighty lord at [his]151-sir abraham back ; [[his]151-sir abraham father]508-his father had been [a country apothecary]2144-a country apothecary , [[his]151-sir abraham mother]2145-his mother a [[farmer]351-farmer 's daughter]2147-farmer 's daughter . Why should [he]151-sir abraham respect any but [himself]151-sir abraham ? And so [he]151-sir abraham glitters along through [the world]325-the world , the brightest among the bright ; and when [his]151-sir abraham glitter is gone , and [he]151-sir abraham is gathered to [[his]151-sir abraham fathers]2149-his fathers , no eye will be dim with a tear , no heart will mourn for [[its]2150-its lost friend]2151-its lost friend . " And so , [Mr. Warden]234-mr. warden , "[151-sir abraham] said [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , " all [our]4282-our trouble about this law - suit is at an end . " [I]151-sir abraham know [I]151-sir abraham have no right to trouble [you]151-sir abraham personally with this matter , but as it is of most vital importance to [me]151-sir abraham , as all [my]151-sir abraham happiness is concerned in it , [I]151-sir abraham thought [I]151-sir abraham might venture to seek [your]151-sir abraham own advice . " Of course , "[3357-the latter] said [the latter]3357-the latter , " if [you]102-mr. harding have private means sufficient for [your]102-mr. harding wants , and if this — "[3357-the latter] " [I]318-the warden have n't a sixpence , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , "[318-the warden] said [the warden]318-the warden . " God bless [me]318-the warden ! Why , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , how do [you]102-mr. harding mean to live ? "[318-the warden] [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding proceeded to explain to [the man of law]2165-the man of law that [he]102-mr. harding meant to keep [his]102-mr. harding precentorship,—that was eighty pounds a year ; and , also , that [he]102-mr. harding meant to fall back upon [his]102-mr. harding own little living of [Crabtree]41-crabtree , which was another eighty pounds . That , to be sure , the duties of [the two]4110-the two were hardly compatible ; but perhaps [he]102-mr. harding might effect an exchange . And then , recollecting that [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general would hardly care to hear how the service of [a cathedral church]2168-a cathedral church is divided among [the minor canons]2169-the minor canons , stopped short in [his]102-mr. harding explanations . " [I]151-sir abraham really think , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , [you]102-mr. harding had better wait for [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon . [A man]545-a man is never [the best judge of [his]545-a man own position]4298-the best judge of his own position . "[151-sir abraham] " [A man]545-a man is the best judge of what [he]545-a man feels [himself]545-a man . [I]102-mr. harding 'd sooner beg [my]102-mr. harding bread till [my]102-mr. harding death , than read such another article as those two that have appeared , and feel , as [I]102-mr. harding do , that [the writer]4300-the writer has truth on [his]4300-the writer side . "[102-mr. harding] " Have [you]2170-his not [a daughter]4301-a daughter , [Mr. Harding,—an unmarried daughter]4302-mr. harding,—an unmarried daughter ? "[151-sir abraham] " [I]2170-his have , "[2170-his] said [he]2170-his , now standing also , but still playing away on [his]2170-his fiddle with [his]2170-his hand behind [his]2170-his back . " [I]2170-his have , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham ; and [she]4301-a daughter and [I]2170-his are completely agreed on this subject . "[2170-his] " Pray excuse [me]318-the warden , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , if what [I]318-the warden say seems impertinent : but surely it is [you]102-mr. harding that should be prudent on [her]4301-a daughter behalf . [She]4301-a daughter is young , and does not know the meaning of living on an income of a hundred and fifty pounds a year . On [her]4301-a daughter account give up this idea . Believe [me]318-the warden , it is sheer Quixotism . "[318-the warden] [The warden]318-the warden walked away to the window , and then back to [his]2170-his chair ; and then , irresolute what to say , took another turn to the window . [The attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general was really extremely patient , but [he]3508-the attorney - general was beginning to think that the interview had been long enough . " But if this income be not justly [mine]318-the warden , what if [she]4301-a daughter and [I]318-the warden have both to beg ? "[318-the warden] said [the warden]318-the warden at last , sharply , and in a voice so different from that [he]318-the warden had hitherto used , that [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham was startled . " If so , it would be better to beg . "[318-the warden] " [[My]2174-i dear [sir]1337-sir]4292-my dear sir , [nobody]1025-nobody now questions its justness . "[2174-i] " Yes , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , [one]729-one does question it,—the most important of [all witnesses]4307-all witnesses against me,—I question it [myself]2174-i . [[My]2174-i God]4308-my god knows whether or no [I]2174-i love [[my]2174-i daughter]2013-my daughter ; but [I]2174-i would sooner that [she]4301-a daughter and [I]2174-i should both beg , than that [she]4301-a daughter should live in comfort on money which is truly the property of [the poor]1029-the poor . It may seem strange to [you]151-sir abraham , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , it is strange to [myself]2174-i , that [I]2174-i should have been ten years in [that happy home]4311-that happy home , and not have thought of these things , till they were so roughly dinned into [my]2174-i ears . [I]2174-i can not boast of [my]2174-i conscience , when it required the violence of a public newspaper to awaken it ; but , now that it is awake , [I]2174-i must obey it . When [I]2174-i came [here]904-here [I]2174-i did not know that the suit was withdrawn by [Mr. Bold]122-mr. bold , and [my]2174-i object was to beg [you]151-sir abraham to abandon [my]2174-i defence . As there is no action , there can be no defence ; but it is , at any rate , as well that [you]151-sir abraham should know that , from to - morrow , [I]2174-i shall cease to be [the warden of [the hospital]364-the hospital]2799-the warden of the hospital . [[My]2174-i friends]989-my friends and [I]2174-i differ on this subject , [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , and that adds much to [my]2174-i sorrow : but it can not be helped . "[2174-i] And , as [he]2174-i finished what [he]2174-i had to say , [he]2174-i played up such a tune as never before had graced the chambers of [any attorney - general]2175-any attorney - general . [He]2174-i was standing up , gallantly fronting [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , and [his]2174-i right arm passed with bold and rapid sweeps before [him]2174-i , as though [he]2174-i were embracing some huge instrument , which allowed [him]2174-i to stand thus erect ; and with the fingers of [his]2174-i left hand [he]2174-i stopped , with preternatural velocity , a multitude of strings , which ranged from the top of [his]2174-i collar to the bottom of the lappet of [his]2174-i coat . [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham listened and looked in wonder . As [he]151-sir abraham had never before seen [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , the meaning of these wild gesticulations was lost upon [him]151-sir abraham ; but [he]151-sir abraham perceived that [the gentleman who had a few minutes since been so subdued as to be unable to speak without hesitation]2176-the gentleman who had a few minutes since been so subdued as to be unable to speak without hesitation , was now impassioned — nay , almost violent . " [You]102-mr. harding 'll sleep on this , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , and to - morrow — "[318-the warden] " [I]318-the warden have done more than sleep upon it , "[318-the warden] said [the warden]318-the warden ; " [I]318-the warden have laid awake upon it , and that night after night . [I]318-the warden found [I]318-the warden could not sleep upon it ; now [I]318-the warden hope to do so . "[318-the warden] [The attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general had no answer to make to this ; so [he]3508-the attorney - general expressed a quiet hope that whatever settlement was finally made would be satisfactory ; and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding withdrew , thanking [the great man]3592-the great man for [his]3592-the great man kind attention . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was sufficiently satisfied with the interview to feel a glow of comfort as [he]102-mr. harding descended into [the small old square of [Lincoln 's Inn]22-lincoln 's inn]2180-the small old square of lincoln 's inn . It was a calm , bright , beautiful night , and by the light of the moon , even [the chapel of [Lincoln 's Inn]22-lincoln 's inn]2181-the chapel of lincoln 's inn , and [the sombre row of chambers , which surround [the quadrangle]3031-the quadrangle]2182-the sombre row of chambers , which surround the quadrangle , looked well . [He]102-mr. harding stood still a moment to collect [his]102-mr. harding thoughts , and reflect on what [he]102-mr. harding had done , and was about to do . [He]102-mr. harding knew that [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general regarded [him]102-mr. harding as little better than [a fool]2185-a fool , but that [he]102-mr. harding did not mind ; [he]102-mr. harding and [the attorney - general]3508-the attorney - general had not much in common between [them]2187-them ; [he]102-mr. harding knew also that others , whom [he]102-mr. harding did care about , would think so too ; but [Eleanor]104-eleanor , [he]102-mr. harding was sure , would exult in what [he]102-mr. harding had done , and [the bishop]260-the bishop , [he]102-mr. harding trusted , would sympathise with [him]102-mr. harding . In the meantime [he]102-mr. harding had to meet [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , and so [he]102-mr. harding walked slowly down [Chancery Lane]92-chancery lane and along [Fleet Street]64-fleet street , feeling sure that [his]102-mr. harding work for the night was not yet over . When [he]102-mr. harding reached [the hotel]1924-the hotel [he]102-mr. harding rang the bell quietly , and with a palpitating heart ; [he]102-mr. harding almost longed to escape round the corner , and delay the coming storm by a further walk round [St. Paul 's Churchyard]93-st. paul 's churchyard , but [he]102-mr. harding heard the slow creaking shoes of [the old waiter]1895-the old waiter approaching , and [he]102-mr. harding stood [his]102-mr. harding ground manfully . " [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly is [here]904-here , [sir]1337-sir , "[102-mr. harding] greeted [his]102-mr. harding ears before the door was well open , " and [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly ; [they]4318-they have [a sitting - room above]4319-a sitting - room above , and are waiting up for [you]1337-sir . "[102-mr. harding] There was something in the tone of [the man]3682-the man 's voice which seemed to indicate that even [he]3682-the man looked upon [the warden]318-the warden as [a runaway school - boy]2194-a runaway school - boy , just recaptured by [[his]2194-a runaway school - boy guardian]2195-his guardian , and that [he]3682-the man pitied [the culprit]2196-the culprit , though [he]3682-the man could not but be horrified at the crime . [I]318-the warden 'll go [upstairs]1490-upstairs at once ; "[318-the warden] but [he]318-the warden failed signally : there was , perhaps , a ray of comfort in the presence of [[his]318-the warden married daughter]2198-his married daughter ; that is to say , of comparative comfort , seeing that [[his]318-the warden son - in - law]440-his son - in - law was there : but how much would [he]318-the warden have preferred that [they]2200-they should both have been safe at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi ! "[2219-the dignitary of the church] " Not at all , "[382-the archdeacon] said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , catching a ray of hope . " Then [your]102-mr. harding threat of resignation amounts to nothing , and [we]4329-we are just where [we]4329-we were before . "[102-mr. harding] [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was now standing on the rug , moving uneasily from one foot to the other . [He]102-mr. harding made no distinct answer to [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's last proposition , for [his]102-mr. harding mind was chiefly engaged on thinking how [he]102-mr. harding could escape to bed . That [his]102-mr. harding resignation was a thing finally fixed on , a fact all but completed , was not in [his]102-mr. harding mind a matter of any doubt ; [he]102-mr. harding knew [his]102-mr. harding own weakness ; [he]102-mr. harding knew how prone [he]102-mr. harding was to be led ; but [he]102-mr. harding was not weak enough to give way now , to go back from the position to which [his]102-mr. harding conscience had driven [him]102-mr. harding , after having purposely come to [London]13-london to declare [his]102-mr. harding determination : [he]102-mr. harding did not in the least doubt [his]102-mr. harding resolution , but [he]102-mr. harding greatly doubted [his]102-mr. harding power of defending it against [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law . " [You]103-susan must be very tired , [Susan]103-susan , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding : " would n't [you]103-susan like to go to bed ? "[2254-the son - in - law] [[My]0-i dear warden]2255-my dear warden , " said [he]0-i , "[2254-the son - in - law] this is all nonsense . " A hot tear stood in each of [the warden]318-the warden 's eyes as [he]318-the warden looked round upon [[his]318-the warden married daughter]2198-his married daughter . Then [he]318-the warden thought of the pelican feeding [its]4342-its young with blood from its own breast , but [he]318-the warden gave no utterance to that either ; and then of [Eleanor]104-eleanor waiting for [him]318-the warden at [home]3108-home , waiting to congratulate [him]318-the warden on the end of all [his]318-the warden trouble . " [The lady]612-the lady was really moved beyond [her]612-the lady usual calm composure . "[0-i] It can never be rash to do right , " said [he]0-i . " "[0-i] Then , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , there is nothing before [you]102-mr. harding but ruin , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , now moved beyond all endurance . " "[2734-archdeacon] Such absurdity is enough to provoke [Job]141-skulpit , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , marching quickly up and down [the room]3355-the room . "[141-skulpit] [[Your]102-mr. harding father]2726-your father is like [a child]2748-a child . Eight hundred pounds a - year!—eight hundred and eighty with [the house]374-the house — with nothing to do . [The very place for [him]2726-your father]2272-the very place for him . And to throw that up because [some scoundrel]2273-some scoundrel writes an article in a newspaper ! Well — [I]0-i have done [my]0-i duty . If [he]2273-some scoundrel chooses to ruin [[his]2273-some scoundrel child]3741-his child [I]0-i can not help if ; " and [he]0-i stood still at the fireplace , and looked at [himself]0-i in a dingy mirror which stood on the chimney - piece . There was a pause for about a minute , and then [the warden]318-the warden , finding that nothing else was coming , lighted [his]318-the warden candle , and quietly said , "[0-i] Good night . " "[0-i] Good night , [papa]2730-papa , " said [the lady]612-the lady . And so [the warden]318-the warden retired ; but , as [he]318-the warden closed the door behind [him]318-the warden , [he]318-the warden heard the well - known ejaculation — slower , lower , more solemn , more ponderous than ever—"Good[2730-papa] heavens ! " [The party]4355-the party met the next morning at breakfast ; and a very sombre affair it was — very unlike the breakfasts at [Plumstead Episcopi]32-plumstead episcopi . There were three thin , small , dry bits of bacon , each an inch long , served up under a huge old plated cover ; there were four three - cornered bits of dry toast , and four square bits of buttered toast ; there was a loaf of bread , and some oily - looking butter ; and on the sideboard there were the remains of a cold shoulder of mutton . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , however , had not come up from [[his]382-the archdeacon rectory]4357-his rectory to [St. Paul 's Churchyard]93-st. paul 's churchyard to enjoy [himself]382-the archdeacon , and therefore nothing was said of the scanty fare . [The guests]4358-the guests were as sorry as [the viands]4359-the viands — hardly anything was said over the breakfast table . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon munched [his]382-the archdeacon toast in ominous silence , turning over bitter thoughts in [his]382-the archdeacon deep mind . [The warden]318-the warden tried to talk to [[his]318-the warden daughter]280-his daughter , and [she]280-his daughter tried to answer [him]318-the warden ; but [they]4363-they both failed . There were no feelings at present in common between [them]4363-they . [The warden]318-the warden was thinking only of getting back to [Barchester]6-barchester , and calculating whether [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon would expect [him]382-the archdeacon to wait for [him]382-the archdeacon ; and [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly was preparing [herself]129-mrs. grantly far a grand attack which [she]129-mrs. grantly was to make on [[her]129-mrs. grantly father]293-her father , as agreed upon between [herself]129-mrs. grantly and [[her]129-mrs. grantly husband]611-her husband during [their]4363-they curtain confabulation of that morning . When [the waiter]1890-the waiter had creaked out of [the room]3355-the room with the last of the teacups , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon got up and went to the window , as though to admire the view . [The room]3355-the room looked out on [a narrow passage which runs from [St. Paul 's Churchyard]93-st. paul 's churchyard to [Paternoster Row]84-paternoster row]4372-a narrow passage which runs from st. paul 's churchyard to paternoster row ; and [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly patiently perused the names of [the three shopkeepers whose doors were in view]4373-the three shopkeepers whose doors were in view . [The warden]318-the warden still kept [his]318-the warden seat at the table , and examined the pattern of the table - cloth ; and [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly , seating [herself]129-mrs. grantly on the sofa , began to knit . After awhile [the warden]318-the warden pulled [his]318-the warden Bradshaw out of [his]318-the warden pocket , and began laboriously to consult it . There was [a train]4376-a train for [Barchester]6-barchester at 10 A.M. That was out of the question , for it was nearly ten already . Another at [3 P.M.]94-3 p.m. ; another , [the night - mail train]4377-the night - mail train , at 9 P.M. [The three o'clock train]4378-the three o'clock train would take [him]0-i [home]3108-home to tea , and would suit very well . "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]2725-my dear , " said [he]0-i , "[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i shall go back [home]3108-home at three o'clock to - day . [I]0-i shall get [home]3108-home at half - past eight . [I]0-i do n't think there 's anything to keep [me]0-i in [London]13-london . " "[382-the archdeacon] [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon and [I]0-i return by [the early train]2280-the early train to - morrow , [papa]2730-papa ; wo n't [you]2730-papa wait and go back with [us]2282-us ? " "[2730-papa] Why , [Eleanor]104-eleanor will expect [me]0-i to - night ; and [I]0-i 've so much to do ; and — " "[0-i] Much to do ! " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon sotto voce ; but [the warden]318-the warden heard [him]382-the archdeacon . "[2730-papa] [You]2730-papa 'd better wait for [us]2282-us , [papa]2730-papa . " "[2730-papa] Thank [ye]2730-papa , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear ! [I]0-i think [I]0-i 'll go this afternoon . " [The tamest animal]4382-the tamest animal will turn when driven too hard , and even [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was beginning to fight for [his]102-mr. harding own way . "[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [you]2730-papa wo n't be back before three ? " said [the lady]612-the lady , addressing [[her]612-the lady husband]611-her husband . "[2730-papa] [I]0-i must leave this at two , " said [the warden]318-the warden . "[0-i] Quite out of the question , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , answering [[his]382-the archdeacon wife]607-his wife , and still reading [the shopkeepers]4388-the shopkeepers ' names ; "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't suppose [I]0-i shall be back till five . " There was another long pause , during which [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding continued to study [his]102-mr. harding "[0-i] Bradshaw . " "[0-i] [I]0-i must go to [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming , " said [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon at last . "[0-i] Oh , to [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming , " said [the warden]318-the warden . It was quite a matter of indifference to [him]318-the warden where [[his]318-the warden son - in - law]440-his son - in - law went . The names of [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming had now no interest in [his]318-the warden ears . What had [he]318-the warden to do with [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming further , having already had [his]318-the warden suit finally adjudicated upon in a court of conscience , a judgment without power of appeal fully registered , and the matter settled so that [all the lawyers in [London]13-london]4392-all the lawyers in london could not disturb it . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon could go to [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming , could remain [there]713-there all day in anxious discussion ; but what might be said there was no longer matter of interest to [him]318-the warden , who was so soon to lay aside the name of [warden of [Barchester Hospital]4396-barchester hospital]4395-warden of barchester hospital . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon took up [his]382-the archdeacon shining new clerical hat , and put on [his]382-the archdeacon black new clerical gloves , and looked heavy , respectable , decorous , and opulent , [a decided clergyman of [the Church of England]3292-the church of england , every inch of [him]382-the archdeacon]4398-a decided clergyman of the church of england , every inch of him . "[132-cox] [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i shall see [you]2285-you at [Barchester]6-barchester the day after to - morrow , " said [he]0-i . [The warden]318-the warden supposed [he]0-i would . "[0-i] [I]0-i must once more beseech [you]2285-you to take no further steps till [you]2285-you see [[my]0-i father]942-my father ; if [you]2285-you owe [me]0-i nothing , " and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon looked as though [he]382-the archdeacon thought a great deal were due to [him]2285-you , "[0-i] at least [you]2285-you owe so much to [[my]0-i father]942-my father ; " and , without waiting for a reply , [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly wended [his]106-dr. grantly way to [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming . [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly waited till the last fall of [[her]129-mrs. grantly husband]611-her husband 's foot was heard , as [he]611-her husband turned out of [the court]4403-the court into [St. Paul 's Churchyard]93-st. paul 's churchyard , and then commenced [her]129-mrs. grantly task of talking [[her]129-mrs. grantly father]293-her father over . "[191-papa] [Papa]191-papa , " [she]129-mrs. grantly began , "[191-papa] this is a most serious business . " "[191-papa] Indeed it is , " said [the warden]318-the warden , ringing the bell . "[191-papa] [I]0-i greatly feel the distress of mind [you]2285-you must have endured . " "[2285-you] [I]0-i am sure [you]2285-you do , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear ; " and [he]0-i ordered [the waiter]1890-the waiter to bring [him]0-i pen , ink , and paper . "[2285-you] Are [you]2285-you going to write , [papa]2730-papa ? " "[2285-you] Yes , [[my]0-i dear]2725-my dear — [I]0-i am going to write [my]0-i resignation to [the bishop]260-the bishop . " "[0-i] Pray , pray , [papa]2730-papa , put it off till [our]2293-our return , — pray put it off till [you]2730-papa have seen [the bishop,—dear papa]2294-the bishop,—dear papa ! for [my]0-i sake , for [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's ! — " "[2730-papa] It is for [your]2730-papa sake and [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's that [I]0-i do this . [I]0-i hope , at least , that [[my]0-i children]2295-my children may never have to be ashamed of [[their]2295-my children father]2296-their father . " "[0-i] How can [you]2730-papa talk about shame , [papa]2730-papa ? " and [she]104-eleanor stopped while [the waiter]1890-the waiter creaked in with the paper , and then slowly creaked out again ; "[2730-papa] how can [you]2730-papa talk about shame ? [you]2730-papa know what all [[your]2730-papa friends]4296-your friends think about this question . " [The warden]318-the warden spread [his]318-the warden paper on the table , placing it on the meagre blotting - book , which [the hotel]1924-the hotel afforded , and sat [himself]318-the warden down to write . "[2730-papa] [You]2730-papa wo n't refuse [me]0-i one request , [papa]2730-papa ? " continued [[his]318-the warden daughter]280-his daughter ; "[2730-papa] [you]2730-papa wo n't refuse to delay [your]2730-papa letter for two short days?—two days can make no possible difference . " "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]2725-my dear , " said [he]318-the warden naïvely , "[0-i] if [I]0-i waited till [I]0-i got to [Barchester]6-barchester , [I]0-i might , perhaps , be prevented . " "[0-i] But surely [you]2730-papa would not wish to offend [the bishop]260-the bishop ? " said [she]103-susan . "[2730-papa] God forbid ! [The bishop]260-the bishop is not apt to take offence , and knows [me]0-i too well to take in bad part anything that [I]0-i may be called on to do . " "[2730-papa] But , [papa]2730-papa — " "[103-susan] [Susan]103-susan , " said [he]0-i , "[2730-papa] [my]0-i mind on this subject is made up ; it is not without much repugnance that [I]0-i act in opposition to the advice of [such men as [Sir Abraham Haphazard]151-sir abraham and [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon]2304-such men as sir abraham haphazard and the archdeacon ; but in this matter [I]0-i can take no advice , [I]0-i can not alter the resolution to which [I]0-i have come . " "[2730-papa] But two days , [papa]2730-papa — " "[2730-papa] [No,—nor]238-no,—nor can [I]0-i delay it . [You]2307-i may add to [my]0-i present unhappiness by pressing [me]0-i , but [you]2307-i can not change [my]0-i purpose ; it will be a comfort to [me]0-i if [you]2307-i will let the matter rest : " and , dipping [his]0-i pen into the inkstand , [he]0-i fixed [his]0-i eyes intently on the paper . There was something in [his]0-i manner which taught [[his]0-i daughter]280-his daughter to perceive that [he]0-i was in earnest ; [she]280-his daughter had at one time ruled supreme in [[[her]280-his daughter father]293-her father 's house]1050-her father 's house , but [she]280-his daughter knew that there were moments when , mild and meek as [he]0-i was , [he]0-i would have [his]0-i way , and the present was an occasion of the sort . [She]280-his daughter returned , therefore , to [her]280-his daughter knitting , and very shortly after left [the room]3355-the room . [The warden]318-the warden was now at liberty to compose [his]318-the warden letter , and , as it was characteristic of [the man]3682-the man , it shall be given at full length . The official letter , which , when written , seemed to [him]318-the warden to be too formally cold to be sent alone to so dear [a friend]1011-a friend , was accompanied by a private note ; and both are here inserted . The letter of resignation ran as follows : — ' Chapter Hotel , [St. Paul 's]83-st. paul 's , ' [London,—August]96-london,—august , 18 — ' [[My]2307-i Lord Bishop]4418-my lord bishop , It is with the greatest pain that [I]2307-i feel [myself]2307-i constrained to resign into [[your]4418-my lord bishop Lordship]4419-your lordship 's hands [the wardenship of [the hospital at [Barchester]6-barchester]4421-the hospital at barchester which [you]4418-my lord bishop so kindly conferred upon [me]2307-i , now nearly twelve years since]4420-the wardenship of the hospital at barchester which you so kindly conferred upon me , now nearly twelve years since . [I]2307-i need not explain the circumstances which have made this step appear necessary to [me]2307-i . [You]4418-my lord bishop are aware that a question has arisen as to the right of [the warden]318-the warden to the income which has been allotted to [the wardenship]4423-the wardenship ; it has seemed to [me]2307-i that this right is not well made out , and [I]2307-i hesitate to incur the risk of taking an income to which [my]2307-i legal claim appears doubtful . The office of [precentor of [the cathedral]258-the cathedral]268-precentor of the cathedral is , as [[your]4418-my lord bishop Lordship]4419-your lordship is aware , joined to that of [the warden]318-the warden ; that is to say , [the precentor]441-the precentor has for many years been [the warden of [the hospital]364-the hospital]2799-the warden of the hospital ; there is , however , nothing to make the junction of [the two offices]4431-the two offices necessary , and , unless [you]4418-my lord bishop or [the dean and chapter]368-the dean and chapter object to such an arrangement , [I]2307-i would wish to keep the precentorship . The income of [this office]4433-this office will now be necessary to [me]2307-i ; indeed , [I]2307-i do not know why [I]2307-i should be ashamed to say that [I]2307-i should have difficulty in supporting [myself]2307-i without it . [[Your]4418-my lord bishop Lordship]4419-your lordship , and such others as [you]4418-my lord bishop may please to consult on the matter , will at once see that [my]2307-i resignation of [the wardenship]4423-the wardenship need offer not the slightest bar to its occupation by [another person]4436-another person . [I]2307-i am thought in the wrong by [all those whom [I]2307-i have consulted in the matter]4437-all those whom i have consulted in the matter ; [I]2307-i have very little but an inward and an unguided conviction of [my]2307-i own to bring [me]2307-i to this step , and [I]2307-i shall , indeed , be hurt to find that any slur is thrown on the preferment which [your]4418-my lord bishop kindness bestowed on [me]2307-i , by [my]2307-i resignation of it . [I]2307-i , at any rate for one , shall look on [any successor whom [you]4418-my lord bishop may appoint as enjoying a clerical situation of the highest respectability , and one to which [[your]4418-my lord bishop Lordship]4419-your lordship 's nomination gives an indefeasible right . [I]2307-i can not finish this official letter without again thanking [[your]4418-my lord bishop Lordship]4419-your lordship for all [your]4418-my lord bishop great kindness , and [I]2307-i beg to subscricbe [myself]2307-i ' [[Your]4418-my lord bishop Lordship 's most obedient servant]4441-your lordship 's most obedient servant , ' [Septimus Harding]100-septimus harding , ' Warden of [Barchester Hospital]4396-barchester hospital , and [Precentor of [the cathedral]258-the cathedral]268-precentor of the cathedral]4438-any successor whom you may appoint as enjoying a clerical situation of the highest respectability , and one to which your lordship 's nomination gives an indefeasible right . i can not finish this official letter without again thanking your lordship for all your great kindness , and i beg to subscricbe myself ' your lordship 's most obedient servant , ' septimus harding , ' warden of barchester hospital , and precentor of the cathedral . ' [He]2307-i then wrote the following private note : — ' [[My]2307-i dear]2725-my dear [Bishop]137-bishop , [I]2307-i can not send [you]137-bishop the accompanying official letter without a warmer expression of thanks for all [your]137-bishop kindness than would befit a document which may to a certain degree be made public . [You]137-bishop , [I]2307-i know , will understand the feeling , and , perhaps , pity the weakness which makes [me]2307-i resign [the hospital]364-the hospital . [I]2307-i am not made of calibre strong enough to withstand public attack . Were [I]2307-i convinced that [I]2307-i stood on ground perfectly firm , that [I]2307-i was certainly justified in taking eight hundred a year under [Hiram]107-john hiram 's will , [I]2307-i should feel bound by duty to retain the position , however unendurable might be the nature of the assault ; but , as [I]2307-i do not feel this conviction , [I]2307-i can not believe that [you]137-bishop will think [me]2307-i wrong in what [I]2307-i am doing . [I]2307-i had at one time an idea of keeping only some moderate portion of the income ; perhaps three hundred a year , and of remitting the remainder to [the trustees]4447-the trustees ; but it occurred to [me]2307-i , and [I]2307-i think with reason , that by so doing [I]2307-i should place [[my]2307-i successors]4448-my successors in an invidious position , and greatly damage [your]137-bishop patronage . [[My]2307-i dear friend]4449-my dear friend , let [me]2307-i have a line from [you]137-bishop to say that [you]137-bishop do not blame [me]2307-i for what [I]2307-i am doing , and that [the officiating vicar of [Crabtree Parva]42-crabtree parva]4450-the officiating vicar of crabtree parva will be the same to [you]137-bishop as [the warden of [the hospital]364-the hospital]2799-the warden of the hospital . [I]2307-i am very anxious about the precentorship ; [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon thinks it must go with the wardenship ; [I]2307-i think not , and that , having it , [I]2307-i can not be ousted . [I]2307-i will , however , be guided by [you]137-bishop and [the dean]3020-the dean . No other duty will suit [me]2307-i so well , or come so much within [my]2307-i power of adequate performance . [I]2307-i thank [you]137-bishop from [my]2307-i heart for the preferment which [I]2307-i am now giving up , and for all [your]137-bishop kindness , and am , [dear bishop]4455-dear bishop , now as always , ' [Yours]137-bishop most sincerely , "[2307-i] [Septimus Harding]100-septimus harding . ' [London,—August]96-london,—august , 18—. ' Having written these letters and made a copy of the former one for the benefit of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , whom [we]2309-we must now cease to call [the warden]318-the warden , [he]102-mr. harding having designated [himself]102-mr. harding so for the last time , found that it was nearly two o'clock , and that [he]102-mr. harding must prepare for [his]102-mr. harding journey . Yes , from this time [he]102-mr. harding never again admitted the name by which [he]102-mr. harding had been so familiarly known , and in which , to tell the truth , [he]102-mr. harding had rejoiced . The love of titles is common to [all men]3341-all men , and [a vicar or fellow]2312-a vicar or fellow is as pleased at becoming [Mr. Archdeacon]2313-mr. archdeacon or [Mr. Provost]2314-mr. provost , as [a lieutenant at getting [his]102-mr. harding captaincy]2315-a lieutenant at getting his captaincy , or a city tallow - chandler in becoming [Sir John]239-sir john on the occasion of [a Queen]2316-a queen 's visit to [a new bridge]2317-a new bridge . But [warden]304-warden [he]304-warden was no longer , and the name of [precentor]279-precentor , though the office was to [him]304-warden so dear , confers in itself no sufficient distinction ; [[our]2320-our friend]996-our friend , therefore , again became [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly had gone out ; [he]102-mr. harding had , therefore , [no one]283-no one to delay [him]102-mr. harding by further entreaties to postpone [his]102-mr. harding journey ; [he]102-mr. harding had soon arranged [his]102-mr. harding bag , and paid [his]102-mr. harding bill , and , leaving a note for [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter , in which [he]102-mr. harding put the copy of [his]102-mr. harding official letter , [he]102-mr. harding got into [a cab]2324-a cab and drove away to [the station]2325-the station with something of triumph in [his]102-mr. harding heart . Had [he]102-mr. harding not cause for triumph ? Had [he]102-mr. harding not been supremely successful ? Had [he]102-mr. harding not for the first time in [his]102-mr. harding life held [his]102-mr. harding own purpose against that of [[his]102-mr. harding son - in - law]440-his son - in - law , and manfully combated against great odds,—against [[the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's wife]3872-the archdeacon 's wife as well as [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon ? Had [he]102-mr. harding not gained a great victory , and was it not fit that [he]102-mr. harding should step into [[his]102-mr. harding cab]2330-his cab with triumph ? [He]102-mr. harding had not told [Eleanor]104-eleanor when [he]102-mr. harding would return , but [she]104-eleanor was on the look out for [him]102-mr. harding by [every train by which [he]102-mr. harding could arrive]2331-every train by which he could arrive , and [the pony carriage]1844-the pony carriage was at [the Barchester station]2333-the barchester station when [the train]2334-the train drew up at [the platform]2335-the platform . " [[My]102-mr. harding dear]2725-my dear , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding , sitting beside [her]104-eleanor , as [she]104-eleanor steered [her]104-eleanor little vessel to one side of [the road]3938-the road to make room for the clattering omnibus as [they]2337-they passed from [the station]2325-the station into [the town]254-the town ; " [I]104-eleanor hope [you]104-eleanor 'll be able to feel a proper degree of respect for [the vicar of [Crabtree]41-crabtree]4457-the vicar of crabtree . "[104-eleanor] " [Dear papa]1258-dear papa , "[104-eleanor] said [she]104-eleanor , " [I]104-eleanor am so glad . "[104-eleanor] There was great comfort in returning [home]3108-home to [that pleasant house]2341-that pleasant house , though [he]102-mr. harding was to leave [it]2341-that pleasant house so soon , and in discussing with [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter all that [he]102-mr. harding had done , and all that [he]102-mr. harding had to do . It must take some time to get out of [one house]2343-one house into another ; [the curate at [Crabtree]41-crabtree]2344-the curate at crabtree could not be abolished under six months , that is , unless other provision could be made for [him]2344-the curate at crabtree ; and then the furniture — the most of that must be sold to pay [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham Haphazard for sitting up till twelve at night . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was strangely ignorant as to [lawyers]3264-lawyers ' bills ; [he]102-mr. harding had no idea , from twenty pounds to two thousand , as to the sum in which [he]102-mr. harding was in indebted for legal assistance . True , [he]102-mr. harding had called in [no lawyer]1141-no lawyer [himself]102-mr. harding ; true , [he]102-mr. harding had been [no consenting party]2347-no consenting party to the employment of either [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming , or [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham ; [he]102-mr. harding had never been consulted on such matters;—the [archdeacon]113-archdeacon grantly had managed all this [himself]113-archdeacon grantly , never for a moment suspecting that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding would take upon [him]113-archdeacon grantly to end the matter in a way of [his]113-archdeacon grantly own . Had [the lawyers]3904-the lawyers ' bills been ten thousand pounds , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding could not have helped it ; but [he]102-mr. harding was not on that account disposed to dispute [his]102-mr. harding own liability . The question never occurred to [him]102-mr. harding ; but it did occur to [him]102-mr. harding that [he]102-mr. harding had very little money at [[his]102-mr. harding banker]2349-his banker 's , that [he]102-mr. harding could receive nothing further from [the hospital]364-the hospital , and that the sale of the furniture was [his]102-mr. harding only resource . " Not all , [papa]2730-papa , "[104-eleanor] said [Eleanor]104-eleanor , pleadingly . " Not quite all , [[my]102-mr. harding dear]2725-my dear , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding ; " that is , if [we]2351-we can help it . [We]2351-we must have a little at [Crabtree]41-crabtree — but it can only be a little ; [we]2351-we must put a bold front on it , [Nelly]104-eleanor ; it is n't easy to come down from affluence to poverty . "[102-mr. harding] And so [they]2351-we planned [their]2351-we future mode of life ; [the father]3737-the father taking comfort from the reflection that [[his]3737-the father daughter]280-his daughter would soon be freed from it , and [she]280-his daughter resolving that [[her]280-his daughter father]293-her father would soon have in [[her]280-his daughter own house]2355-her own house a ready means of escape from the solitude of [the Crabtree vicarage]2356-the crabtree vicarage . When [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon left [[his]382-the archdeacon wife]607-his wife and [father]3696-father - in - law at [the Chapter Coffee House]85-the chapter coffee house to go to [Messrs. Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming , [he]382-the archdeacon had no very defined idea of what [he]382-the archdeacon had to do when [he]382-the archdeacon got [there]713-there . [Gentlemen when at law , or in any way engaged in matters requiring legal assistance]2361-gentlemen when at law , or in any way engaged in matters requiring legal assistance , are very apt to go to [[their]2361-gentlemen when at law , or in any way engaged in matters requiring legal assistance lawyers]2362-their lawyers without much absolute necessity ; — [gentlemen]482-gentlemen when doing so , are apt to describe such attendance as quite compulsory , and very disagreeable . [The lawyers]3904-the lawyers , on the other hand , do not at all see the necessity , though [they]3904-the lawyers quite agree as to the disagreeable nature of the visit;—gentlemen when so engaged are usually somewhat gravelled at finding nothing to say to [[their]2361-gentlemen when at law , or in any way engaged in matters requiring legal assistance learned friends]2365-their learned friends ; [they]2361-gentlemen when at law , or in any way engaged in matters requiring legal assistance generally talk a little politics , a little weather , ask some few foolish questions about [their]2361-gentlemen when at law , or in any way engaged in matters requiring legal assistance suit , and then withdraw , having passed half an hour in [a small , dingy waiting - room]2366-a small , dingy waiting - room , in company with [some junior assistant - clerk]2367-some junior assistant - clerk , and ten minutes with [the members of [the firm]2369-the firm]2368-the members of the firm ; the business is then over for which [the gentleman]3851-the gentleman has come up to [London]13-london , probably a distance of a hundred and fifty miles . To be sure [he]3851-the gentleman goes to the play , and dines at [[[his]3851-the gentleman friend]285-his friend 's club]2372-his friend 's club , and has [a bachelor]2373-a bachelor 's liberty and [bachelor]2374-bachelor 's recreation for three or four days ; and [he]3851-the gentleman could not probably plead the desire of such gratifications as a reason to [[his]3851-the gentleman wife]607-his wife for a trip to [London]13-london . [Married ladies]2376-married ladies , when [[your]2377-your husbands]2378-your husbands find [they]2378-your husbands are positively obliged to attend [[their]2378-your husbands legal advisers]2379-their legal advisers , the nature of the duty to be performed is generally of this description . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon would not have dreamt of leaving [London]13-london without going to [Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming ; and yet [he]382-the archdeacon had nothing to say to [them]2381-them . The game was up ; [he]3851-the gentleman plainly saw that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding in this matter was not to be moved ; [his]3851-the gentleman only remaining business on this head was to pay the bill and have done with it : and [I]0-i think it may be taken for granted , that whatever the cause may be that takes [a gentleman]2104-a gentleman to [[a lawyer]605-a lawyer 's chambers]2107-a lawyer 's chambers , [he]3851-the gentleman never goes [there]713-there to pay [his]3851-the gentleman bill . [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly , however , in the eyes of [Messrs. Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming represented the spiritualities of [the diocese of Barchester]2386-the diocese of barchester , as [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick did the temporalities , and was , therefore , too great [a man to undergo the half - hour in the clerks]2387-a man to undergo the half - hour in the clerks ' room . No tragedy occurred , though [Mr. Cox]240-mr. cox , [a short and somewhat bull - necked man]2392-a short and somewhat bull - necked man , was very near a fit of apoplexy when [he]240-mr. cox first attempted to ejaculate that fatal word — resign ! On the morning after [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's return [home]3108-home , [he]102-mr. harding received a note from [the bishop]260-the bishop full of affection , condolence , and praise . " Pray come to [me]260-the bishop at once , "[260-the bishop] wrote [the bishop]260-the bishop , " that [we]2404-the two old friends may see what had better be done ; as to [the hospital]364-the hospital , [I]260-the bishop will not say a word to dissuade [you]102-mr. harding ; but [I]260-the bishop do n't like [your]102-mr. harding going to [Crabtree]41-crabtree : at any rate , come to [me]260-the bishop at once . "[260-the bishop] [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding did go to [him]260-the bishop at once ; and long and confidential was the consultation between [the two old friends]2404-the two old friends . There [they]2404-the two old friends sat together the whole long day plotting to get the better of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , and to carry out little schemes of [their]2404-the two old friends own , which [they]2404-the two old friends knew would be opposed by the whole weight of [his]382-the archdeacon authority . [The bishop]260-the bishop 's first idea was , that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , if left to [himself]102-mr. harding , would certainly starve — not in the figurative sense in which so many of [[our]2407-our ladies]2408-our ladies and [gentlemen]482-gentlemen do starve on incomes form one to five hundred a year not that [he]102-mr. harding would be starved as regarded dress coats , port wine , and pocket - money ; but that [he]102-mr. harding would positively perish of inanition for want of bread . " How is [a man]545-a man to live , when [he]545-a man gives up all [his]545-a man income ? "[260-the bishop] said [the bishop]260-the bishop to [himself]260-the bishop . And then [the good - natured little man]2411-the good - natured little man began to consider how [[his]2411-the good - natured little man friend]285-his friend might be best rescued from a death so horrid and painful . [His]260-the bishop first proposition to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was , that [they]2404-the two old friends should live together at [the palace]947-the palace . [He]260-the bishop , [the bishop]260-the bishop , positively assured [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding that [he]260-the bishop wanted [another resident chaplain]2415-another resident chaplain : not [a young , working chaplain]2416-a young , working chaplain , but [a steady , middle - aged chaplain]2417-a steady , middle - aged chaplain ; [one who would dine and drink a glass of wine with [him]102-mr. harding , talk about [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , and poke the fire]2418-one who would dine and drink a glass of wine with him , talk about the archdeacon , and poke the fire . [The bishop]260-the bishop did not positively name all these duties , but [he]260-the bishop gave [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding to understand that such would be the nature of the service required . It was not without much difficulty that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding made [[his]102-mr. harding friend]285-his friend see that this would not suit [him]102-mr. harding ; that [he]102-mr. harding could not throw up [the bishop]260-the bishop 's preferment , and then come and hang on at [the bishop]260-the bishop 's table ; that [he]102-mr. harding could not allow [people]1126-people to say of [him]102-mr. harding that it was an easy matter to abandon [his]102-mr. harding own income , as [he]102-mr. harding was able to sponge on that of [another person]4436-another person . [He]102-mr. harding succeeded , however , in explaining that the plan would not do , and then [the bishop]260-the bishop brought forward another which [he]260-the bishop had in [his]260-the bishop sleeve . [He]260-the bishop , [the bishop]260-the bishop , had in [his]260-the bishop will left certain moneys to [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's two daughters]2428-mr. harding 's two daughters , imagining that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding would [himself]102-mr. harding want no such assistance during [his]102-mr. harding own lifetime . " [The girls]4470-the girls , [you]4470-the girls know , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding , " will have it just the same when [you]4470-the girls 're gone — and [they]4470-the girls wo n't want it sooner — and as for the interest during [my]102-mr. harding lifetime , it is n't worth talking about . [I]102-mr. harding have more than enough . "[102-mr. harding] With much difficulty and heartfelt sorrow , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding refused also this offer . No ; [his]102-mr. harding wish was to support [himself]102-mr. harding , however poorly,—not to be supported on the charity of [any one]431-any one . It was hard to make [the bishop]260-the bishop understand this ; it was hard to make [him]102-mr. harding comprehend that the only real favour [he]102-mr. harding could confer was the continuation of [his]102-mr. harding independent friendship ; but at last even this was done . At any rate , thought [the bishop]260-the bishop , [he]102-mr. harding will come and dine with [me]0-i from time to time , and if [he]102-mr. harding be absolutely starving [I]0-i shall see it . Touching the precentorship , [the bishop]260-the bishop was clearly of opinion that it could be held without the other situation — an opinion from which [no one]283-no one differed ; and it was therefore soon settled among [all the parties concerned]2435-all the parties concerned , that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding should still be [the precentor of [the cathedral]258-the cathedral]305-the precentor of the cathedral . On the day following [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's return , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon reached [Plumstead]20-plumstead full of [Mr. Cumming]237-cumming 's scheme regarding [Puddingdale]98-puddingdale and [Mr. Quiverful]241-quiverful . "[382-the archdeacon] [[His]260-the bishop lordship]2863-his lordship looked very unhappy , and shuffled about in [his]2863-his lordship chair , but still did n't give way ; [he]2863-his lordship thought [Puddingdale]98-puddingdale would n't do for [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ; it was too far from [Barchester]6-barchester .
