[The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon then left [[his]382-the archdeacon father]508-his father , and went down to [the hospital]364-the hospital ; but [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding would n't listen at all to the [Puddingdale]98-puddingdale scheme . To [his]102-mr. harding eyes it had no attraction ; it savoured of simony , and was likely to bring down upon [him]102-mr. harding harder and more deserved strictures than any [he]102-mr. harding had yet received : [he]102-mr. harding positively declined to become [vicar of [Puddingdale]98-puddingdale]2455-vicar of puddingdale under any circumstances . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon waxed wroth , talked big , and looked bigger ; [he]382-the archdeacon said something about dependence and [beggary]2457-beggary , spoke of the duty [every man]2458-every man was under to earn [his]2458-every man bread , made passing allusions to the follies of youth and waywardness of age , as though [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding were afflicted by both , and ended by declaring that [he]102-mr. harding had done . [He]382-the archdeacon felt that [he]382-the archdeacon had left no stone unturned to arrange matters on the best and easiest footing ; that [he]382-the archdeacon had , in fact , so arranged them , that [he]382-the archdeacon had so managed that there was no further need of any anxiety in the matter . And how had [he]382-the archdeacon been paid ? [His]382-the archdeacon advice had been systematically rejected ; [he]382-the archdeacon had been not only slighted , but distrusted and avoided ; [he]382-the archdeacon and [his]382-the archdeacon measures had been utterly thrown over , as had been [Sir Abraham]151-sir abraham , who , [he]382-the archdeacon had reason to know , was much pained at what had occurred . [He]382-the archdeacon now found it was useless to interfere any further , and [he]382-the archdeacon should retire . If any further assistance were required from [him]382-the archdeacon , [he]382-the archdeacon would probably be called on , and should be again happy to come forward . And so [he]382-the archdeacon left [the hospital]364-the hospital , and has not since entered [it]364-the hospital from that day to this . And here [we]2460-we must take leave of [Archdeacon Grantly]113-archdeacon grantly . [We]2460-we fear that [he]382-the archdeacon is represented in these pages as being worse than [he]382-the archdeacon is ; but [we]2460-we have had to do with [his]382-the archdeacon foibles , and not with [his]382-the archdeacon virtues . [We]2460-we have seen only the weak side of [the man]3682-the man , and have lacked the opportunity of bringing [him]3682-the man forward on [his]3682-the man strong ground . That [he]382-the archdeacon is [a man somewhat too fond of [his]382-the archdeacon own way]2462-a man somewhat too fond of his own way , and not sufficiently scrupulous in [his]382-the archdeacon manner of achieving it , [[his]382-the archdeacon best friends]2463-his best friends can not deny . That [he]382-the archdeacon is bigoted in favour , not so much of [his]382-the archdeacon doctrines as of [his]382-the archdeacon cloth , is also true : and it is true that the possession of a large income is a desire that sits near [his]382-the archdeacon heart . Nevertheless , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon is [a gentleman]2104-a gentleman and [a man of conscience]2466-a man of conscience ; [he]382-the archdeacon spends [his]382-the archdeacon money liberally , and does the work [he]382-the archdeacon has to do with the best of [his]382-the archdeacon ability ; [he]382-the archdeacon improves the tone of society of [those among whom [he]382-the archdeacon lives]2467-those among whom he lives . [His]382-the archdeacon aspirations are of [a healthy , if not of the highest , kind]2468-a healthy , if not of the highest , kind . Though never [an austere man]2469-an austere man , [he]382-the archdeacon upholds propriety of conduct both by example and precept . [He]382-the archdeacon is generous to [the poor]1029-the poor , and hospitable to [the rich]1791-the rich ; in matters of religion [he]382-the archdeacon is sincere , and yet [no Pharisee]2472-no pharisee ; [he]382-the archdeacon is in earnest , and yet [no fanatic]2473-no fanatic . On the whole , [the Archdeacon of [Barchester]6-barchester]3389-the archdeacon of barchester is [a man doing more good than harm,—a man to be furthered and supported , though perhaps also to be controlled]2475-a man doing more good than harm,—a man to be furthered and supported , though perhaps also to be controlled ; and it is matter of regret to [us]2476-us that the course of [our]2476-us narrative has required that [we]2476-us should see more of [his]382-the archdeacon weakness than [his]382-the archdeacon strength . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding allowed [himself]102-mr. harding no rest till everything was prepared for [his]102-mr. harding departure from [the hospital]364-the hospital . It may be as well to mention that [he]102-mr. harding was not driven to the stern necessity of selling all [his]102-mr. harding furniture : [he]102-mr. harding had been quite in earnest in [his]102-mr. harding intention to do so , but it was soon made known to [him]102-mr. harding that the claims of [Messrs. Cox]132-cox and [Cumming]237-cumming made no such step obligatory . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon had thought it wise to make use of the threat of [the lawyer]1856-the lawyer 's bill , to frighten [[his]382-the archdeacon father - in - law]435-his father - in - law into compliance ; but [he]382-the archdeacon had no intention to saddle [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding with costs , which had been incurred by no means exclusively for [his]102-mr. harding benefit . The amount of the bill was added to the diocesan account , and was , in fact , paid out of [the bishop]260-the bishop 's pocket , without any consciousness on the part of [[his]102-mr. harding lordship]2863-his lordship . A great part of [his]102-mr. harding furniture [he]102-mr. harding did resolve to sell , having no other means to dispose of it ; and the ponies and [carriage]2483-carriage were transferred , by private contract , to the use of [an old maiden lady]2484-an old maiden lady in [the city]2485-the city . For [his]102-mr. harding present use [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding took [a lodging in [Barchester]6-barchester]2486-a lodging in barchester , and [thither]2487-thither were conveyed such articles as [he]102-mr. harding wanted for daily use — [his]102-mr. harding music , books , and instruments , [his]102-mr. harding own arm - chair , and [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's pet sofa ; [her]104-eleanor teapoy and [[his]102-mr. harding cellaret]2488-his cellaret , and also the slender but still sufficient contents of [[his]102-mr. harding wine - cellar]2489-his wine - cellar . [Mrs. Grantly]129-mrs. grantly had much wished that [[her]129-mrs. grantly sister]3823-her sister would reside at [Plumstead]20-plumstead , till [[[her]129-mrs. grantly father]293-her father 's house at [Crabtree]41-crabtree]2492-her father 's house at crabtree should be ready for [her]129-mrs. grantly ; but [Eleanor]104-eleanor [herself]104-eleanor strongly resisted this proposal . It was in vain urged upon [her]104-eleanor , that [a lady in lodgings]2493-a lady in lodgings cost more than [a gentleman]2104-a gentleman ; and that , under [[her]129-mrs. grantly father]293-her father 's present circumstances , such an expense should be avoided . [Eleanor]104-eleanor had not pressed [[her]129-mrs. grantly father]293-her father to give up [the hospital]364-the hospital , in order that [she]104-eleanor might live at [Plumstead Rectory]99-plumstead rectory , and [he]293-her father alone in [[his]293-her father Barchester lodgings]2498-his barchester lodgings ; nor did [Eleanor]104-eleanor think that [she]104-eleanor would be treating [a certain gentleman]2499-a certain gentleman very fairly , if [she]104-eleanor betook [herself]104-eleanor to [the house which [he]2499-a certain gentleman would be the least desirous of entering of any in [the county]2501-the county]2500-the house which he would be the least desirous of entering of any in the county . So [she]104-eleanor got [a little bedroom for [herself]104-eleanor behind [the sitting - room]2503-the sitting - room]2502-a little bedroom for herself behind the sitting - room , and just over [the little back parlour of [the chemist]2505-the chemist , with whom [they]2506-they were to lodge]2504-the little back parlour of the chemist , with whom they were to lodge . There was somewhat of a savour of senna softened by peppermint about [the place]794-the place ; but , on the whole , [the lodgings]2508-the lodgings were clean and comfortable . The day had been fixed for the migration of [the ex - warden]2509-the ex - warden , and [all Barchester]2510-all barchester were in a state of excitement on the subject . Opinion was much divided as to the propriety of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's conduct . [The mercantile part of [the community]2512-the community]2511-the mercantile part of the community , [the mayor]2513-the mayor and corporation , and [council]2514-council , also [most of [the ladies]4188-the ladies]2515-most of the ladies , were loud in [his]102-mr. harding praise . Nothing could be more noble , nothing more generous , nothing more upright . But [the gentry]2517-the gentry were of a different way of thinking , — especially [the lawyers]3904-the lawyers and [the clergymen]2519-the clergymen . [They]2517-the gentry said such conduct was very weak and undignified ; that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding evinced a lamentable want of esprit de corps , as well as courage ; and that such an abdication must do much harm , and could do but little good . On the evening before [he]102-mr. harding left , [he]102-mr. harding summoned [all the bedesmen]2520-all the bedesmen into [[his]102-mr. harding parlour]2521-his parlour to wish [them]2520-all the bedesmen good - bye . With [Bunce]136-bunce [he]102-mr. harding had been in frequent communication since [his]102-mr. harding return from [London]13-london , and had been at much pains to explain to [the old man]3683-the old man the cause of [his]102-mr. harding resignation , without in any way prejudicing the position of [[his]102-mr. harding successor]2523-his successor . [The others]3042-the others , also , [he]102-mr. harding had seen more or less frequently ; and had heard from most of [them]3042-the others separately some expression of regret at [his]102-mr. harding departure ; but [he]102-mr. harding had postponed [his]102-mr. harding farewell till the last evening . [He]102-mr. harding now bade [the maid]2525-the maid put wine and glasses on the table ; and had the chairs arranged around [the room]3355-the room ; and sent [Bunce]136-bunce to each of [the men]378-the men to request [they]378-the men would come and say farewell to [[their]378-the men late warden]2528-their late warden . Soon the noise of aged scuffling feet was heard upon the gravel and in [the little hall]2529-the little hall , and [the eleven men who were enabled]2530-the eleven men who were enabled to leave [[their]2530-the eleven men who were enabled rooms]3787-their rooms were assembled . " Come in , [[my]318-the warden friends]989-my friends , come in , "[318-the warden] said [the warden]318-the warden — [he]318-the warden was still [warden]304-warden then . " Come in , and sit down ; "[318-the warden] and [he]318-the warden took the hand of [Abel Handy]119-handy , who was the nearest to [him]318-the warden , and led [the limping grumbler]2534-the limping grumbler to a chair . [The others]3042-the others followed slowly and bashfully : [the infirm]2536-the infirm , [the lame]2537-the lame , and [the blind]2538-the blind ; poor wretches ! who had been so happy , had [they]3042-the others but known it ! Now [their]3042-the others aged faces were covered with shame , and every kind word from [[their]3042-the others master]2539-their master was a coal of fire burning on [their]3042-the others heads . When first the news had reached [them]3042-the others that [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding was going to leave [the hospital]364-the hospital , it had been received with a kind of triumph;—his departure was , as it were , a prelude to success . [He]102-mr. harding had admitted [his]102-mr. harding want of right to the money about which [they]3042-the others were disputing ; and as it did not belong to [him]102-mr. harding , of course it did to [them]3042-the others . The one hundred a - year to each of [them]3042-the others was actually becoming a reality ; and [Abel Handy]119-handy was [a hero]2541-a hero , and [Bunce]136-bunce [a faint - hearted sycophant , worthy neither honour nor fellowship]2542-a faint - hearted sycophant , worthy neither honour nor fellowship . But other tidings soon made [their]3042-the others way into [[the old men]314-the old men 's rooms]401-the old men 's rooms . It was first notified to [them]3042-the others that the income abandoned by [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding would not come to [them]3042-the others ; and these accounts were confirmed by [attorney Finney]131-finney . [They]3042-the others were then informed that [[Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's place]2545-mr. harding 's place would be at once filled by [another]3704-another . That [the new warden]2547-the new warden could not be [a kinder man [they]3042-the others all knew]2548-a kinder man they all knew ; that [he]2547-the new warden would be [a less friendly one most suspected]2549-a less friendly one most suspected ; and then came the bitter information that , from the moment of [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's departure , the twopence a day , [his]102-mr. harding own peculiar gift , must of necessity be withdrawn . And this was to be the end of all [their]3042-the others mighty struggle — of [their]3042-the others fight for [their]3042-the others rights — of [their]3042-the others petition , and [their]3042-the others debates and [their]3042-the others hopes ! [They]3042-the others were to change the best of [masters]2550-masters for a possible bad one , and to lose twopence a day [each man]377-each man ! No ; unfortunate as this was , it was not the worst , or nearly the worst , as will just now be seen . " Sit down , sit down , [[my]318-the warden [friends]499-friends]989-my friends , "[318-the warden] said [the warden]318-the warden . " [I]318-the warden want to say a word to [you]499-friends , and to drink [your]499-friends healths , before [I]318-the warden leave [you]499-friends . Come up here , [Moody]143-moody , here is a chair for [you]499-friends ; come , [Jonathan]147-jonathan crumple Crumple — "[318-the warden] and by degrees [he]318-the warden got [the men]378-the men to be seated . It was not surprising that [they]378-the men should hang back with faint hearts , having returned so much kindness with such deep ingratitude . [Last of all of [them]378-the men]2554-last of all of them came [Bunce]136-bunce , and with sorrowful mien and slow step got into [his]136-bunce accustomed seat near [the fire - place]2555-the fire - place . When [they]378-the men were all in [their]378-the men places , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding rose to address [them]378-the men ; and then finding [himself]102-mr. harding not quite at [home]3108-home on [his]102-mr. harding legs , [he]102-mr. harding sat down again . " [[My]102-mr. harding dear old friends]4476-my dear old friends , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding , " [you]4476-my dear old friends all know that [I]102-mr. harding am going to leave [you]4476-my dear old friends . "[102-mr. harding] There was a sort of murmur ran round [the room]3355-the room , intended , perhaps , to express regret at [his]102-mr. harding departure ; but it was but a murmur , and might have meant that or anything else . " There has been lately some misunderstanding between [us]4477-we . [You]4476-my dear old friends have thought , [I]119-handy believe , that [you]4476-my dear old friends did not get all that [you]4476-my dear old friends were entitled to , and that the funds of [the hospital]364-the hospital have not been properly disposed of . As for [me]119-handy , [I]119-handy can not say what should be the disposition of these moneys , or how they should be managed , and [I]119-handy have therefore thought it best to go . "[119-handy] " [We]4477-we never wanted to drive [your]4476-my dear old friends reverence out of it , "[119-handy] said [Handy]119-handy . " No , indeed , [your]4476-my dear old friends reverence , "[141-skulpit] said [Skulpit]141-skulpit . " [We]4477-we never thought it would come to this . "[143-moody] said [Moody]143-moody . " No , "[102-mr. harding] continued [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding ; " [I]102-mr. harding am sure [you]4476-my dear old friends did not wish to turn [me]102-mr. harding out ; but [I]102-mr. harding thought it best to leave [you]4476-my dear old friends . [I]102-mr. harding am [not a very good hand at a lawsuit]4479-not a very good hand at a lawsuit , as [you]4476-my dear old friends may all guess ; and when it seemed necessary that [our]4477-we ordinary quiet mode of living should be disturbed , [I]102-mr. harding thought it better to go . [I]102-mr. harding am neither angry nor offended with [any man in [the hospital]364-the hospital]4480-any man in the hospital . "[102-mr. harding] [Here Bunce]136-bunce uttered a kind of groan , very clearly expressive of disagreement . " [I]102-mr. harding am neither angry nor displeased with [any man in [the hospital]364-the hospital]4480-any man in the hospital , "[102-mr. harding] repeated [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , emphatically . " If [any man]4484-any man has been wrong — and [I]102-mr. harding do n't say [any man]4484-any man has — [he]4484-any man has erred through wrong advice . In [this country]4486-this country all are entitled to look for [their]4484-any man own rights , and [you]4476-my dear old friends have done no more . As long as [your]4476-my dear old friends interests and [my]102-mr. harding interests were at variance , [I]102-mr. harding could give [you]4476-my dear old friends no counsel on this subject ; but the connection between [us]4487-us has ceased ; [my]102-mr. harding income can no longer depend on [your]4476-my dear old friends doings , and therefore , as [I]102-mr. harding leave [you]4476-my dear old friends , [I]102-mr. harding venture to offer to [you]4476-my dear old friends [my]102-mr. harding advice . "[102-mr. harding] [The men]378-the men all declared that [they]378-the men would from henceforth be entirely guided by [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's opinion in [their]378-the men affairs . " [Some gentleman]4488-some gentleman will probably take [my]102-mr. harding place [here]904-here very soon , and [I]102-mr. harding strongly advise [you]4476-my dear old friends to be prepared to receive [him]4488-some gentleman in a kindly spirit , and to raise no further question among [yourselves]4476-my dear old friends as to the amount of [his]4488-some gentleman income . Were [you]4476-my dear old friends to succeed in lessening what [he]4488-some gentleman has to receive , [you]4476-my dear old friends would not increase [your]4476-my dear old friends own allowance . The surplus would not go to [you]4476-my dear old friends ; [your]4476-my dear old friends wants are adequately provided for , and [your]4476-my dear old friends position could hardly be improved . "[102-mr. harding] " [God]159-god bless [your]4476-my dear old friends reverence , [we]159-god knows it , "[145-spriggs] said [Spriggs]145-spriggs . God bless [you]102-mr. harding , [[my]102-mr. harding friends]989-my friends ! "[102-mr. harding] and [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding drank [his]102-mr. harding wine . Another murmur , somewhat more articulate than the first , passed round the circle , and this time it was intended to imply a blessing on [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding . It had , however , but little cordiality in it . [Poor old men]2842-poor old men ! how could [they]2842-poor old men be cordial with [their]2842-poor old men sore consciences and shamed faces ? how could [they]2842-poor old men bid [God]245-god bless [him]102-mr. harding with hearty voices and [a true benison]2561-a true benison , knowing , as [they]2842-poor old men did , that [[their]2842-poor old men vile cabal]2562-their vile cabal had driven [him]102-mr. harding from [[his]102-mr. harding happy home]2563-his happy home , and sent [him]102-mr. harding in [his]102-mr. harding old age to seek shelter under a strange roof - tree ? [They]2842-poor old men did [their]2842-poor old men best , however ; [they]2842-poor old men drank [their]2842-poor old men wine , and withdrew . As [they]2842-poor old men left [the hall]3939-the hall - door , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding shook hands with [each of [the men]378-the men]2565-each of the men , and spoke a kind word to [them]378-the men about [their]378-the men individual cases and ailments ; and so [they]2842-poor old men departed , answering [his]102-mr. harding questions in the fewest words , and retreated to [[their]2842-poor old men dens]2567-their dens , [a sorrowful repentant crew]2568-a sorrowful repentant crew . All but [Bunce]136-bunce , who still remained to make [his]136-bunce own farewell . " There 's poor old [Bell]162-mary , "[102-mr. harding] said [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , " [I]102-mr. harding must n't go without saying a word to [him]3683-the old man ; come through with [me]102-mr. harding , [Bunce]136-bunce , and bring the wine with [you]136-bunce ; "[102-mr. harding] and so [they]2842-poor old men went through to [[the men]378-the men 's cottages]2570-the men 's cottages , and found [the old man]3683-the old man propped up as usual in [his]3683-the old man bed . " And [your]102-mr. harding reverence , "[3683-the old man] said [he]3683-the old man , and then [he]3683-the old man paused , while [his]3683-the old man old palsied head shook horribly , and [his]3683-the old man shrivelled cheeks sank lower within [his]3683-the old man jaws , and [his]3683-the old man glazy eye gleamed with a momentary light ; " and , [your]102-mr. harding reverence , shall [we]4503-we get the hundred a - year then ? "[3683-the old man] How gently did [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding try to extinguish the false hope of money which had been so wretchedly raised to disturb the quiet of [the dying man]2578-the dying man ! One other week and [his]3683-the old man mortal coil would be shuffled off ; in one short week would [God]245-god resume [his]3683-the old man soul , and set it apart for its irrevocable doom ; seven more tedious days and nights of senseless inactivity , and all would be over for poor [Bell]162-mary in [this world]2844-this world ; and yet , with [his]3683-the old man last audible words , [he]3683-the old man was demanding [his]3683-the old man moneyed rights , and asserting [himself]3683-the old man to be [the proper heir of [John Hiram]107-john hiram 's bounty]2580-the proper heir of john hiram 's bounty ! Not on [him]3683-the old man , [poor sinner as [he]3683-the old man was]2581-poor sinner as he was , be the load of such sin ! [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding returned to [[his]102-mr. harding parlour]2521-his parlour , meditating with a sick heart on what [he]102-mr. harding had seen , and [Bunce]136-bunce with [him]102-mr. harding . [We]2583-we will not describe the parting of [these two good men]2584-these two good men , for [good men]2585-good men [they]2584-these two good men were . It was in vain that [the late warden]2586-the late warden endeavoured to comfort the heart of [the old bedesman]3680-the old bedesman ; [poor old Bunce]136-bunce felt that [his]136-bunce days of comfort were gone . [The hospital]364-the hospital had to [him]136-bunce been [a happy home]2589-a happy home , but it could be so no longer . [He]136-bunce had had honour [there]713-there , and friendship ; [he]136-bunce had recognised [[his]136-bunce master]1703-his master , and been recognised ; all [his]136-bunce wants , both of soul and body , had been supplied , and [he]136-bunce had been [a happy man]2592-a happy man . [He]136-bunce wept grievously as [he]136-bunce parted from [[his]136-bunce friend]285-his friend , and the tears of [an old man]2594-an old man are bitter . " It is all over for [me]136-bunce in [this world]2844-this world , "[136-bunce] said [he]136-bunce , as [he]136-bunce gave the last squeeze to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's hand ; " [I]136-bunce have now to forgive those who have injured [me]136-bunce — and to die . "[136-bunce] And so [the old man]3683-the old man went out , and then [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding gave way to [his]102-mr. harding grief , and [he]102-mr. harding too wept aloud . [Our]2596-our tale is now done , and it only remains to [us]2596-our to collect the scattered threads of [our]2596-our little story , and to tie them into a seemly knot . This will not be a work of labour , either to [the author]432-the author or to [[his]432-the author readers]2598-his readers ; [we]2596-our have not to deal with [many personages]2599-many personages , or with stirring events , and were it not for the custom of the thing , [we]2596-our might leave it to the imagination of [all concerned]2600-all concerned to conceive how affairs at [Barchester]6-barchester arranged themselves . On the morning after the day last alluded to , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , at an early hour , walked out of [the hospital]364-the hospital , with [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter under [his]102-mr. harding arm , and sat down quietly to breakfast at [[his]102-mr. harding lodgings]1756-his lodgings over [the chemist 's shop]2604-the chemist 's shop . There was no parade about [his]102-mr. harding departure ; [no one]283-no one , not even [Bunce]136-bunce , was there to witness it : had [he]102-mr. harding walked to [the apothecary 's]2606-the apothecary 's thus early to get a piece of court plaster , or a box of lozenges , [he]102-mr. harding could not have done it with less appearance of an important movement . There was a tear in [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's eye as [she]104-eleanor passed through the big gateway and over [the bridge]405-the bridge ; but [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding walked with an elastic step , and entered [[his]102-mr. harding new abode]2608-his new abode with a pleasant face . " Now , [[my]102-mr. harding dear]2725-my dear , "[102-mr. harding] said [he]102-mr. harding , " [you]2725-my dear have everything ready , and [you]2725-my dear can make tea [here]904-here just as nicely as in [the parlour at [the hospital]364-the hospital]4507-the parlour at the hospital . "[102-mr. harding] So [Eleanor]104-eleanor took off [her]104-eleanor bonnet and made the tea . After this manner did [the late Warden of [Barchester Hospital]29-barchester hospital]2609-the late warden of barchester hospital accomplish [his]2609-the late warden of barchester hospital flitting , and change [[his]2609-the late warden of barchester hospital residence]2610-his residence . It was not long before [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon brought [[his]382-the archdeacon father]508-his father to discuss the subject of [a new warden]2613-a new warden . Of course [he]102-mr. harding looked upon the nomination as [his]102-mr. harding own , and [he]102-mr. harding had in [his]102-mr. harding eye three or four fitting candidates , seeing that [Mr. Cumming]237-cumming 's plan as to the living of [Puddingdale]98-puddingdale could not be brought to bear . How can [I]0-i describe the astonishment which confounded [him]102-mr. harding , when [[his]382-the archdeacon father]508-his father declared that [he]508-his father would appoint [no successor to [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding]2615-no successor to mr. harding ? " If [we]4509-we can get the matter set to rights , [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding will return , "[260-the bishop] said [the bishop]260-the bishop ; " and if [we]4509-we can not , it will be wrong to put [any other gentleman]4510-any other gentleman into so cruel a position . "[260-the bishop] It was in vain that [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon argued and lectured , and even threatened ; in vain [he]382-the archdeacon my - lorded [[his]382-the archdeacon poor father]2618-his poor father in [his]382-the archdeacon sternest manner ; in vain [his]382-the archdeacon " good heavens ! "[382-the archdeacon] were ejaculated in a tone that might have moved a whole synod , let alone [one weak and aged bishop]2619-one weak and aged bishop . Nothing would induce [[his]382-the archdeacon father]508-his father to fill up the vacancy caused by [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding 's retirement . Even [John Bold]121-bold would have pitied the feelings with which [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon returned to [Plumstead]20-plumstead : [the church]454-the church was falling , nay , already in ruins ; [[its]454-the church dignitaries]2623-its dignitaries were yielding without a struggle before the blows of [its antagonists]2624-its antagonists ; and [one of [[its]454-the church most respected bishops]2626-its most respected bishops , [[his]382-the archdeacon own father]2627-his own father]2625-one of its most respected bishops , his own father — [the man considered by all [the world]325-the world as being in such matters under [his]382-the archdeacon , [Dr. Grantly]106-dr. grantly 's control]2628-the man considered by all the world as being in such matters under his , dr. grantly 's control — had positively resolved to capitulate , and own [himself]2627-his own father vanquished ! And how fared [the hospital]364-the hospital under this resolve of [[its]364-the hospital visitor]2631-its visitor ? Badly indeed . It is now some years since [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding left [it]364-the hospital , and [[the warden]318-the warden 's house]3248-the warden 's house is still tenantless . [Old Bell]246-old bell has died , and [Billy Gazy]174-billy gazy and poor bedridden bell ; [the one - eyed Spriggs]2634-the one - eyed spriggs has drunk [himself]2634-the one - eyed spriggs to death , and [three others of the twelve]2635-three others of the twelve have been gathered into the [church - yard mould]2636-church - yard mould . [Six]247-six have gone , and the six vacancies remain unfilled ! Yes , [six]2637-six have died , with [no kind friend]2638-no kind friend to solace [their]2637-six last moments , with [no wealthy neighbour]2639-no wealthy neighbour to administer comforts and ease the stings of death . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , indeed , did not desert [them]2637-six ; from [him]102-mr. harding [they]2637-six had such consolation as [a dying man]2640-a dying man may receive from [[his]2640-a dying man Christian pastor]2641-his christian pastor ; but it was the occasional kindness of [a stranger]3873-a stranger which ministered to [them]2637-six , and not the constant presence of [a master]4491-a master , [a neighbour]2644-a neighbour , and [a friend]1011-a friend . Nor were those who remained better off than [those who died]2646-those who died . Dissensions rose among [them]2637-six , and contests for pre - eminence ; and then [they]2637-six began to understand that soon one among [them]2637-six would be [the last,—some one wretched being]2647-the last,—some one wretched being would be alone there in [that now comfortless hospital,—the miserable relic of what had once been so good and comfortable]2648-that now comfortless hospital,—the miserable relic of what had once been so good and comfortable . [The building of [the hospital itself]2650-the hospital itself]2649-the building of the hospital itself has not been allowed to go to ruins . [Mr. Chadwick]109-mr. chadwick , who still holds [his]109-mr. chadwick stewardship , and pays the accruing rents into an account opened at [a bank for the purpose]2651-a bank for the purpose , sees to that ; but [the whole place]2652-the whole place has become disordered and ugly . [[The warden]318-the warden 's garden]3011-the warden 's garden is [a wretched wilderness]2655-a wretched wilderness , [the drive and paths]2656-the drive and paths are covered with weeds , the flower - beds are bare , and the unshorn lawn is now a mass of long damp grass and unwholesome moss . The beauty of [the place]794-the place is gone ; [its]794-the place attractions have withered . Alas ! a very few years since [it]794-the place was [the prettiest spot in [Barchester]6-barchester]2658-the prettiest spot in barchester , and now [it]794-the place is a disgrace to [the city]2485-the city . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding did not go out to [Crabtree Parva]42-crabtree parva . An arrangement was made which respected [the homestead of [Mr. Smith]208-smith]2660-the homestead of mr. smith and [[his]208-smith happy family]2661-his happy family , and put [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding into possession of [a small living within [the walls of [the city]2485-the city]2663-the walls of the city]2662-a small living within the walls of the city . [It]2665-it is [the smallest possible parish]2666-the smallest possible parish , containing [a part of [the Cathedral Close]393-the cathedral close and [a few old houses]2669-a few old houses adjoining]2667-a part of the cathedral close and a few old houses adjoining . [The church]454-the church is [a singular little Gothic building , perched over a gateway , through which the Close is entered]2671-a singular little gothic building , perched over a gateway , through which the close is entered , and is approached by a flight of stone steps which leads down under the archway of the gate . It is no bigger than an ordinary room,—perhaps twenty - seven feet long by eighteen wide,—but still [it]454-the church is [a perfect church]2672-a perfect church . [It]454-the church contains an old carved pulpit and reading - desk , a tiny altar under a window filled with dark old - coloured glass , a font , some half - dozen pews , and perhaps a dozen seats for [the poor]1029-the poor , and also a vestry . The roof is high - pitched , and of black old oak , and the three large beams which support [it]454-the church run down to the side walls , and terminate in grotesquely carved faces — two devils and [an angel on one side]2674-an angel on one side , [two angels]2675-two angels and [a devil on the other]2676-a devil on the other . Such is [the church of [St. Cuthbert]248-st. cuthbert at [Barchester]6-barchester]2677-the church of st. cuthbert at barchester , of which [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding became [rector]2678-rector , with a clear income of seventy - five pounds a - year . Here [he]102-mr. harding performs afternoon service every Sunday , and administers the Sacrament once in every three months . [His]102-mr. harding audience is not large ; and , had [they]2679-they been so , [he]102-mr. harding could not have accommodated [them]2679-they : but enough come to fill [his]102-mr. harding six pews , and , on the front seat of those devoted to [the poor]1029-the poor is always to be seen [[our]2681-our old friend]4224-our old friend [Mr. Bunce]136-bunce , decently arrayed in [his]136-bunce bedesman 's gown . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding is still [precentor of [Barchester]6-barchester]442-precentor of barchester ; and it is very rarely the case that [those who attend the Sunday morning service]2684-those who attend the sunday morning service miss the gratification of hearing [him]102-mr. harding chant the Litany , as [no other man in [England]14-england]2685-no other man in england can do it . [He]102-mr. harding is neither a discontented nor [an unhappy man]2686-an unhappy man ; [he]102-mr. harding still inhabits [the lodgings to which [he]102-mr. harding went on leaving [the hospital]364-the hospital]2687-the lodgings to which he went on leaving the hospital , but [he]102-mr. harding now has them to [himself]102-mr. harding . Three months after that time [Eleanor]104-eleanor became [Mrs. Bold]249-mrs. bold , and of course removed to [[[her]104-eleanor husband]611-her husband 's house]2690-her husband 's house . There were some difficulties to be got over on the occasion of the marriage . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon , who could not so soon overcome [his]382-the archdeacon grief , would not be persuaded to grace the ceremony with [his]382-the archdeacon presence , but [he]382-the archdeacon allowed [[his]382-the archdeacon wife]607-his wife and [children]3456-children to be [there]713-there . The marriage took place at [the palace]947-the palace , and [the bishop]260-the bishop [himself]260-the bishop officiated . It was the last occasion on which [he]260-the bishop ever did so ; and , though [he]260-the bishop still lives , it is not probable that [he]260-the bishop will ever do so again . Not long after the marriage , perhaps six months , when [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's bridal - honours were fading , and [persons]1180-persons were beginning to call [her]104-eleanor [Mrs. Bold]249-mrs. bold without twittering , [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon consented to meet [John Bold]121-bold at a dinner - party , and since that time [they]2699-they have become [almost friends]2700-almost friends . [The archdeacon]382-the archdeacon firmly believes that [[his]382-the archdeacon brother - in - law]861-his brother - in - law was , as [a bachelor]2373-a bachelor , [an infidel]2704-an infidel , an unbeliever in the great truths of [our]2705-our religion ; but that matrimony has opened [his]382-the archdeacon eyes , as it has those of [others]551-others . [And Bold]121-bold is equally inclined to think that time has softened the asperities of [the archdeacon]382-the archdeacon 's character . Friends though [they]2699-they are , [they]2699-they do not often revert to the feud of [the hospital]364-the hospital . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding , [we]2705-our say , is not [an unhappy man]2686-an unhappy man ; [he]102-mr. harding keeps [[his]102-mr. harding lodgings]1756-his lodgings , but they are of little use to [him]102-mr. harding , except as being [the one spot on earth which [he]102-mr. harding calls [his]102-mr. harding own]2711-the one spot on earth which he calls his own . [His]102-mr. harding time is spent chiefly at [[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter 's or at [the palace]947-the palace ; [he]102-mr. harding is never left alone , even should [he]102-mr. harding wish to be so ; and within a twelvemonth of [Eleanor]104-eleanor 's marriage [his]102-mr. harding determination to live at [[his]102-mr. harding own lodging]2714-his own lodging had been so far broken through and abandoned , that [he]102-mr. harding consented to have [his]102-mr. harding violoncello permanently removed to [[[his]102-mr. harding daughter]280-his daughter 's house]2716-his daughter 's house . Every other day a message is brought to [him]102-mr. harding from [the bishop]260-the bishop . " [The bishop]260-the bishop 's compliments , and [[his]3683-the old man lordship]2863-his lordship is not very well to - day , and [he]3683-the old man hopes [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding will dine with [him]3683-the old man . "[260-the bishop] This bulletin as to [the old man]3683-the old man 's health is a myth ; for though [he]3683-the old man is over eighty [he]3683-the old man is never ill , and will probably die some day , as a spark goes out , gradually and without a struggle . [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding does dine with [him]3683-the old man very often , which means going to [the palace]947-the palace at three and remaining till ten ; and whenever [he]3683-the old man does not [the bishop]260-the bishop whines , and says that the port wine is corked , and complains that [nobody]1025-nobody attends to [him]3683-the old man , and frets [himself]3683-the old man off to bed an hour before [his]3683-the old man time . It was long before [the people of [Barchester]6-barchester]2722-the people of barchester forgot to call [Mr. Harding]102-mr. harding by [his]102-mr. harding long well - known name of [Warden]304-warden . It had become so customary to say [Mr. Warden]234-mr. warden , that it was not easily dropped .
